 Document(page_content='Chapter One: \nGeneral Poker Strategy - Introduction  \nPoker is a game of people. That\'s the most important lesson you should learn \nfrom my book.  \nI\'ll be teaching you guidelines and conc epts you\'ll be able to use with great \nsuccess, and you\'ll quickly become a very good player. But, if your ambition \nis to become a great player, a top flight Pro, a superstar ... you\'ll need to really \nunderstand your opponents. You\'ll need to get inside your opponent\'s head \nand be able to estimate with a high de gree of certainty what his check, bet or \nraise really means ... and what hand he\'s likely to be playing.  \nBeing able to do that accurately isn\'t easy. But you can do it if you\'re alert, \nobservant, disciplined and if you concen trate whenever you play (whether or \nnot you\'re involved in the pot). Using my  advice and the advice of my expert \ncollaborators, you\'ll find that the "t ask" of unmasking your Poker faced \nopponents will become easier and easier.  \nWhen you\'re able to put your opponent  on exactly the hand he\'s playing \n(because you know him almost as well as he knows himself) you can select \nthe best strategy possible for that particular Poker situation. When you reach \nthat level of skill, you\'ll be a complete player.  \nThat\'s what Poker\'s all about. People ...and the strategy you use against them. \nMore than any other game, Poker de pends on your understanding your \nopponent. You\'ve got to know what makes him tick. More importantly, \nyou\'ve got to know what makes him tick  at the moment you\'re involved in a \npot with him. What\'s his mood ... his feeling? What\'s his apparent \npsychological frame of mind right now? Is  he in the Mood to gamble ... or is \nhe just sitting there waiting for the nuts? Is he a loser and on tilt (playing far \nbelow his normal capability) ... or has he screwed down (despite his being \nloser) and begun playing his best possi ble game? Is he a cocky winner who\'s \nnow playing carelessly and throwing off most of his winnings...or is he a \nwinner who\'s started to play very ti ght so he can protect his gains?  \nWhen you can accurately answer questi ons like those (and there are many \nmore like them) ... and employ the other ideas, principles, rules, techniques \nand strategies I\'ll teach you in this book you\'ll be one super tough Poker \nplayer.  \nPut all of it together and your play ing ability will border on being World \nClass.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 1}),
 Document(page_content="It takes a lot to play winning Poker at  a World Class level because Poker is \nsuch a complex game more complex than any other game ... or any other form \nof gambling.  \nFor example, the difference between pl aying good Poker and playing good \nBlackjack is as vast as the difference between squad tactics and grand strategy \nin warfare. You can beat a Blackjack game by knowing exactly what to do in every situation...and doing it. That's tactics. But in Poker you may face an \nidentical situation twice against the same opponent, handle it two different \nways, and be right both times. That's strategy.  \nAnd that's why there's never going to be a computer that will play World \nClass Poker. It's a people game.  \nA computer could be programmed to ha ndle the extensive mathematics of a \nPoker game. But the psychological complexities are another matter. A system \nfigured out by computer can beat Blackjack because there the dealer has no \noptions. He has to stand on 17, he has to hit 16.  \nA computer could play fair to middling Poker. But no computer could ever \nstand face to face with a table full of people it had never met before, and make \nquality, high profit decisions based on psychology.  \nTo do that requires perception and ju dgement. It requires a human mind.  \nThe way I accumulate knowledge of a part icular player is by listening to him, \nand looking at him, instead of talking.  \nPAY ATTENTION...and it will pay you   \nConcentrate on everything when yo u're playing. Watch and listen ... \nremember you have to do both, and rela te the two. You listen to what your \nopponent says, but you watch what he's doing independently of what he says \nbecause a lot of players talk loose and play tight, and a little later they'll \nreverse it on you. So you look at a ma n every time he's involved in a hand. \nYou judge him every time. That's the way you get to know him and his \nmoves.  \nIf you aren't learning what you want to know just by watching and listening, \ncreate your own opportunity. Try to bluff at him the first good opportunity, \nand see if he'll call you or not what kind of hand he'll call with, and what kind \nhe'll throw away. Of course, anybody with a lick of sense is trying to keep you \nfrom reading him. But you can still figure him because it is very, very difficult \nfor any man to conceal his character.  \nA man's true feelings come out in a Poker game", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 2}),
 Document(page_content='You\'ll see smart lawyers playing Poke r and giggling and carrying on like \nschool kids. And a man\'s hostilities can boil over after a while, too.  \nWatch a ballgame with a man when he\'s betting a lot of money on it. You\'ll \nlearn what kind of temperament he\'s got, how well he can take \ndisappointment. That\'s the way it is with Poker.  \nIf you wanted to use Poker just for a te st of character, solely to learn about the \nmen you\'ll have to deal with away from the Poker table, it would be a telling \ntest. As a matter of fact, isn\'t that wh at a lot of Friday night Poker games \nbetween business acquaintances are really all about? Size them up at the \nFriday night Poker sessions ... and then take advantage of them during the \nnext business week.  \nThis brings us to another subtlety of Poker: Not everybody you\'re going to \nplay against thinks the way you do. Almost everybody wants to win, but they \nexpect to win in different ways.  \nPLAY AGGRESSIVELY, it\'s the winning way   \nThere\'s a very well known Poker player, a man who enters the World Series of \nPoker  every year, who has a talent for figuring out exactly what your hand is. \nBut when he decides that you\'re holding a Pair of Jacks (in Hold \'em) and his \nown hand will not beat the Jacks, he\'ll try to make you throw your hand \naway.  \nTo me, that\'s not being aggressive ... th at\'s being stupid. It works sometimes, \nbut should you jeopardize your money when you think your opponent\'s got a \ngood hand? Let him win the pot and wait till you think he doesn\'t have much \nof anything. That\'s when you can try to bluff him out of the pot. Or wait until \nyou think you have him beat.  \nEverybody in Poker thinks he knows what a tight  player is, but I\'m going to \ndefine it again because so many people confuse the term "tight" with "solid".  \n"Tight" means conservative. A tight player is a player that is tight pretty much \nall the time.  \nBut a "solid" player is a player who\'s tight about entering a pot in the first \nplace ... but after he enters the pot he becomes aggressive.   \nMost good players, by the way, are solid.  \nThe opposite of the tight player, as yo u would imagine from the name, is the \nloose player. He\'ll play most of the pots. Often he\'ll be drunk. You need \npatience to play him, and you require a good hand to bet because he\'ll call \nyou with extremely weak hands.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 3}),
 Document(page_content="The perfect opponent to face is the Calling Station . He's similar to a loose \ndrunk player, but he rarely bets. Most of the time, he just checks and calls. \nAnd if you cant beat a man who always checks to you ... you can't beat \nanyone.   \nTimid players don't win in high stakes Poker.   \nAs you'll learn, I don't fit into any of  the classic categories. I have the \nreputation of being a very aggressive play er with a definite tendency to be on \nthe loose side. But, despite my aggressiveness and looseness, I exercise a \nconsiderable amount of judgement whenever I play", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 4}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter One: \nGeneral Poker Strategy - Tells  \nTELLS - look for them...and you\'ll find them   \nOnce you\'ve pegged a player\'s basic style, don\'t make the mistake of \nassuming he\'s going to play that same way every day of his life. Sometimes a \nplayer makes a conscious effort to change his manner of play. More often, \nhowever, his current mood affects his play.  \nSome days people have more of a playin g spirit than on other days. If a man \ndoesn\'t feel like playing, and has beco me involved in a game anyway, he\'ll \nthrow his hand away very easily. He can be bluffed.  \nBut if you see another guy sitting ther e chewing gum, and bouncing his leg \nup and down, you know he\'s anxious to get into action. He came to play. You \nhave to handle him with caution. It\'s not safe to bluff him, at least not to start with.  \nAlmost all players have Tells ... those giveaway moves that are almost as \nrevealing, to a rival who has spotted them, as actually showing him your \nhand.  \nThe most common Tell is the pulse in a man\'s neck. On a lot of people, the \npulse in the neck is visible. If so, a man can\'t hide it, since nobody can control \ntheir heartbeat in stress situations. When  you see a man\'s neck just throbbing \naway, you know he\'s excited, and usually  he\'s excited because he is bluffing.  \nYou may have heard someone ask another player: "How deep are you?" That \nquestion is sometimes an attempt to es tablish a Tell. (The question means: \nHow much money do you have in front of you?) It\'s worth knowing. I don\'t \nthink a player should be obligated to tell you, even though I have heard it \nargued both ways.  \nQuestions like that are worth asking for psychological reasons. When a man\'s \nunder pressure, his voice may break, and then you know something about his \ncurrent attitude.  \nWhen I\'m playing in a big pot, I won\'t let anyone involve me in \nconversation.   \nEven real Pros are susceptible. On ce I had a Tell on Puggy Pearson. Every \ntime he put his chips in the rack and be t them, he was bluffing. He must have \nbeen doing that six months before somebo dy else discovered it and told him.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 5}),
 Document(page_content='Another time, Amarillo Slim Preston poin ted out to me that I was counting \nmy chips off and betting them when I had a hand, and when I was bluffing I \nwould just push them in without counti ng. That\'s the only Tell anyone had on \nme that I know about, but I\'m sure there have been others.  \nAll top Professionals have a defense against people using Tells against them. \nSometimes when I\'m bluffing I say some particular thing, like "gee whiz", so \nthat people will connect that with bluff.  \nBut the next time I say "gee whiz", I won\'t be bluffing.  \nWith a great deal of experience, you may learn not only whether a man is \nbluffing or has a quality hand, but the actual cards he holds. This is what \npeople mean when they say a particular player can "put a man on a hand". \nMy natural ability along these lines has contributed a lot to my success.  \nI remember playing in a game wher e you could almost tell what Jimmy \nCassella had by the amount he would raise. That\'s the only thing you had to \nknow. With an A 10 in Hold \'em, he\'d raise about $100; with an A J, he\'d raise \n$125, and so forth.  \nOther players have patterns that, while less pronounced, are definitely visible \nto a Poker Professional. You take into account the way they are sitting, their \nprevious playing habits, how they bet, an d often even the tone of their voices. \nIt\'s the totality of everything about them rather than any one particular thing.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 6}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter One: \nGeneral Poker Strategy - ESP  \nESP - it\'s a Jellyroll   \nThis book will deal scientifically wi th Tells and with psychology, but \nsometimes you don\'t even know how yo u know ... only that you\'re sure of \nwhat your opponent has.  \nI believe some good Poker players actually employ a degree of extrasensory \nperception (ESP). While I\'ve never studie d the subject in depth, it seems to me \nthere\'s too much evidence to ignore that ESP exists or that most people have it \nto some degree. Everybody has had the experience of riding with someone \nelse in an automobile and thinking of a song, then being surprised to hear his \ncompanion start singing that very song.  \nYou can\'t imagine how often I\'ve called a player\'s exact hand to myself and \nbeen proven right. There\'s even a pl ausible, though completely unproven, \nexplanation how a person could know what cards another player is holding. \nThe brain\'s functions involve electrical impulses. In this electronic age we\'re \nbecoming more familiar every day with Appliances which broadcast, purely \nas an unintentional by product, ener gy impulses which are picked up on \ndissimilar appliances at considerable distances.  \nIs it really too unreasonable to susp ect that such a highly sophisticated \nelectrical device as the human brain, du ring the intensity of concentration in a \nbig pot, could broadcast a simple message like a "pair of Jacks" a mere eight \nfeet?  \nI hope I live to see that question answered, and not merely asked. I like to \nthink of ESP as a Jellyroll anyway.  \nIn the meantime, use all the sophistica ted techniques and strategies presented \nin this book in determining whether or not to call, bet or raise. But in the rare \nsituations when all your card knowle dge and best judgement leave you in \ndoubt, go with your strong feeling ... and not against it.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 7}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter One: \nGeneral Poker Strategy - \nSuperstitions  \nSuperstitions - There Are Bigger Faults   \nI don't believe in the traditional superstiti ons, but there are a couple that I still \nhonor. Like most Poker players, I don't like to be paid in $50 bills. But there's \nalso a reason for that. It's easy to mistake a $50 bill for a $5 bill.  \nAnd I don't eat peanuts at a card table. There's no reason in the world eating \npeanuts should affect the outcome of  the game, but it doesn't cost me \nanything to observe the taboo against it, so  I observe it. That's a jellyroll, too. \nAnd ... there are bigger faults a player can have.  \nWhen I lose a pot, I sometimes get up  and walk around the chair. Some Poker \nplayers do that to change their lu ck. I do it just to cool off.  \nNor do I like to see women at a Poker table. That's not superstition, either. I \nwas brought up to respect women, and I just don't feel comfortable in high stakes warfare against women.  \nI've never met a woman who was a rea lly top player. Maybe that's because \nthere aren't a lot of women players. I have, however, seen some who were \npretty good, even by Professional standards.  \nI doubt that any of my children will decide to play professionally. It can be a \nvery good life, and it has been for me , but my children haven't come from the \nbackground that produces good Poker players. You try to make life a little \neasier for your kids than it was for you (and rightfully so), but the other side \nof that coin is that they're not forced to be so competitive when they're young, \nand are unlikely to develop the instin ct it takes to be a good player.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 8}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter One: \nGeneral Poker Strategy - Honor  \nHonor - A Gambler' s Ace in the Hole   \nIt is good insurance to have the reputa tion and respect that make it possible \nfor you to borrow money, but borrowing is to be avoided. The first time I \ncame to Las Vegas, I lost my entire bankroll of $70,000, and I got up from the \nPoker table and didn't ask anyone fo r anything. And the men who were at \nthat Poker table will always respect me for that, even though I have loaned \nmoney to some of them, and they to me, since.  \nI was completely broke when I got home to Fort Worth. I got a $20 bill \nsomewhere, and started grinding it out playing two cent Auction Bridge. \nWhen I built up a little bankroll, I move d into richer company, and eventually \nreturned to Vegas.  \nDon't borrow from anyone you don' t want to loan money to.   \nI could've made a faster comeback by borrowing money, but you have to be \ncareful whom you borrow from in the gambling business. And if you make \nup your mind to use the credit you have, you may not manage your money so \nwell, or the money you borrow.  \nWhen you've mismanaged somebody's mone y, it is hard to compete against \nhim. It's hard even to play in the same game.  \nMake it a practice never to be staked, never to borrow money if you can help \nit. And if you can't help borrowing, bo rrow the minimum, and pay it back on \nthe exact day you promise...or sooner.  \nYou must maintain a reputation for honor in the gambling business. Your \nword must be your bond. It'll be your Ace in the hole.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 9}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter One: \nGeneral Poker Strategy - Being \nCompetitive  \nBe As Competitive As You Can Be   \nFew people realize how intensely competitive you must be to become a good \nPoker player. I couldn't play Poker just for fun, and I don't think many of the \ntop Professionals could. I've always played to win, and whenever I could \ndiscover any bad habits, I've tried to e liminate them just as I would try to \neliminate mistakes in a business I might be running.  \nUse your best game against anybody you play. Many of the top Pros are close \nfriends, but they almost never give each other a break in a game. Sailor \nRoberts, for instance, is one of the best friends I've ever had. He helped pick \nme up when I was young and unknown and broke. But when I play cards \nwith Sailor, I do my level best to cut hi s throat and he tries to cut mine. It's \nbeen like that from the time we met. In fact, the first time we played he broke \nme.  \nIn the trade, this characteristic is called Alligator Blood, and it is highly \nvalued and respected. It means you'll do anything within the rules to win. \nYou try to have special moves, such as ma king a slow, hesitant call in place of \na fast call, when a man might bet at you ag ain (after the next card is turned up \nin Hold 'em). You might set a trap fo r him by leading him to believe you're \nbetting a hand which is a slight favorite , when you actually have a hand that's \npractically unbeatable.  \nI go into a Poker game with the idea of completely destroying it.   \nChanging gears is one of the most impo rtant parts of playing Poker. It means \nshifting from loose to tight play and vice versa. Don't do it gradually...it \nworks better to switch suddenly. Once they catch on, change gears again.  \nIf you're playing with a lineup of people  who have played you before, do this \neven more often. When you really thin k they know you, change gears several \ntimes in one game.  \nIn a No Limit game, the gear to stay in most of the time is the one that most \npeople at the table are not using. In other words:  \nPlay mostly  tight in a loose game, and mostly  loose in a tight game.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 10}),
 Document(page_content="I also vary my play according to how I' m going. If I am losing badly, I play \ntighter. If I'm winning, I try to play looser. Players are more apt to be \nintimidated by me when I'm winning.  \nWhen I'm playing a No Limit game like Hold 'em  or Deuce to Seven Lowball , if I \nwin a pot, I nearly always play the next  pot as well, within reason. Although \nthe cards will break even in the long run, card rushes  do happen. A card rush \nmeans more than that you're winning a lot of pots. It also means that you \nhave temporary command of the game. Your momentum is clear to all the \nplayers. On occasions like this you're going to make correct decisions and \nyour opponents may make errors because they are psychologically affected \nby your rush. Make the most of these opportunities and give yourself the \nchance to enjoy them to the fullest.  \nArt and Science: Playing Great Poker Takes Both   \nPoker is more art than science, and that's  what makes it so difficult to master. \nKnowing what  to do the science is about 10% of the game. Knowing how to \ndo it the art is the other 90%. You not only  have to know when to bet, when to \nraise, and when to fold...you also have to  be able to do those things with a \ncertain finesse.  \nBut one has to start with the basi cs. There are certain things about \nprobabilities that you absolutely must know.  \nThe first is that the cards break even. If you turn over 13 cards from a deck, \nthen reshuffle, and do this again and agai n, the Ac will show up just as many \ntimes (one out of four) if I'm shuff ling them or if you're shuffling them \nyourself.  \nOver a long period of time, the worst pl ayer in the world is going to catch \njust as many good cards as th e best player in the world.   \nWe'll have the same cards to play, but I'll beat him sooner or later because I'm \na better player.  \nThat's universally true. It applies to all forms of Poker.  \nBut...as you'll soon discover...there are certain games that involve a lot more \nskill than others. You have to know what to do with your cards in all types of \nPoker, but the relative importance of th at knowledge varies with the kind of \nPoker you're playing.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 11}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter One: \nGeneral Poker Strategy - Important \nTips  \nAnother thing you should understand is th at Poker is set up in a fashion that \nis not entirely logical. A Royal Flush is the highest hand. But it's just as hard \nto be dealt exactly Jd 9c 6s 4h 2d as Ah Kh Qh Jh 10h, but the first hand is \nworthless. A Flush is better than a Straigh t because it's harder to make than a \nStraight.  \nBut the ranking of the cards themselves is arbitrary. There's no real reason a \nKing should be worth more than a Deuce. (And that's a very good \njustification for playing high cards, particularly in games where winning \nhands often consist of a mere Pair. It's just as easy to make a Pair of Kings as it \nis to make a Pair of Deuces ... but the Kings will get the money.)  \nIn any Poker game you're in ... remember th at it takes a stronger hand to call a \nraise than it takes to raise it yourself.  \nAlso, remember that in Limit Poker, you must show down the best hand \nmost of the time to win. In No Limit, on the other hand, you more often than not take a pot without ever showing your hand.   \nIf you've never had the opportunity to see a real No Limit game, you'd be \nvery surprised how much bluffing there is. Good No Limit players bluff four \nor five times as often as good players in Limit games.  \nYou have to pick your players to bluff. You can hardly bluff a Sucker at all, \nwhereas any good player can be bluffed . But always bear in mind the \nplayer's mood that particular day ... if he's anxious to play, you handle him \nmore cautiously than you would otherwise.  \nBluffing is the main reason I believe No  Limit Poker requires more skill thin \nLimit. Bluffing in No Limit requires re al strategy, and the ability to size up \nyour opponents every time you sit down to play.  \nYet, paradoxically, Poker becomes easier the higher the stakes of the game, at \nleast in games where Professionals are involved.  \nDown in the low Limit games, the Professionals who are involved don't have \nmuch money, and what they do have they 're trying to keep for a stake and to \nlive on. So they're playing the best  Poker they know how to play.  \nBut tip in the high stakes games yo u encounter big businessmen, bookies, \nhotel owners, millionaires...and they're pl aying for entertainment. And they \nare not playing hard.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 12}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter One: \nGeneral Poker Strategy - Money \nManagement  \nI've never been as conservative abou t money management as most successful \npeople are. I don't think your bankroll is the only factor you should consider \nin deciding whether or not to play in a high limit game.  \nIf the game cries out to be played, in if it's a good game, you feel good, and if \nyou aren't tired, you should try that game even if it is higher than you \nnormally would play. And you should st ay in it until the game becomes bad \nor you grow tired.  \nOf course, you make that decision with in reason. Any time you extend your \nbankroll so far that if you lost, it woul d really distress you, you probably will \nlose. It's tough to play your be st under that much pressure.  \nI prefer using judgement on individual games rather than hard rules, but if \nyou want such a rule, I would suggest yo u not play $10 limit until you have at \nleast a $1000 bankroll (not the buy in).  \nIn No Limit, you'll usually want a bi gger bankroll for a game of the same \ngeneral size. In a No Limit game with two Blinds of $5 and $10, I'd say you need at least $2,500.  \nTo play No Limit $5, $10, $25 and $50 (Fou r Blinds), you'd need about $10,000.  \nIt's been a long time since I was broke, but the way I always got broke was by \nplaying with desperation money. I let myself get into too much of a hurry, \nand played in games I didn't have the bankroll for.  \nIf you have a limited bankroll, be very  certain to get the maximum amount of \ngamble you can for your money. That's an important factor to consider in \npicking your games. If you have only a Small amount of money to invest in a \ngame, and if you have a wide choice of games (like you do in Las Vegas), you \nmay be better off playing a small No Li mit game than a high Limit game. If \nyou have $10,000 you can afford to lose in one game, you might be better off \nrisking it in a No Limit game, simply be cause if you do get lucky, you can win \nreal big and your bankroll might get healthy fast.  \nWhen I buy into a No Limit game, I want to have as many checks in front of \nme as anybody else at the table, or mo re. I'm not afraid, and you shouldn't be \nafraid, of getting drawn out on a hand and going through the whole stack. All \nyour efforts in Poker are directed tow ard getting in a position to bet the \nmaximum amount you can on the hand s that are worth it. When those", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 13}),
 Document(page_content='opportunities do occur, you don\'t want to  be limited in the amount of action \nyou can accept.  \nAlways play for Chips, rather than cash.  \nChips are easier to win. A $5 chip is th e same size as a $500 chip it\'s just not \nthe same color. If you bet a man $20,000 in $500 chips, that\'s only forty chips, \ntwo stacks. But if you bet him $20,000 in $100 bills, it would be a big pile of \nmoney, and would tend to freeze him up.  \nThe way to get a person to convert to chips is to point out to him that it takes \ntoo long to count out the bills. It\'s the tr uth, and a legitimate reason to change \nto chips, though not really the reason you\'re doing it.  \nIt\'s also to your own advantage to thin k of chips as units, and not as money. \nYou may consider your money status before the game and after the game, but \nwhile the game is in progress it is only  a game, and the chips are just units. \nYou\'re trying to win as many units as you can.  \nThis concept is not really unique to Poker, when you think about it. All good \nbusinessmen realize that they have to  have different standards of what \nconstitutes extravagance in business, and what constitutes extravagance in \ntheir lives outside of business. And the standard they set for business is often \nmore liberal. They realize that the house,  or the car they buy for their private \nuse has to be paid for out of profits, rather than out of operating capital.  \nSo when they need a new piece of equi pment to make a few more dollars of \nprofit, or just to maintain their comp etitive edge, Poker Professionals don\'t \nsay to themselves: "I could buy a new ho use with this money what am I doing \nrisking it in a Poker game?" They realiz e that it\'s operating capital, and not \nprofit, and therefore not really available to buy that new house or car, \nanyway.  \nAll I\'m telling you to do is apply the sa me sound principles to the business of \nplaying Poker and that reminds me of a story.  \nLOWBALL PETE \nand his  friend SHORTY  \nThis guy named Lowball Pete went over to his friend Shorty\'s house and Pete \nsaid to Shorty: "I\'ve got to have some money, the baby don\'t have any food, \nthe rent\'s due and they\'re going to throw me out of my house." So Shorty, who was a good friend of Pete\'s said  "well I understand, here\'s $100." Pete \nsaid "thanks Shorty, I\'ll pay you back as soon as I can." Shorty said: "well, I \nknow that. Where are you going now?" An d Pete said "I\'m going over to Al\'s \nhouse, they have a $200 limit Lowball game going right now." Shorty said:', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 14}),
 Document(page_content='"well what difference does that make, how are you going to play?" And Pete \nsaid "Oh...I\'ve got money for THAT."  \nThe factor that really determines what ki nd of game it\'s going to be is not the \nlimit itself, but the size of the ante in relation to the limit. If you\'re playing $10 \nlimit and anteing a dollar, you\'ll have to pl ay more liberally than if the ante is \nonly a quarter.  \nThis is very important information  because it\'s something you can ascertain \nbefore you ever sit down and risk any of your money.  \nThat information, and all the other pre game data you can collect (such as \nthe kind of players your opponents are) should be weighed against the \nfollowing consideration: How much do  you stand to win in this game?   \nSuppose the ante is so high, and the players are such that you\'ll have to \ninvolve $8,000 or $9,000 of your own money to win, but the players have only \nabout $30,000 among them on the table, and you know that they probably \nwon\'t bring any more money into the game if they lose that. It\'s pretty hard to \nget more than about half the money in a game, so $15,000 would be a big win.  \nTo go into that game you\'d be risking $8,000 or $9,000 to win a maximum of \n$15,000, even if you got the best hands of your life and played them jam up. That\'s probably too much risk for that  much money, since there\'s usually a \nbetter game down the street.  \nI can remember losing $98,000 in a game that didn\'t warrant losing $10,000. I \ncould have only won $30,000 or $40,000 ... an d to do that, I\'d have had to \nbreak everybody there.  \nSo this advice amounts to telling you to do  as I say, and not as I do. I believe a \nperson should try to learn from watc hing another man\'s mistakes. It\'s so \nmuch cheaper than learning from his own.  \nYou have to set a stricter limit on yo ur losses if you\'re playing Limit Poker \nthan if you\'re playing No Limit, becaus e it\'s harder to win money back in a \ngame where the size of the pot\'s limited.  \nIn a Limit game, if you find yourself losing consistently over a significant \nperiod of time and you feel that the cards have been breaking close to even \nthe game may be too tough for you. Walk away from it, and don\'t come back until something has changed to make you more of a favorite - like the absence \nof a few very good players who were th ere before, or the feeling that you \nhave improved your own play.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 15}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter One: \nCourage and Other Important \nQualities  \nCourage: The Heart of the Matter   \nI'm asking you to walk a very thin line between wisdom and courage, and \nkeep a tight rein on both. The line gets  thinner the more you excel at Poker.  \nThe reason it's so narrow a line is th at courage is one of the outstanding \ncharacteristics of a really top player. It's important because some people \ncompletely break down when they lose a big pot, and they play very badly \nafter that. Whereas other men play just that much harder.  \nIf I could give you a single player to  take as a shining example of true \ncourage, it would be Puggy Pearson. Puggy at his best is really, really good, \nbut he has suffered long losing streaks.  Yet even during such dismal streaks, \nhis play doesn't rise and fall with the way he's doing in a particular game. He \njust keeps trying. Nothing stops him.  \nOne of the elements in a player's cou rage is the realization that money you \nhave already bet is no longer yours re gardless of how much is involved. You \nno longer own any money you've already put in the pot. It belongs to the pot. \nYour decision must be based on the current  situation. If you feel that large bet \nis now necessary to win the pot, then th at's what you should  do. If you think \nthat there's no way for you to win the pot,  then you have to give it up even if \nyou've already committed a large amount of money. It's a cliché, but true \nanyway, don't throw good money after bad .  \nAnother element which demands courage and judgement is dealing with \nimplied odds . It's a concept you'll be dealing with  in other sections of this book. \nIt means you have to weigh your bet against not only the present size of the \npot, but the anticipated size of the pot when all psychological and \nmathematical factors are evaluated. It takes a lot of courage to risk your \nmoney against a profit you can't see. And it takes courage to move all in with \na bluff when you suspect an opponent is weak, They say courage is invisible, \nbut I never knew a top player who didn't have it written all over his face - \nclear as day.  \nThe important Twins of Poker - \nPATIENCE and STAYING POWER   \nCome to the table with enough time to  stay and play awhile. While sitting \ndown and trying to destroy a game by firing from the start is my favorite \nstrategy, it doesn't always work. There are games that demand staying power.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 16}),
 Document(page_content="Limit games take lots of patience be cause the best hands are usually shown \ndown that means it's hard er to bluff successfully. So you have to wait for the \nbest hand, and you have to recognize the best hand when you get it.  \nOr suppose you sit down at a game that includes two drunks who are calling \nevery bet. It will be impossible to simply take charge of that game, so you'll \nhave to wait until you get hands that will beat them.  \nOTHER IMPORTANT \nQUALITIES FOR SUCCESS:  \nAlertness   \nWhenever you're in a game...you have to stay alert the whole time concentrate \nduring the entire session. And it ca n be a very long time indeed.  \nThe ability to stay alert for long sessions can be a major factor contributing to \nyour earning power, and it has been a key to my own success. Once, when I \nwas in my middle twenties, I played fi ve days and five nights without any \nbreaks except to go to the bathroom or to eat meals which were brought in. I \nnever left the table for mo re than five minutes.  \nI wouldn't do it again, and I wouldn't recommend anyone else do it. I never \nagain had the stamina I did before that session. But it demonstrates how \nlong it's humanly possible to stay awake and alert when you have the \nresolve and the courage.   \nToday, at the age of 44, I suspect I could and would play three days in a game \nwhere I could make a great deal of mone y. But I don't like to play that long \nnow, not only because it's gruelling an d not particularly he althy, but because \nit's bad policy to play anything but the best you can. (And that's simply not \npossible much beyond the first day.)  \nI can play at my best for about 36 hours now, but after that the drop off \nbecomes noticeable to me, if not to my  opponents. The reason I have more \nstaying power than other players is just discipline.  \nDiscipline   \nI don't drink much, and neither do most good Poker players.  \nAnd, I NEVER drink when I play. No top player drinks while playing.   \nNor do we let our minds dwell on person al problems when we're playing.  \nYou should make a conscious and constant effort to discover any leaks  in your \nplay and...then eliminate them. If you discover you're playing too many \npots...tighten up. Other times you may need to play more pots.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 17}),
 Document(page_content='One form of discipline is to learn to play all Poker games, profitably...even \nthose you don\'t like. Keep yourself alert and conditioned by playing some of \nthe games you\'re not best at. Besides...it\' ll enable you to give the other guy a \nlittle action at his game if he wants it.  \nTry to keep a mental record of the kinds of games in which you do well, as \nopposed to those in which you don\'t. (I know, for example, that Limit Ace to \nFive is my worst game, because I\'ve won the least money at it.)  \nConstant self discipline will pay off in those long. drawn out sessions because \nany bad habits you have will become exaggerated as you grow tired. The \nfewer bad habits you have, the less ris ky it is to play longer sessions.  \nDiscipline will also help your general co nfidence after three or four losing \nsessions. If I lose a few times, I will re examine my game and ask, "Am I \nplaying bad?" Sometimes I\'ll ask somebo dy else\'s opinion as well. If the \nanswer is "No, you\'re not playing badly, you\'re just playing unlucky", I can \nbelieve the answer because I know I\'ve  done everything I could to keep my \ngame at its best. So my confidence is unshaken. I can continue to play the way \nI know I should.  \nMaintaining confidence is your strongest defense against "going bad". When \nyou start to go bad, or just start to think you\'re going bad, you become \nhesitant. And that oft quoted rule that your first instinct is the right one is \nmore true in Poker than in any othe r game. When you act hesitantly, you \noften go against your first (and best) judgement.  \nAllowing your confidence to be shaken can turn a simple losing streak into \na terrible case of going bad.   \nAt the same time, you still have to remain open to the idea that you may need \nto shape up your play. You know about how often you can expect to lose, just \non the basis of luck, and if you have a streak of many straight losses, you \nmust admit (to yourself) that something might be wrong. If so, try to correct \nit.  \nFor instance, if I lost five straight sessi ons at one of my better forms of Poker. \nI\'d suspect something basic was wrong. If  I lost ten straight, there would be \nno doubt whatever  that I was doing something wrong, and that luck was not \nthe main thing.  \nYou may also be fortunate enough to have the unforgettable experience of \ngoing good . But that\'s no more a matter of luck than going bad . There are \nreasons for it.  \nControlling Your Emotions', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 18}),
 Document(page_content="Romantic problems have the biggest effect s, of course. I have seen very good, \nsolid players (even by Professional stan dards) thrown into second childhood \nby their wives or girl friends. Emotional entanglements affect their \njudgement  at everything. And, at the Poker table, of course, it costs them \nmoney.  \nThey divert their interest to their love  affairs. They don't concentrate. They \nhave trouble sitting and they want to get up and walk around. Poker doesn't \nreally interest them.  \nI'm sure that any kind of  trauma involving my wife  or children would affect \nme much the same way. But, I wouldn't  be playing at such a time.  \nIt's hard to give anybody advice abou t this, but I believe that if something \nhappens that is so upsetting that it really affects your ability to play, you \nshould consider quitting entirely at least for a time, until you regain your \nemotional balance.  \nI've been fortunate enough not to go th rough any traumas of that sort, but it \nseems to me that taking a long break because of a big problem is a logical \nextension of the proven practice of taking a short break because of a little \nproblem. So, you'll be doing yourself a service, if you follow this rule:  \nNever play when you're upset  \nIt's not my disposition to get upset very easily, but I have saved a great deal \nof money over the years by quitting wh enever I have lost enough money to \nbother me, And that is an even more important principle in Limit Poker than \nin No Limit...because it takes you so mu ch longer to grind it out at Limit.  \nAbout once every three or four months  something will happen (like a fight at \nhome, or an argument with a friend) that will get me upset. On those days I \ngo see a movie or play golf. I'll pass a game up on those days, regardless of \nhow good it is, because I know I'll probably lose if I play.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 19}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter One: Vacations  \nActually SCHEDULE VACATIONS   \nAnd if you\'re playing Professionally, remember to take some vacations. \nYou\'ve got to give your mind a rest.  \nOnce, my friend Jack Straus had come by a game just to watch me play, and \nhe told me "Doyle, you\'re playing terrible."  \nI had been under the impression I was playing pretty well, but I hadn\'t been \nwinning as often as usual. Jack pointe d out to me that I had been playing \nalmost every day for a year.  \nSo I went to Hawaii for two weeks, and when I came back I not only played \nbetter, but dramatically better , than I had before leaving.  \nLooking back, it\'s worth noting that even though I do a lot more self \nexamining than most Poker players, I had failed to recognize how badly my \ngame was Off, and why it was off, until jack pointed it out to me.  \nBecause it\'s so difficult to recognize when  you\'re going stale, I think it\'s best to \ntake some vacations even when you think you don\'t need them. Schedule \nthem.  \nThere\'s such a great difference in the ma keup of people that I can\'t tell you \nhow often you should go. But it seems to me that it would be better to err on \nthe side of too many vacations than too few. They don\'t have to be lengthy. \nBut there should be three or four days in which you\'re having fun and not \nthinking about Poker at all. Hunt, fish , or just lie on the beach you\'ll be a \nbetter player afterward.  \nThe occasional break makes it easier to get a perspective on how you\'re doing, \nand what your abilities are. That\'s very important.  \nSure, you want to study the emotional makeup of your opponents. But of \nall the players at the Poker table, the one whose capabilities and limitations \nare going to affect you most, is the one sitting in your chair.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 20}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter One: \nBeing Versatile  \nBE VERSATILE   \nHaving recognized those capabilities and limitations, it's best to test them \noccasionally, not only to see if your assessments are still valid, but also to \nmaintain a reputation of being willing to give action.  \nI know very well that I play any kind of No Limit Poker better than almost \nany kind of Limit Poker. And I know that Hold 'em is my best game, and Ace to Five my worst.  \nBut that doesn't mean I won't play anyth ing but No Limit Hold 'em. I've seen \ntoo many players who won't play unle ss everything is in their favor won't \nplay unless the game is right, won't play  unless it's their game, and then won't \nbet unless they have the nuts.  \nI reject their philosophy for what I consider the best of reasons ... none of \nthose players has any real money . If you get a reputation for playing only \nwhen you have the best of it, you'll get very few people to play against you.  \nSo I end up playing a lot of games in which I'm not a big favorite, just to \nstimulate action, and keep Poker going.  \nEven if you lose money by doing that, at  least you have put it back into the \nPoker economy of which you are a part, wh ich isn't the case if you blow it in \nthe casino on Craps or spend it on a trip to Europe or anything else.  \nBy playing the other man's game, you ma y get him to agree to play yours in \nreturn . By participating in the game of the day, you make it hard for others to \nshut you out with a game you don't pl ay. (If you're an all around player, you \ndo play his game.) Once they've decide d that you'll play whatever the game \nis, most players will go back to lobbying for the game at which they think \nthey're the best. That may well be your own strongest game.  \nBy playing games like High Low Split, Razz, Seven Card Stud, and Draw \nPoker, I may get a weaker player to face me, because I don't have a great \nreputation at those games.  \nFinally, by playing those games I mainta in a reputation as a man who will bet \non something at which he has no real  advantage. A reputation for giving \naction.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 21}),
 Document(page_content="Don't worry that you might get a reputa tion for being a Sucker if you follow \nthis advice. That's the best thing that could possibly happen to you. (To have \nthe reputation of being a Sucker, with everybody in the world throwing their \nmoney at me trying to win mine, would be my idea of earthly paradise!)  \nYOUR REPUTATION can be a two edged sword  \nThe opposite kind of reputation is, of course, a two edged sword. It cuts both \nways. After winning the World Hold 'em Championship two years in a row, it \nis understandably hard for me to ge t a lot of high Hold 'em action  \nIdeally, you want a reputation (particularly in Hold 'em) that will make other \nplayers just a little afraid of you. Not so afraid they won't play... but afraid \nenough to respect you.  \nThere isn't really any good way of estab lishing your credentials as a top Poker \nplayer except to get to the top and stay there.  \nPlaying head up against another good pl ayer, for instance, is not a realistic \ntest of who's the best player because it happens that some people who are \nvery good at head up play are not very good in a Ring game ... and vice versa.  \nThe perfect test would probably be to ha ve the same line up (set of players), \nplaying against each other five nights  a week for a year. There would be no \nextraneous factors (like the introducti on of new players), and almost no \namount of luck could keep the best pl ayer from winning the most money over \na period of a year (providing there was a real difference in the quality of play \nbetween the best and the second best player).", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 22}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter One: \nTournament Play  \nTOURNAMENTS: \nMore benefits than meets the ey e - and how to adjust to them   \nBut in the absence of games like that, about the only way for a man to \nestablish a reputation quickly is to en ter and win (or perform well in) a Poker \ntournament.  \nBut, that's not the only motivation for entering a tournament. By the time I \nwon the World Hold 'em Championship, the title of champion didn't mean \nmuch to me. There are only a very f ew people who are good enough players \nthemselves that I value their opinion th at I'm a good one. Since all of these \nmen are also Professionals, they know who is the best player without having \nto hold a tournament to decide it.  \nBelieve me, the main motivation was the $220,000 it paid me in 1976, the first \nyear I won, and the $340,000 in 1977 th e second year. (I also won $90,000 in \nthe Deuce-to-Seven  World Championship in 1976 and in 1977 I won $55,000 in \nthe High Low Split  World Championship.)  \nBut, you don't have to win the tournament to profit by it ... even a winner take \nall tournament. The tournament itself will generate other games which can \nmake the buy in price of the tournament even the $10,000 buy in Hold 'em \nChampionship a bargain for a good player.  \nAfter people start getting eliminated  from the Hold 'em Championship, \nthere's a solid week of the best Poker action to be found anywhere. Everybody \nis still in a mood to gamble, and most of them have the money to do it.  \nNot only do you get a chance at that money by being at the tournament, but \nyou get to know these people, and because they're from all over the country, \nyou develop contacts that can get you a game almost anywhere.  \nThe contacts and side games at the World Series of Poker*  are so valuable that a \nlot of players who could afford to enter don't bother to. They show up for the \nside games and contacts alone.  \nI think that's often a mistake. Playing in the tournament itself helps you \nestablish a reputation as an action man who's willing to risk a significant \namount of money in a game, even if  he doesn't have any substantial \nadvantage. And action is the most im portant aspect of the reputation a \nProfessional Poker player has to maintain.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 23}),
 Document(page_content="Furthermore, the people who actually play in the tournaments are the ones \nwho get the chances at the best action  surrounding the tournaments. If you \nforce another player out of a pot in  a tournament, and break him because \nyou're both playing on artificially limit ed bankrolls, he may get a little sore \nabout it and invite you to try him in a regular game. There's nothing like \nplaying somebody who is mad at you to increase your earnings for the year.  \n*The World Series of Poker Is a regist ered trademark of the HORSESHOE HOTEL \nCASINO In Las Vegas, Nevada.   \nThis brings up one of the most signif icant points about tournaments -- the \nstrategy of tournament play differs from the strategy of ordinary play.   \nIt took me longer than it should have to learn this. I played in the Hold 'em \nTournament for seven years before I won it. Of course, I wanted to win the \nmoney, but another way I'd justify en tering the tournament year after year \nand it was a legitimate justification rather than a rationalization was on my \ngeneral principle of investing money just to promote gambling, and to keep a \nreputation for being an action man.  \nSince I felt the need to be there anyw ay, I kept pondering how to win. And I \nnoticed that Johnny Moss always seemed to do very well in the tournaments. \nI've always been an apostle of John's at  No Limit. I used to observe and watch \nhim in each Poker game I went to, and it seemed he was always there. Slim, \nSailor and I used to joke about how c razy we were, wearing our automobiles \nout chasing John all across Texas. The truth was, John was usually the big \nwinner in the games ... with myself a close second. As the years passed, the \nmargin between us got closer and clos er because I was watching and picking \nup his favorite plays as any young apprentice might watch and learn from the \nmaster in his field. Much of my No Limit strategy comes from those times.  \nI have much more respect for Johnny than  a lot of younger players do. In his \nprime, he was the best No Limit player I've ever seen, and a lot of people \ndon't believe that because they're too young to have seen Johnny play at his \nbest. They fail to take into account the fact that he's some 70 years old now, \nand that is 20 years past the point at  which most men's play begins to \ndeteriorate. just because the years ha ve affected your circulation and the \nspeed at which you think, and may have softened your ability to play, does \nnot mean you know any less about how to play. And Johnny's success in \nthose tournaments indicated he knew a great deal about how to play. (He's \nthe only man besides myself who has won the World Series more than once.)  \nSo I studied Johnny's strategy and saw that he didn't  try to win early in the \ntournament. He just tried to exist, and to keep from losing his money. Now, \nas you may remember from the earlier part  of this section, this is exactly the \nopposite of my normal strategy in ordinary games. And I had been trying to", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 24}),
 Document(page_content="win the tournament the same way I have always won at ordinary games. That \nwas wrong for tournaments .  \nI had been jeopardizing my chips on even money situations, which can be a \nvery good strategy in the early stage of an ordinary  Poker game, but is not \ngood in a tournament , where you can't pull another few thousand out of your \npocket and buy more chips.  \nIn my new strategy, I tried to avoid pl aying big pots until the field had been \nnarrowed substantially. Then later, after the field had been cut to a few \nplayers, I played more aggressively, and tried to get players to jeopardize all \ntheir checks at every opportunity.  \nUsing this strategy designed specifically  for tournaments, I've won the World \nChampionship the last two years in a row.  \nIt should go without saying that yo u should mentally train for a Poker \ntournament, but there, I said it anyw ay because it's so important. You \nwouldn't go into a Basketball or Golf tournament without working on your \ngame first and you should give the same consideration to a Poker \ntournament. You sit down alone, yo u concentrate, and when the first \ntournament hand is dealt ... you're playing for keeps.  \nOne of the things I like about the World Series of Poker  is that it brings out the \nfinest in a lot of players. There's a fr iend of mine who doesn't play any good \nHold 'em the rest of the year, but always plays pretty well in the World Series .  \nIt's been an expensive lesson to him each year, but I keep hoping that the \ntournament will make him realize he could be playing tough the whole year \nround.  \nTournaments are not always won by the be st player. You have to be good to \nwin, but you can be the very best  and not win in a tournament.  \nEvery year at the World Series  we have half a dozen or so who always make it \nto the last couple of tables, but have never  won and never  will win. Some are \nvery solid players in ordinary situatio ns, but just not quite good enough to \nwin in a game against four or five of the best. And some are as solid as they \ncome, but just don't have the killer instinct they fade at the finish.  \nWhen you're in a tournament, and it becomes obvious to you that you're \nprobably going to lose, I think it's be st to die with a bang, rather than a \nwhimper. Go out playing with courage, instead of playing tight and meekly.  \nFor one thing, it gives you the better of  those two famous chances - slim and \nnone to stay alive long enough to win. If you play conservatively on a low \nbankroll, the antes, which increase as the tournament goes on, will eat you up.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 25}),
 Document(page_content='If you do get eliminated early, you can get into those very rich side games I \nmentioned earlier.  \nBE COMPETITIVE with Class   \nWhen you do get into those side games,  I hope you\'ll remember not to kill the \ngoose that laid the golden egg. A lot of people who come to tournaments \ndon\'t really have much chance of going home winner. They\'re people who \nlike to play high, largely for the enjo yment, and are willing to pay for the \npleasure.  \nA few years ago there was such  a man who played in the World Series . He \nwasn\'t a good player, but he could a fford to lose, and besides that, we all \nliked him.  \nBut one of the World Class players (a big name player) got that man into a \nside game and made some kind of Sucker  play at him, and the fellow went for \nit. So instead of just taking his winnings gracefully, our "big name" player (no \nname in this book) showed everybody at the rail what he had done. Then to \nmake matters worse, one of our local bookmakers made this poor fellow a 100 \nto 1 shot not to win the tournament. (Nobody likes to be a 100 to 1 dog.)  \nThe guy left, and he hasn\'t been back. Each of the Professionals had invested \n$10,000 every year for several years, knowing he probably would not win it, \nbut did it anyway to stimulate action . And then these two guys (the "big \nname" and the bookmaker) drove off on e of the biggest action men we had \never attracted just for the sake of a few cruel laughs.  \nThat\'s not only bad manners ... it\'s bad business. It\'s not only conduct \nunbecoming a gentleman, but especially  conduct unbecoming a Professional \nPoker player. I don\'t care if you\'re play ing $1 ante or $10,000 buy in don\'t ever \nbe guilty of it.  \nBe highly competitive ... but do it with class.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 26}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter Two: \nHOLD \'EM Limit and No Limit Similarities and Differences  \nIf you\'ve never played Hold \'em, you\'re about to learn about the most \nfascinating of all the various forms of Poker. If you have played it, then you \nknow what I\'m talking about.  \nHold \'em has more variety to it than  any other form of Poker. And more \ncomplexity. It has something for everybody ... the mathematicians and \npsychologists ... the "loose gooses" and the "hard rocks".  \nAbove all, it has action ... more multi way action than any other game. Almost \nevery pot you get involved in will be tremendously exciting. The thrills and \nfrustrations are never ending. Once you play Hold \'em ... you may never want \nto play any other form of Poker again. It could become your main game. It\'s \nconverted a lot of other players.  \nBut, of course, it\'s Poker...so it\'s simil ar in many respects to other Poker games \nespecially Seven Card Stud. However, there are enough differences in the \nstrategy you use and the mathematics you apply to Hold \'em - to make it a \ntruly unique game. The mere fact that it can be played with as many as 23 \nplayers is an oddity that alone distingu ishes it from any other form of Poker. \n(However, Hold \'em is rarely played wi th more than 11 players in the Limit \nversion and No Limit Hold \'em is most often played with nine players.)  \nBecause Hold \'em may be unfamiliar to you, it\'s the only game where I\'m \ngoing to discuss its simple mechanics. In both Limit and No Limit, the game is \nalways played with a Blind. The first pl ayer to receive cards is said to be in the \nBlind  and must make a forced bet to start the action. It\'s also a live Blind which \nmeans the player in the Blind  has the option of raising  when the action gets \nback to him or he can simply "call" (without putting anymore money in the \npot) if his Blind bet is not raised. In Limit Hold \'em there is usually a single \nBlind and each player (including the B lind) must ante. No Limit Hold \'em is \nalso played that way. Additionally, th e No Limit version is commonly played \nwith multiple Blinds and no ante.  \nIn a casino, the game is dealt by a House dealer and a Button (an object that \nphysically resembles a small Hockey puck) is placed in front of the last player \nto receive cards. The player with the Bu tton is considered to be the dealer and \nthe first player to his left is considered  to be the (first) Blind. A private game \nmay or may not have a paid dealer. If it doesn\'t, each player takes turns \ndealing. In the casino, the Button is mo ved from player to player after each \npot.  \nThe game starts with each player receiv ing two hole cards the only ones he \npersonally receives. Then, there is the fi rst round of betting. Quite often in No \nLimit play that bet is also the last round of betting because someone makes a', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 27}),
 Document(page_content='huge bet (or moves in with all the money he has in front of him) and no one \ncalls him. That\'s not an uncommon play. I do it often when I think I can pick \nup the antes and when I feel someone has made a weak bet.  \nA pot in Limit Hold \'em seldom ends so quickly. There\'s a second round of \nbetting after the \'dealer burns  (removes from play) the top card,* deals off \nthree cards face down and Flops  them over in the center of the table. ( Turn  and \nFall are often used synonyms for "Flop".) Those three cards are community \ncards. All the players still in the pot ca n use them with their hole cards to \nmake up a hand. In both Limit and No Li mit play, the Flop is the most critical \npoint in the hand. It\'s here you\'ll make the major decision as to whether or not \nyou want to continue to play.  \n*The top card Is always "burned" because It might be marked ... and any \nplayer who know how It was marked would have a tremendous advantage.   \nThere\'s another round of betting after the dealer burns one and turns one . This \nis Fourth Street  (the fourth community card). The last round of betting occurs \non Fifth Street  (after the dealer burns an d turns again). That\'s when all the cards \nare out . The pot is won by the player with the best five card hand made up \nwith both (or one) of his hole cards combined with three (or four) of the \ncommunity cards. Occasionally, a pot is split by two players with identical \nhands (usually Straights) and in rare instances the Board  (all five community \ncards) is the best hand. In the latter  case, the pot is divided among all the \nplayers who have called all the bets on the end.  \nThat\'s all there is to the mechanics of Ho ld \'em ... but it\'s hardly all there is to \nacquiring a mastery of the game so yo u can win at it consistently. What\'s \nmore ... there\'s a vast difference in th e strategies you\'ll use in the Limit and \nNo Limit versions of the game.  \nIn Limit play, you must play solid hand s because it\'s almost impossible to run \nanybody out of a pot. But, in No Limi t play, you can make your opponent(s) \nlay down a hand by using your position and your money.  \nYou must also have a certain aptitude to be a strong No Limit player. In a \nword, what you must have is "Heart". Not everyone has that. Of course, you \nmust have respect for your money and kn ow its value ... but if you want to be \na strong No Limit player you can\'t th ink you\'re betting a Lincoln Continental \neverytime you bet ten or fifteen thousand dollars. If you do think that \nway...you\'ll never make it playing No Limit.  \nThere are also Limit players who can\'t rise above a certain class. I know of \nmany such players who are super strong  players when they play $30 and $60 \nor $60 and $125 Limit ... but, when they tr y to move up and play in a much \nhigher limit game say $200 and $400 or $400 and $800 they just can\'t cut it. \nI\'ve seen it over and over and over. They try to move up and play in a higher', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 28}),
 Document(page_content='game than they\'re used to and they get busted out. Of course, that\'s not true \nof all players. Some make the big move...and do it successfully. But most \ndon\'t. So you should always bear that in mind when you try to step up in \nclass. Don\'t be in too big a hurry. An d if you\'ve got what it takes ... you\'ll \nmake it. A lot of what you\'ll need is right here on these pages.  \nI won\'t get into all the sp ecific differences in strategy you\'ll use at Limit and \nNo Limit Hold \'em until the two versions are discussed individually in the \npages that follow. For now, I\'ll just cont inue to discuss some of them and also \nthe things that make Hold \'em the unique game that it is.  \nEvery Poker player has heard that drawin g to an inside Straight is usually a \nSucker play. That\'s generally true at most forms of Poker. But, in Hold \'em (especially No Limit) ... drawing to an  inside Straight can be a sound and \njustifiable play. It all depends on the si tuation. If you can draw to that belly \nStraight cheap and there\'s the possibility you can win a real big pot by \nbreaking your opponent if you make it ... then you should gamble and take \nthat 5 to 1 shot.* The reward makes the risk worthwhile. I make plays like that \nall the time (as you\'ll soon learn).  \nThere are also times when you\'ll play  hands that would be completely \nunplayable if the ordinary standards you applied to other forms of Poker \nwere applied to Hold \'em. But Hold \'em is a game in a class by itself. More so \nthan in any other game and especially so in No Limit any two cards in Hold \n\'em can get the money.  \nI\'m not saying you can indiscriminately play any two cards you\'re dealt. \nThat\'s not the case at all. As in the other forms of Poker I\'ve discussed, I\'m \ngoing to give you standards to guide your  play. What I am saying is in Hold \n\'em there are more exceptions to the rules than in a more "mechanical" game \nsuch as High Low Split. So much in Hold \'em depends on the Flop. And on \nyour position.  \nIn No Limit Hold \'em, position is ... well, it\'s the name of the game. It\'s \neverything. If I had position all night, I could beat the game ... and I\'d never \nhave to look at my hole cards. In Limit play position\'s not nearly so important.   \nNo Limit play is also far more comp lex than Limit because you can do so \nmany more things. You can make a few cute little moves in Limit play...but, \nas I said earlier, for the most part you just have to play a solid game. You can\'t \nget too fancy at any form of Limit Poker. When your opponent knows the \nmost it can cost him is another bet he won\'t be as hesitant to call as he would \nbe in No Limit when you move in on him.  In the latter case, he\'ll usually be in \na quandry. He won\'t know whether you\'re bluffing ... or whether you have \nthe nuts.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 29}),
 Document(page_content="*Drawing to an Inside Straight is about 5 to 1 against you with two cards to come. \nAnd it's about 10 to 1 with one card to come.   \nThat's another thing that distinguishes Hold 'em from other games (except for \nthe now nearly dead game of Five Card Stud). It's very easy to see when you \nhave the nuts (or very close to it). It's not so easy to know when you have the \nnuts at other forms of Poker. You can use that fact to great advantage in Hold \n'em because you can represent  (bluff) when you don't have the nuts and when \nyou're quite certain your opponent does n't have them either. I'll show you \nhow to do that. It's something else I do all the time.  \nAnother interesting aspect of Hold 'em is that you can turn the nuts and be \nthe dog to win the pot. Here's how that could come about:  \n \nIn the above example, you flopped a Straight which is the nut hand right \nthere but, you're not the favorite to win the pot. Your opponent is. He has a \nchance to make a bigger Straight and he also has a Flush draw. He has 14 \nwins 3 Fives, 4 Tens and 7 Clubs (other than the Five and Ten of Clubs). With \ntwo cards to come, there's a 53% chance that he'll catch one of those 14 cards. \nThat makes him a 53 to 47 (or a 6%) favorite.  \nThere's also a case in Hold 'em where you could be in a lot worse shape than \nthat after you flop the nuts. This intere sting situation could occur as follows:", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 30}),
 Document(page_content='You flopped the nuts ... but so did your opponent. More than that ... he\'s got a \ncold freerolling Flush draw. You\'re in a ne ar desperate situation. The best you \ncould hope to do is split the pot. The worst is that you\'re going to lose more \nthan 1/3 of the time. There are nine Diamonds he can catch to make his Flush \n... and with two cards to come, he\'s goin g to get there about 36% of the time. \nYou turned the nuts ... but you\'re up against the pure nuts.  \nWhenever you have small connecting c ards that are suited, the ideal Flop \nwould be three cards that made your Strai ght two of which are in your suit to \ngive you a Flush draw also. And if yo u were to run into someone else around \nthe table who flopped the same Straight you did (and no Flush draw) ... well, \nthat\'s a No Limit player\'s dream. Some of the biggest pots I\'ve ever seen in \nHold \'em came about just that way. Both players had a cinch ... but one of \nthem was freerolling for a Flush.  \nSituations like the two just noted coul d occur but with less frequency in Seven \nStud. For example, you could have a small Straight made and your opponent \ncould be drawing at a bigger Straight op en on both ends with a Flush draw, \ntoo. Then he\'d be the favorite. Or, both  of you could have an identical Straight \nmade and your opponent could also have  a Flush draw.* But these situations \nare far more common in Hold \'em because of the community cards.  \n*There\'s a difference between the "iden tical Straight" situation in Hold \'em \nand Seven Stud. In Hold \'em, when two players have Identical Straights made, but one of them has, in addition, a Flush draw ... the Flush draw is a \npure freeroll due to the community cards (since both Straights improve the \nsame way). In Seven Stud, the Flush dr aw may not be a freeroll because the \nother player\'s Straight could get hi gher (if It\'s not already Ace high).   \nYou\'ll be learning many more peculiar an d interesting things about this game. \nFor example, when you have a Pair of Aces and a single Ace flops (giving you \na Set of Trips)...there\'ll always  be the possibility that the next card off could \nmake someone a Straight. (I\'ll discuss this in greater detail later when I tell \nyou how I play two Aces when I flop a Set.)  \nIn fact, Straight and Flush draws seem to be ever present in Hold \'em. It\'s one \nof the things that makes the game so ac tion filled and so interesting. Most \nplayers indiscriminately pursue their Straight and Flush draws when it\'s \nclearly not justified by the pot odds in Limit play or the potential amount of \nmoney they can win at No Limit. I\'ll discuss this more thoroughly when we \nget into the individual sections.  \nYou\'ll also discover that overcards (on th e Board that are higher than a Pair \nyou have) and kickers play a more dominant role in Hold \'em than other \nforms of Poker. Quite often, You\'ll find that your hand will become \nunplayable when an overcard falls or  when you suspect you\'ve got "kicker-\ntrouble", But again, I\'ll get into all of this shortly.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 31}),
 Document(page_content='Most players think of Hold \'em as a draw out game because someone always \nseems to be making a Straight or Flush ... or "spiking" a card on Fourth or \nFifth that pairs their kicker. But, in rea lity Hold \'em is much less of a draw out \ngame than it appears to be. That\'s an  important point for you to remember.  \nIn Hold \'em, whenever you have a hand against a hand (as opposed to a \nhand against a draw) ... the draw ou t possibilities are severely limited \nbecause of the community cards.   \nFor example, when you\'ve got A K and your opponent\'s got A Q ... you\'ve got \nhim to the point where he can catch only  one (type of) card (a Queen) to win \nthe pot (assuming he doesn\'t have the possibility of making a Straight or \nFlush after the Flop). In a game like Seven Card Stud, you almost never have \nan opponent waiting to catch just one card. When there aren\'t community \ncards, your opponent usually has a variety of cards he can catch to win the \npot.  \nIn No Limit (and occasionally in Limit) , the reason you see so many big pots \nwon on a draw out is because it\'s a big hand against a big draw. You\'ll rarely \nsee a big pot played when it\'s a Pair ve rsus a Pair. Unless you have a Pair of \nAces or Kings (and sometimes Queens) ... you simply must not play your Pair \ntoo strongly. If you do and you\'re up ag ainst a bigger Pair - you\'re going to be \na big underdog. What\'s more, when you have a Pair and your opponent has \ntwo overcards, you\'re a slight favorite.*  \nIn light of this (see footnote), you sh ould never re raise with two Queens or \ntwo Jacks (all the way down to a Pair of  Deuces) before the flop expecting to \nget all your money in the pot in No Limi t. You don\'t want to ... because if you \nget played with - you\'re either a big dog or a small favorite.  \nUnsophisticated players tend to play Pairs (especially Queens) much more \nstrongly than they should. Another time  they give far too much value to a \nhand is when they flop the bottom Two Pair. An example is when they play \nsmall connecting cards such as a 8 7 ** and the Flop comes K 8 7. Well, if \nthey\'re up against an A K ... they\'re in a very dangerous situation. I know.  \nI\'ve gotten broke more times playing the bottom  Two Pair than with any \nother hand playing Hold \'em.   \nIn that situation, the man with the A K can win with another King or with an \nAce ... and he can cripple your hand with a running Pair  on Fourth and Fifth. \nIf the Board doubles off with even a Deuce Deuce on the last two cards ... \nyou\'re gone. He\'s made Kings and Deuces  ... and your hand was not helped at \nall. So you must proceed with caution  when you flop the bottom  Two Pair.  \n*For example, a Pair of Kings against a Pair  of Aces is more than a 4 1/2 to 1 \ndog. And a Pair of Queens versus Ace King is only about a 6 to 5 favorite.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 32}),
 Document(page_content="**To be consistent throughout the di scussion on Hold 'em, all two card \nhands will be stated with the higher card first.   \nYou should also go slow when you turn the top and bottom  Pair. It's only \nwhen you turn the top Two Pair that your opponent's chances are \nconsiderably reduced of drawing out and breaking you. But, the danger in \nthis (and other such situations) is far greater in No Limit than Limit because \nyour entire table stake could be in jeop ardy. In Limit, your only danger is a \nfew extra bets.  \nAnother reason you'll have to be extremely careful with the small connecting \ncards is because, if you follow my advice, you'll be playing them often. \nThey're my favorite playing hands at No Limit Hold 'em.  \nAn interesting point about those particular hands such as a 6 5, 8 7, 9 8, 10 9 \nwhich I play about the same way is that  the J 10 is the best of the connecting \ncards. It's better than the others because it's the only two cards in the deck \nthat'll make four Straights and they'll all be the nuts. It can make a nut \nStraight with a 9 8 7, Q 9 8, K Q 9 and A K Q. A jack Ten can't  make a bad \nStraight - they're all the best hand.  \nAll the connecting cards from a 10 9 down to 5 4 will make four Straights ... \nbut only three  of them will be the nuts one of the Straights will be the little \nend. If an 8 7 6 falls, a 5 4 can be beaten by a 9 5 or a 10 9 ... and, if a K Q J falls, \na 10 9 can be beaten by an A 10.  \nAlso, when the cards are one card apart  as with a 7 5 ... you can only make \nthree Straights and only two  of those will be the nuts.* (You can have the nuts \nwith a 6 4 3 or an 8 6 4 ... but you won't  have the nuts with a 9 8 6.) Similarly, \nwhen you've got a hand that's two cards apart ... you can only make two \nStraights with just one  being the nuts** (With an 8 5, you can make a Straight \nwith a 7 6 4 and a 9 7 6 ... but only the former  will give you the nuts.) As you \ncan see, when the cards in your hand are separated, it not only reduces the \nnumber of Straights you can make ... but it also means that you'll be able to \nmake fewer nut hands with them. This consideration is the reason why a 7 2 \noffsuit is the worst Hold 'em hand ther e is. It's the one hand that has the \nsmallest probability of success.  \n*An exception here is Q 10 which will make three nut Straights.  \n**An exception here Is K 10 which will make two nut Straights.   \nAnother very interesting point is that even though a J 10 can make four nut \nStraights ... it's not a hand you'd prefer over, let's say, a 9 8. The latter hand is \npreferred because you can make more money  with it. Here's why:", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 33}),
 Document(page_content='If the Board comes A 8 8, you\'ll have a pretty good hand (with a 9 8) ... and \nyou can feel reasonably confident (espec ially in a raised pot) somebody else \ndidn\'t  turn three Eights. If they did, they probably have an 8 7, a 9 8 (like you \nhave) or possibly a 10 8. I mean they\'re not likely to be in there with a Q 8 or K \n8. (There are people who play those hand s, but if you\'re in there with a good \nplayer he\'s not likely to have such a hand.)  \nNow, if you have a J 10 in a raised pot,  and the Board comes J J 4 ... well, you \ncould very well have "kicker trouble". There\'s a lot of players that\'ll play an A \nJ, K J or Q J in a raised pot. Or, if the Board comes 10 10 4 ... you could have a \nsimilar problem since you could be up against an A 10, K 10 or Q 10.  \nThere\'s other interesting points to be noted about the small connecting cards \nthat might go unnoticed. Let\'s say you play  the 7c 6c and the Flop is 6s 6d 2h. \nIf an off card falls on Fourth St. and you continue to play your hand pretty \nstrong (in No Limit) and someone\'s still in there with you ... it\'s likely you\'re \nin there with another Six. Now, you have  to decide what your kicker\'s worth. \nIt\'s bad - only Seven high. So you migh t think you\'ve got "kicker trouble". But, \ndo you? If he\'s a good player, what\'s hi s kicker likely to be? If it was a raised \npot coming in ... you could put him on one of three probable hands a 7 6 (like \nyou have), a 6 5 or an A 6. It\'s not lik ely to be anything else. Because of the \nraise before the Flop, he probably didn\'t  play a 10 6, J 6, Q 6 or any of those \ntrash hands even if they were suited . So your Seven kicker is not so bad after \nall. Most people would think that if yo u\'re in there against another Six, there\'s \njust no chance your Seven could be a good kicker. But it could. It\'s a lot closer \nthan it looks.  \nThere are times you can even know more  than the fact that your kicker\'s \nprobably not as bad as another player mi ght think it is. Quite often, when you \nknow you\'re up against a good, sound player in the situation described above \n... you can do more than merely put him on the other Six. You can name both \nhis cards because you can know what suit he\'s got . He\'s either got the Ah 6h, \n7h 6h or the 6h 5h.
