So if there\'s a back door  Flush possibility (a Flush made \nwith two running  Hearts on Fourth and Fifth), then you could get a read on \nhim there, too.  \nYou can\'t always analyze the possible hands your opponent might have and \nread the situation that well. If you kn ow a player\'s style and the hands he\'s \nlikely to play ... you can usually come pretty close. But, if you\'re up against a \nweak player or somebody who\'s just speeding around  (playing real loose and \nwith no definable pattern) ... then you can\'t say such a player couldn\'t have, \nlet\'s say, a Qs 6s. He could have. As I\'ve so often said ... a big part of winning \nplay is knowing your player. You\'ve ju st got to know people ... and watch \n(carefully) how they play.  \nA good example of knowing your player can be illustrated by a pot I played \nwith Gary Bones  Berland (the man who came in second to me in the World', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 34}),
 Document(page_content='Championship Hold \'em event in the 1977 World Series of Poker ). Bones said \nthat that pot was the turning point in the whole tournament for him. It \nprobably was. I know it was a key pot for me because it gave me a lot of chips \nto operate with. Here\'s what happened:  \n \nBefore the Flop, Bones and I got about $6,000 each in the pot. On the Flop, he \nwas first to act and bet $7,000. I just called. The reason I didn\'t raise was \nbecause I thought he had just exactly what  he did have. I didn\'t want to take \nhim out of the lead since I knew he was going to make a big bet on the next \ncard.  \nThe big tip off (as to what his hand might be) was his raise before the Flop . \nHe was in the first seat (after the Blind) and made it $6,000 to go. He never \nraised  in the first seat with two Aces or  two Kings in the whole Tournament \n... or any other time I saw him play. If he \'d have had two Kings or two Aces ... \nhe\'d have called it and sent it around hoping somebody would raise behind \nhim so he could make a big move before the Flop. Of course, he could\'ve had \nthree Jacks in that spot, but I didn\'t th ink he did. I put him on Ace jack or \nKing Jack.  \nWhen he bet $18,500 on the Turn (Fourth St.) - that big a bet I was close to \ncertain about his hand. As I said, when he made his first bet, I thought there \nwas a small possibility he might have thr ee Jacks. But all my doubts about his \nhand were removed when he bet the ei ghteen-five. Then I knew what he had \n... and knew he was trying to shut me out of the pot right there. So I called the \n$18,500 and moved in with the rest of the money I had ($13,800). He called my \nraise even though he was pretty sure I had him beat at that point. It was a \npretty big pot almost $78,000 before Bones ca lled the last bet. I could\'ve been \nbluffing. I\'ve been known to do that on occasion. Bones\' call swelled the pot to \nover $90,000 ... which put me in a commanding position for the rest of the \nTournament.  \nThat pot illustrates another thing about my play that\'s misunderstood by a lot \nof people. I\'ve heard that I was "luc ky" in that pot because Bones had the \nhand he did. But, as I\'ve explained, it  wasn\'t luck at all. I knew his play. As', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 35}),
 Document(page_content='you\'ll later learn, I\'ve got something of a reputation for being a "lucky" player. \nOf course, it\'s unfounded. It\'s rather difficult to win m illions of dollars \nplaying Poker and be on a "winning st reak" for nearly 25 consecutive years. \nTo do that ... you need a lot more than luck.  \nAs you can see from the discussion of the pot I played with Bones, there\'s \nboth art and science to putting a player  on a particular hand. It\'s not always \neasy to do. It requires experience, clos e observation of your opponents, and a \nkeen analysis of their style of play. I hope  I\'ll be able to teach you how to do it \nwith a reasonable degree of accuracy.  \nBut there\'s another aspect to Hold \'em that doesn\'t require any special \nqualities ... and yet it gives a lot of players a lot of trouble. It\'s the simple matter of reading the Board and being able to relate it to your hand. Correctly.  \nYou\'ll remember that the winning Hold \'em hand (when all the cards are out) \nis the best five card hand made up with both (or just one) of your hole cards \nand three (or four) of the community cards on the Board. So it\'s really a very \nsimple matter to figure out what your best hand is. But, occasionally, it gets a little confusing and even very experienced players will make some horrible \nmistakes. I\'ll tell you about one such mistake shortly. But, for now, let\'s see if \nyou can figure out who\'ll win the pot in this situation:  \n \nThink about it. Who wins? To an experi enced player it looks like a simple \nquestion. But most beginners will ans wer it incorrectly. In any case, you\'ll \nfind the correct answer in a footnote at the end of this chapter.  \nThe problem posed here may seem very simple and it is but I\'ve seen players \noverlook their hands completely... and for a lot of money. I saw a very big pot \nplayed where the Board was K K 4 4 7 and one guy bet eighteen thousand on \nthe end. The other guy called with two Deuces in the pocket  (hole). He called \nthat $18,000  bet with absolutely the worst possible hand. He couldn\'t even \nbeat the Board! (Remember: yo u play the best five out of seven cards the best \ncombination of the two cards in your ha nd and the five cards on the Board.)', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 36}),
 Document(page_content='That was an oversight of enormous prop ortions. It\'s unforgivable. But, Hold \n\'em is a remarkable game. As I noted earlier, you can turn the nuts in Hold \n\'em and have the worst hand. There are so many interesting things that can \nhappen in Hold \'em ...some that border on the miraculous.  \nThe situations in Hold \'em that appear to  be miracles are when a player has to \ncatch perfect  in order to win ... and he does. A perfect catch  is the biggest draw \nout in the game. It\'s when a player is "d ead" to only two card s in the deck - no \nother cards will win it for him and he catches both of them to pull off the \n"miracle". I\'ve seen such "miracles" on several occasions. They\'re hard to \nbelieve when you see them. Especially wh en you\'re on the losing end of them. \nI know. It happened to me in what was probably the biggest Poker game the \nworld has ever seen.  \nThe game was at the Aladdin  (in Las Vegas) a few years ago and it went \nround the clock for about three consecutive months. There was over a million \ndollars on the table at all times. It wa s quite a game. And this particular pot I \nremember very well. I lost over twenty thousand in it.  \nI had two Kings in the pocket and the gu y in the pot with me had two Sevens. \nThe flop came K 2 2. He moved in on me. I called him. I flopped a Full ... but I \ndidn\'t win it. He caught 7 7 on Fourth and Fifth. That was the only way in the \nworld that he could win.. an d that\'s what he did.*  \n*it\'s almost 1000 to 1 against catching two perfect cards (989 to 1 to be exact).   \nI saw a similar situation in that same ga me. (In three months of 24 hour play a \nlot of things can happen ... and they usually do.) Here\'s what happened in this one:  \n \nPlayer A flopped the nuts ... and what looks like an unbeatable hand. But, \nPlayer B beat it by catching perfect on the last two cards.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 37}),
 Document(page_content='Other very "strange" things can happen in Hold \'em. One time, about eight \nyears ago in Reno, I won a $27,000 pot with a Six high. Here\'s how that \nhappened:  \n \nI bet on the Flop and he raised me. I moved in on him which, as you\'ll \ndiscover, is usually my style of play at No  Limit once I take a position (bet) in \na pot. Well, he called me. After the la st two cards were dealt, he had Kings \nand Treys with a Five high. I had the same hand Six high .  \nIf you play Hold \'em often enough, yo u\'re sure to see about everything that \ncan happen in the game. I\'m sure I have  seen everything. One night at the \nDunes  (in Las Vegas) I was involved in an unusual pot. I flopped a Set (of \nTrips) and had to settle for a split (pot).  Document(page_content='Here\'s a last illustration of the very st range things that sometimes occur in \nHold \'em. This interesting situation happened at the Horseshoe  in one of the \nside games (of which there are several) during Tournament time. I didn\'t see \nit, but I\'m sure I\'ve got it right becaus e it was talked about for days after it \nhappened.  \nBefore the Flop, A brought it in and B raised it. A called. On the Flop, A \nchecked and B bet. A called again. The ac tion was the same on Fourth. On the \nend, A checked again and B moved in on him. At that point, A couldn\'t beat \nthe Board... but, in frustration, he calle d. B won the pot, of course, with four \nTreys, King high. Bad Beat.  \nThe brief discussion of the similarities  and differences between Limit and No \nLimit Hold \'em that you\'ve just read was for some quick information only. \nBecause Hold \'em is not as widely played as Seven Card Stud, for example, \nthis little introduction was written for those of you who know nothing at all \nabout the game. Hopefully, even experienced players were able to learn \nsomething from it.  \nActually the differences between play at  No Limit and Limit Hold \'em are far \ngreater than the similarities. They\'re rea lly worlds apart. Proof of this is that \nI\'ve known very few players who can really play both forms jam up.  \nIt stands to reason that\'s true. Limit Ho ld \'em in fact, any form of Limit Poker \nis very much a mechanical game. Ther e\'s only so much you can do when \nthere are restrictions on the amount of money you can bet. That\'s not to say \nyou can\'t put a play on a man in Limit. You can. You just can\'t get too \n"fancy"...because there\'ll be someone ther e to look you up most of the time.  \nHowever, in No Limit, it\'s quite a differe nt story. There\'s so many things you \ncan do when you\'ve got almost as mu ch freedom as you could want. The \nmany options available to you in No Li mit play is what makes the game so \nmuch more complex than Limit. This w ill become quite apparent now that I\'m \ngoing to discuss the two versions separately.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 39}),
 Document(page_content="The answer to the little problem posed earlier is that the pot gets split. The \nEight kicker doesn't do Player A any good because he has a Pair of Kings with an Ace, Queen, Jack ... and so does Player B.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 40}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter Three: \nNo Limit Hold\'em: Introduction - Part \nI  \nThe Cadillac of Poker Games   \nThere\'s a story I\'ve been hearing all my life around Poker games. It\'s related to \na colourful player down in south Texas named Broomcorn. Whenever there\'s \nsomeone in the game who\'s playing re al tight, the opposing players will \nneedle him by saying: "Well, you\'re go nna go like Broomcorn\'s uncle." He\'d \nperk up and respond sharply: "What do  you mean I\'m gonna go like him?" \nAnd they\'d say: "Well, he anted himself to death."  \nThat\'s a little story you should always  keep in mind. Because whenever you \nfind yourself playing a very tight and defensive style of Poker ... you\'ll be in \ndanger of anteing yourself to "death". As I\'ve said throughout these \npages...the ante determines how fast you play in any Poker game. Since you\'ll \ngenerally play in a normal (or medium) ante game... if you play an aggressive \nstyle of Poker, you\'ll have way the best of it.  \nThat\'s the way I play ... and it works. This is especially true of No Limit \nHold\'em which, in my opinion is the Cadillac of Poker games. That opinion is \nnot because No Limit Hold \'em is my best game. It\'s an opinion shared by \nmany of the world\'s best Poker players ... some of whom are only beginning \nto appreciate the great variety of skills you need to be a top level Hold \'em \nplayer. As I\'ve said, although Hold \'em is similar in some respects to a game \nsuch as Seven Stud ... there are enough differences to put it in a class by itself. \nAnd it\'s truly a game that requires very special talents in order to play it at a \nworld class level.  \nAbove all else, No Limit Hold \'em is a game where you have to be aggressive \n... and you have to gamble. One of the great things about Hold \'em is that \nthere are so many different combinatio ns of hands and different things you \ncan do in different situations. As opposed to other forms of Poker, you can \nrepresent a lot of different hands in Hold \'em. You can also put your \nopponent on any one of several hands. It\'s a very complex game. You\'re forced to do a lot of guessing. So is your opponent.  \nIt comes to a point where you have to take a chance. If you want to be a \nwinner a big winner at No Limit Hold \'em ... you can\'t play a solid, safe \ngame. You must get in there and gamble.   \nMy philosophy of play at No Limit Hold  \'em is a simple one: I try to win big \npots ... and the small ones I pick up (w in without a contest). It\'s a philosophy \nthat necessitates a gambling style of play. My style. And it\'s this style that\'s \nfostered a lot of comment from countle ss players about how "lucky" I am. I\'ve \nbeen hearing that for a lot of years. The simple fact is it\'s not true. Everyone', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 41}),
 Document(page_content='gets lucky once in a while. But no one is  consistently lucky. So it has to be \nsomething other than luck to account for the fact I\'ve been a consistently big \nwinner through the years. It is somethin g else. You\'ll soon discover what that \n"something else" is.  \nI\'ve appeared to be a "lucky" player beca use every time a big pot came up, I\'ve \nusually had the worst hand. There are good reasons for that. I\'m a very aggressive player. I\'m reaching out and picking up small pots all the time. I\'m \nalways betting at those pots ... hammeri ng at them. And I don\'t want anybody \nto stop me from doing that. I don\'t want anyone to defeat my style of play.  \nConsequently, if I\'ve got any kind of a hand, any kind of a draw ... I bet. And \nif I get raised ... I don\'t quit. I go ah ead and get all my money in the pot \nknowing I\'ve probably got the worst ha nd that I\'m the underdog to win the \npot.  \nSometimes, I\'ll even call a Post Oak bluff (a  very small bet in a big pot) just to \nget a chance at a draw. Of course, if I\'m going to gamble like that ... the player \nI\'m in there with must have a lot of chip s on the table. For example, I\'ll have a \n10 9 and the Flop comes 8 3 2. And, let\'s say, there was $10,000 in the pot \nbefore the Flop. Now, with a raggedy Flop  like that, a tight player might try to \npick up the pot with a Post Oak bluff of  $1200. Well, that\'s a gutless bet* and \nI\'ll call it trying to catch a Jack or a Seven just so I could get an open end \nStraight draw on Fourth St. I\'m in a good position to pick up the pot on \nFourth whether or not I get the draw I want. The tight player who made that \nweak bet on the Flop is asking me to take his money. And, in most cases, \nthat\'s exactly what I\'m going to do when  the next card falls regardless of what \nit is. I\'m going to move in on that ti ght player because I feel confident he\'s \ngoing to throw his hand away and no t put his whole stack in jeopardy.  \nSince I play that way, I\'ve got a reputation of being an extremely aggressive \nplayer. And I don\'t ever want to lose that reputation. It\'s what enables me to \npick up more than what would normally be considered my share of pots.  \nIn most cases, my opponents are afraid to  play back at me because they know \nI\'m subject to set them all in. So, when th ey don\'t have a real big hand, they let \ngo of the pot ... and I pick it up (i n a way similar to what I\'d do when \nsomebody makes a Post Oak bluff at me).  The accumulation of all those small \npots is a big part of my winning form ula. It\'s the bonus I get for playing the \nway I do ... and it\'s the "secret" as to why I win.  \nIf I win ten pots where nobody has a bi g hand ten pots with let\'s say $3,000 in \nthem ... then I can afford to take 2 to 1 the worst of it and play a $30,000 pot. \nI\'ve already got that pot paid for with  all the small pots I picked up. And \nwhen I play that big pot. ..it\'s a freeroll.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 42}),
 Document(page_content='As I said a little while ago, when a big pot\'s played... I\'ve usually got the \nworst hand. I\'d say over 50% of the time  ... when all the money goes in, I\'ve \ngot the worst hand. Obviously, I couldn\'t overcome that unless I had \nsomething to compensate for it. And my compensation is all those small pots \nI\'ve picked up.  \n*I NEVER make a Post Oak bluff.   \nOf course, I\'m almost never completely out on a limb in a big pot. Whenever I \nmake a substantial bet or raise ... I\'ve al most always got an Out. Betting with \nan Out. That\'s what I call it. And it\'s  the Out I have that makes me appear \n"lucky" when I\'m a dog in a big pot and wind up winning it.  \nYou\'ll have additional compensations for playing the aggressive way I \nrecommend. You\'ll be able to break a lot of players because you\'re in there \ngambling all the time ... and, because of that, you\'ll get a lot of your real good hands paid off. Tight players don\'t get their real good hand s paid off because \nthey make a move so rarely that th eir hands are an "open book" whenever \nthey do. And they almost never change gears (start playing loose). But you\'ll \nbe out there betting, betting, betting all the time. Your opponents will see \nyou\'re an aggressive player. They\'ll know you\'re out there trying to pick up \nall those pots ... so they\'ll sometimes gi ve you a little loose action. And, since \nyou\'ll hold a few hands (you won\'t alwa ys be out there with the worst hand) \n... you\'ll break one or two of them. After that, they\'ll be scared to get involved \nwith you.  \nSo your style of play will be very de ceiving it\'ll get all the other players \nbefuddled. They won\'t know whether you\'v e really got a hand or not. They \nwon\'t know whether you\'re going to set them all in or not. Because they might \nhave to put all their money in the pot no t knowing if they have the best hand \n... they won\'t know what to do. And an ytime you get your opponents in that \nconfused situation you\'ll have an advantage over them.  \nOf course, you don\'t play every hand aggressively. Occasionally you slow \ndown ... and sometimes you completely stop and throw your hand away.  \nYou should never start out bluffing at a pot and keep bluffing at it without \nan Out.   \nFor example, whenever I raise the pot be fore the Flop., I\'m going to bet after \nthe Flop about 90% of the time. So if the Flop comes completely ragged (one \nthat doesn\'t look like anyone can have mu ch of it) ... I\'m going to bet at the pot \nand try to pick it up even if I don\'t have  a piece of the Flop. But, if I get called \n... I\'m usually going to give it up unless I have some kind of an Out [even as \nlittle as Third Button (a Pair made with the lowest card on the Flop) or an \ninside Straight draw]. Sometimes, you can keep hammering on certain players \nand drive them off even when you don\' t have an Out. But, you\'re usually \nbetter off when you have some kind of escape hatch.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 43}),
 Document(page_content='The reason I go ahead and put all. my mo ney in on occasion when I know I\'ve \nprobably got the worst hand deserves repeating since it\'s so important for you \nto understand. I do it because I don\'t want somebody playing back at me and \ntrying to stop me from being the aggre ssor. If I allow that to happen ... it\'ll \ncramp my style. I\'ll no longer be able to pick up all those pots when nobody \nhas a hand. And nobody\'s got anything a big percentage of the time. \nSomebody\'s got to get the money that\'s le ft out there. I want it to be me.  \nAn example will best show you what I\'m talking about. Let\'s say I raised \nbefore the Flop with a type of hand that\'s one of my favorites: small \nconnecting cards that are suited. I\'m in  the pot with one player who called \nbehind me. At this point, I put him on a couple of big cards or a medium Pair. \nThat\'s all right. It\'s what I want him to  have. Now, here\'s what\'ll happen if the \nfollowing Turn comes up.  \n \nWith that Flop, I\'m going to lead right o ff and bet. If he plays back at me, I\'m \nnow going to be quite sure he\'s got two Aces (or better). So, I\'m about a 9 to 5 \ndog. The pot (odds) will compensate a little bit for that price ... but it won\'t be laying me enough to put the rest of my money in. Yet, I\'ll go ahead and get it \nall in there because I don\'t want that same guy, who might be a pretty good \nplayer, taking a Jack Ten and making that same play when I don\'t have \nanything. To let his play succeed, I ha ve to throw my hand away and give \nhim the pot. Because I want the pot ... I can\'t let him succeed. I want him to \nfear me. I want him to have the opinion I\'m going to defend the money I put \nout there. I don\'t want him to have any doubts. So I go ahead and put the rest \nof my money in.  \nIn making that play on the Flop, there\' s a good chance I can win the pot right \nthere. Because I\'m known to play any reasonable hand (and some \n"unreasonable" hands in a short handed hi gh ante game) ... I\'ve really made it \ntough on him. I could\'ve flopped a Set (of Trips), Two Pair or even the \nStraight. I\'ve put him on the defensive ... and he\'s got a lot of guessing to do.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 44}),
 Document(page_content="If he decides to call me ... it's not all that bad because I've got an Out. If I make \nmy Straight, I'm going to break him. An d if I draw out on him ... it appears \nlike I got lucky again. Well, I did ... and I didn't. When I moved in on him, I \nwas gambling to pick up the pot. When  I didn't succeed because of his call ... \nyou might say I got unlucky. What's more ... I am supposed to make my \ndraws once in a while. In fact, in that sp ecific situation I'll draw out more than \none third of the time (by making my Straight or back dooring Two Pair or \nTrips).  \nA very interesting thing about that part icular hand of 7 6 is that I'd rather \nhave it than a 9 8. The reason is that  when you turn a Straight with a 9 8 ... \nyou'll frequently find that somebody is on top of you. A good example is \nwhen the Flop comes Q J 10. An A K will have you nutted and even a Sucker \nwho plays a K 9 will have you beat. I' ve turned many a Straight with a 9 \n8...but when a Q J 10 falls, I'm always real cautious with the hand. Because \npeople play the higher cards more freq uently than the lower ones, you're less \nlikely to be in trouble when you turn a Straight with a 7 6 than you would be \nwith a 9 8.  \nI'll discuss the general category of sm all connecting cards in great detail a \nlittle later. As I previously noted, they'r e one of my favorite hands. Another of \nmy favorites is a hand where you can turn a double belly buster (two way \ninside) Straight. It's one of the most deceiving hands there is ... and I \nespecially like it in No Limit. Because it's so deceptive, I almost invariably \nraise with it when I can win a big pot. It  has all the advantages of an open end \nStraight... but it's not as easy to read.  \nAn example of turning a double belly bu ster is when you have a Q 10 and the \nTurn comes A J 8. As you can see, it's very deceptive because you can make a \nStraight with a Nine or a King. What's more, if you catch a King and there's \nsomeone in the pot with you with A K ... you can see all the trouble he's in.  \nSince double belly busters are such g ood gambling hands (because of their \ndeceptive qualities), you might find the following quick rule of thumb useful \nfor now.  \nIt's possible to turn a double belly buste r with any two cards that are part of \na Straight such as a 7 6, 8 6, 9 6 and a 10 6. Also, two cards with five gaps between them such as a Q 6 can also turn a double belly buster draw. (In \nthe Supplement at the end of this section you'll find a complete rundown \non all the hands that have double belly buster potential.)   \nWhen you turn a double belly buster draw, you should very carefully note \nwhich of your possible Straights will be the nuts. For example, if you have a J \n9 and the Fall is K 10 7 ... both an Eight and a Queen will make you a Straight. \nHowever, only the Eight will give you th e nuts. If a Queen falls on Fourth, \nsomeone with an A J can beat your Straigh t. So you must be careful especially \nin No Limit play and you must know ho w to read the Board perfectly (to see", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 45}),
 Document(page_content="what hand is the absolute nuts), Prac tice at home, until you don't make a \nsingle mistake. You're sure to learn af ter you get broke a few times with what \nyou thought was the nuts, but was actually the second best hand.  \nA good case in point is the example noted in the above paragraph. A player \ncould easily think he had the best Straight when the Queen fell ... until \nsomeone showed him an A J for all his money.  \nAn easy way to determine whether your Straight is the nuts is by using one \nof the following observations. You'll have the nut Straight if:  \n1. the high end of the Straight is made up with the highest card in your \nhand; or  \n2. the high end of the highest possible Straight is already on the Board.  \nDrawing to a double belly buster is on e of few exceptions in No Limit where \nyou might be drawing to an inside Strai ght that won't make the best hand. As \nI noted earlier, inside Straight draws can be real good plays in No Limit Hold \n'em because for a few chips you have th e opportunity to win a very big pot. \nBut, you almost never draw to a (single)  belly buster Straight that will not be \nthe best hand if you make it. They're lo ngshot plays ... so when you do make \nthem, you want to be sure they're the nuts.  \nFor example, let's say you held a Q J and the Fall was 9 8 4. Now, you might \nwant to draw at that belly buster tryi ng to catch a Ten even in Limit, but \nmostly in No Limit. You know if you ca tch that Ten, you'll have a cinch hand. \nBut if you held a 6 5 ... you'd never d raw to it (with the same Fall) because \nthere'd be two different Straights that could beat you if you catch a Seven. \n(You'd lose to a 6 7 8 9 10 and a 7 8 9 10 J.) If a man makes a Straight with you, \nhe's either got you tied or he's got you beat. So, you never draw to the dead \nend of a (single) belly buster.  \nBefore you decide to draw to a belly buster, you also want to feel reasonably \ncertain that your opponent is going to gamble with you if you do make it. I \nmean, they're good plays ... but only if you can win a big pot if you make your \nlongshot. So you want your opponent to have the best hand possible on the \nBoard. If it came a 9 8 4 (as above) ... ideally, you want your opponent to have \n3 Nines. You don't want him to have a Pair of Kings or A 9. You want him to \nhave at least Eights and Nines, or better, 3 Nines. You want him to have a very big hand. Your Q J would be a very good hand against 3 Nines. It \nwouldn't be as good against a Pair of  Nines because it won't make enough \nmoney. Your opponent will release a Pair  far more readily than he'll release a \nSet.  \nSo if you can get in real cheap and have  the potential to win a big pot ... belly \nbuster Straights are good gambles. But, you also have to be very selective \nabout the belly busters you do draw to. You don't want it to be apparent to", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 46}),
 Document(page_content='your opponent that you could\'ve made a Straight. In the illustration just used, \nyou might not get the action you want if  a Ten falls off on Fourth Street. A \nQueen jack is actually a weak hand when the Flop is 9 8 4. Your opponent \nmight put you on a 7 6 and, when the Te n came, he might be very leery about \ncalling a big bet you made. The Straight possibility might even scare him off \ncompletely.  \nBut, if a possible Straight wasn\'t so a pparent when the Ten came off ... then, \nyou could probably win a lot of money. Let\'s say, you had the Qh 9h and the \nFlop was J 8 2. You might want to pick the Ten off there ... because that would \nbe a very deceptive belly buster draw. And that\'s the kind of inside Straight \nyou want to draw for to win a big pot the ones that aren\'t so obvious.  \nIf you graduate from Limit Hold \'em to No Limit, you\'ll find that you\'ll be \ndoing many things (besides drawing to inside Straights) that simply won\'t \nwork when all it can cost your opponent is another bet.  \nA good example of a bluff that has a lot of power to it in No Limit, but will \nrarely work at Limit play is when th e Board\'s one card off a Straight on \nFourth. Let\'s say there\'s an A K Q J out there and your opponent bets. You\'ve \ngot a Ten in the hole so you\'ve got the nuts, (There\'s no Flush possible.) Your \nopponent bets, you raise and he plays back. Now ... there\'s no question he\'s \ngot a Straight also.  \nAn unsophisticated player would move  in on him right there because he \nknows he can\'t lose. But, what good is that? He\'s only going to get a split.  \nHowever, add some drama and a little acting to your play and there\'s a \nchance you could win it all. You know you\'re going to call his re raise ... but you don\'t have to do it instantaneously. Take your time. Just stall around. \nStudy the Board real hard and shake your head several times making it \nappear as though you overlooked the po ssible Straight. You could even pick \nup your cards slightly and make him think you\'re going to throw them away. \nThen.. put them back down and say "OK, I\'ll call it,"  \nWith all your agonizing, he\'s got to give you credit for a Set. You\'ve made him \nthink you\'re gambling the Board will pair so you\'ll make a Full. If the Board \ndoes pair on the end ... you bet him all your money. There\'s almost no risk to \nthat play. You represent a Full and many  a time your opponent will throw his \nhand away. It works a lot of times. (O f course, it\'s harder to do in Limit \nbecause all the guy has to do is call one bet.)  \nAs you can see from the play just descr ibed, bluffing often involves a lot of \n"art". But, there\'s "science" to it also. There\'s even science to calling a bluff. The \nfollowing pot I was involved in w ill clearly illustrate what I mean.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 47}),
 Document(page_content='It was a small (ante) No Limit game early in my career. I was on the Button so \nI limped in with a J 10 in the hole. (The re were two players in the pot in front \nof me.) Here\'s what the Flop looked like:  \n \nAs you see, I had two to a (belly) Straigh t. Since there was no raise before the \nFlop, I was reasonably sure neither of  my two opponents had very strong \nhands.  \nOn the Flop, the guy in the first seat made a reasonable (size) bet* and the \nplayer in front of me called it. Both players had a lot of money in front of \nthem ... so I also called.  \nThe. fourth card was the 2s. They both checked on Fourth St. and so did I. The \nlast card was the 3d. The Board now looked like this:  \nWhen all the cards were out, the guy in the first seat checked again. I felt \nwhen he bet (on the Flop) and then checked twice (on Fourth and Fifth) ... he \nhad the top Pair with a small kicker. I felt the guy in front of me was drawing \nat some kind of Straight (and, obviously, missed his hand). Much to my \nsurprise, he made a real out of line bet on the end far bigger than the size of \nthe pot.  \nWhen he did that, it looked to me like he  was clearly trying to steal the pot. I \nwas also sure I had him highcarded. (As I said, I felt sure he was drawing at a \nsmaller Straight than I was.)  \nIf I was correct in thinking I had been  drawing at the highest possible Straight \n... I "knew" I\'d win the pot if I just ca lled. (I also "knew" the other player \ncouldn\'t overcall because his hand wasn\'t strong enough.)  \nSo I called that out of line bet...and my analysis proved correct. The player \nwith the Pair threw his hand away and the guy who over bet the pot was drawing to a little Straight. So I won the pot with a lack high.  \n*Throughout these discussions, a reasonab le (size) bet meant about the size \nof the pot.   \nI didn\'t tell you that Poker story beca use I won the pot with a Jack high. And \nyou shouldn\'t remember it for that reas on. It has a more significant message.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 48}),
 Document(page_content='I stated that I "felt" neither guy had much of anything. I then went on to \nexplain why I had that feeling. Obviousl y, it was more than just a nebulous \nfeel that I had. I had played with both  those guys often ... so my feel was a \ncertain amount of reasoning and a process of elimination was involved. And a \nlot of it was based on recall.  \nWhenever I use the word "feel"...you sh ould understand it\'s not some extra \nsensory power that I have (although, as I noted in the section on GENERAL \nPOKER STRATEGY, I do believe there is so mething to the theories relating to \nESP). I recall what happened ... even th ough I might not consciously do it...I \nrecall that this same play came up (or something close to it) and this is what \nhe did or what somebody else did. So I ge t a feeling that he\'s bluffing or that I \ncan make a play here and get the pot. But, actually my subconscious mind is \nreasoning it all out.  \nYou build up a history of every player you ever played with ... I mean \neveryone that you\'ve ever done any serious gambling with. You\'ve got some \nkind of information on them. It\'s ther e ... buried in your mind. And you don\'t \nhave to concentrate to get it out. When  the time comes to use it, it\'ll come \nnaturally you won\'t have to force it.  \nAll good Poker players have tremendous recall. They reach back into the \ndepths of their mind and remember what a certain guy did in a similar \nsituation. A good player might not re alize what he\'s doing ... and he might \nnot know exactly what it is ... but he feels he can make a real big play or make \na super call when he feels a guy\'s bluffing . The vibrations are definitely there. \nHe just knows it.  \nAnd what it actually is, is a sense of recall. The same (or similar) situation \nexisted some time ago ... and he knows ex actly what to do in this one. It\'s \nusually a stress situation when a (relativ ely) big amount of money\'s involved \nthat these things are always true.  \nThere\'s another kind of "feel" you can ha ve in a game that doesn\'t depend on \nrecall. This type of feel depends on close observation of what\'s going on \nduring a particular session. You acquire this feel when you notice that a \ncertain player is really off his game and playing far below the quality of play \nhe\'s normally capable of. You see this happen all the time. A lot of players \nlose control and go on tilt after they get one (or more) big hands cracked \n(beaten). They become unglued (lose thei r composure). To recoup their losses, \nthey start playing weak hands ... and th ey play those hands badly. Very \nbadly. It\'s easy to capitalize on those situations. Here\'s how:  \nLet\'s say you\'re in a game with a high ante structure (a subject I\'ll soon \ndiscuss) and naturally everybody\'s playing real fast. You played a 9 6 and the \nFlop came A 9 8. Normally, if you got played with, you\'d be very concerned \nabout that Ace (and also your kicker). Bu t, in this case, you\'re in the pot with a', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 49}),
 Document(page_content='player who\'s losing and, from what you\'v e been able to observe, he\'s playing \nvery badly. You check on the Flop ... and so does he.  \nNow, all of a sudden, you get a "feel" that all he\'s got is the Third Button (a \nPair of Eights). The reason why you feel he got "something" (a small piece of \nthe Flop) is because he checked. He di dn\'t bet because he wants to get the \nhand shown down. If he had nothing at all ... he would\'ve bet to try to steal the pot. And, you "know" he doesn\'t have an Ace. You know the worst that \ncan happen is that he could also have a Nine and run you down (chase you). \nWell, what you want is for him to run you down with an Eight which is what \nyou really think he has. You know if yo u\'re really off base ... he might have a \nNine.  \nBut, you feel confident you\'re not wron g and if a Rag falls off on Fourth ... \nyou bet. You know he\'s going to call you ... almost out of desperation because \nhe\'s losing. So you make some money on Fourth and also on the end. You \nknow he\'s not going to show you a hand unless he gets lucky and pairs his \nkicker.  \nThe very surprising thing about the prev ious discussion is that the player I \nwas referring to who\'s on tilt is actually  a very good player. He could even be \nworld class. Of course, the super stars of the Poker world those who I play \nagainst on a regular basis are able to  exercise far more control than the \naverage player. Yet, even a real good player has moments when he\'s playing \nconsiderably off his usual game. So, you have to be observant and take \nadvantage of such opportunities when they present themselves. You\'ll have \nfar more opportunities to do that against the average player simply because \nthey lose control far more often.  \nThere\'s something else that\'s extremel y important that you\'ll have to be \nconstantly aware of. It\'s this:  \nYou\'ll have to be able to categorize your opponents as to the quality of their \nplay ... and you\'ll have to play very di fferently against st rong players than \nyou do against weaker ones. This is of crucial importance in No- Limit play.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 50}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter Three: \nNo Limit Hold'em: Introduction - Part \nII  \nShortly, I'm going to go into considerab le detail on this very important subject \nbecause I've seen very good players fa il to adjust their strategy when they're \nin a pot with a certain type of player. In fact, as recently as the 1977 World \nSeries of Poker (in the World Championsh ip Hold 'em event), some of the best \nplayers I know made such amateurish mistakes that I wouldn't have believed \nit possible if I hadn't seen it with my own two eyes. But, before I get into the \nspecific details, I want to give you tw o general rules to guide you in this \nmatter.  \n1. Against a low grade player ... you simply make the obvious \nplay. That is, you don't try to get fancy when you're in a pot with a weak player. You don't try to make subtle moves that'll be far beyond his capacity to understand or appreciate. You play fundamentally better (rather than strategically better) than a weak player. In a word, you outplay him.  \n2. Against a higher grade player ... (someone who could be \nthinking along the same lines as you)…you must mix up your play. Sometimes you make an obvious play against a strong player (as you always would against a weak player) ... and sometimes you go at it another way and make a play that's not so obvious. Most of the time ... you have to put a play on (outmanoeuvre) a strong player.  \nIn a nutshell, that's all there is to it . And it seems simple and logical enough. \nThere's even very good players who kn ow that that's wh at they're supposed \nto do. But knowing something ... and bein g able to execute it are not the same \nthing. As I said, I saw some world cla ss Poker players make mistakes in the \n1977 World Championship Tournament th at only an idiot would make.  \nThere was a particular player Who entere d the Tournament for the first time \n... and, almost immediately, it was easy to see that he was a weak player. He was the supreme example of a calling station a player who's next to \nimpossible to bluff.  \nEven though I had never played against him before, it didn't take me very \nlong to recognize the type of player he was. I've played with thousands just \nlike him throughout my career. So I kn ew what to do when I was involved \nwith him in a pot. More precisely ... I knew what not to do. I was not going to \ntry to bluff him. Not even once.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 51}),
 Document(page_content="I quickly decided that if I was in the pot with him, I was going to show him a \nhand. And, if he got lucky enough to be at me ... well, he was going to beat a \nhand. My mind was made up about that.  \nBut there were other very good players in the Tournament who tried to run \nover him tried to force him out of a pot. They would bluff at him constantly ... \nand they were rarely successful. If he ha d anything at all ... he looked 'em up. \nAs I said, he was the ultimate calling st ation. He looked enough of them up \noften enough to finish far higher than  he was legitimately supposed to. He \nwas probably about a 1000 to 1 dog to finish  as high as he did. The reason he \ndid was simply because so many players and some very experienced ones just \nhanded him their money. They almost literally gave it away to him.  \nWhat they should not have done is try to bluff him. It takes an idiot, in my \nbook, to bluff at a man who you know is going to call you.  \nYou simply can't bluff a bad player ... because a bad player will play when \nhe's got some kind of a hand and will pass when he doesn't have a hand. I \nmean ... it's clear cut. You don't have to be an expert psychologist to figure out \nwhat he's doing. All you have to know  is if he's in the pot.. he's got \nsomething. And you're not going to get him out of the pot by trying to bluff \nhim.  \nAbove all ... you don't want to gamble with a weak player. Forget about that \n... show him a hand. You do very funda mental things against a bad player. \nObvious things. That is ... no tricks ... no  strategic plays ... nothing fancy. Play \nstraight forward Poker against a weak player.  \nFor example, if a weak player raised th e pot coming in (before the Flop) and \nthen checked it on the Flop and chec ked again on Fourth St. well, I would \nautomatically bet (regardless of what I' ve got) because I'd know he didn't \nhave anything at all. It's simple to outplay him because his actions tell me \nwhether he's got something or not. There's no mystery about it.  \nI could also outplay him by adjusting my style to his. For example, I noted \nthat I'm always stabbing around trying to pick up pots. I could still do that \nwith a weak player in the pot ... but I'd ad just my play because he's in there. \nLike I might raise him without looking at my hand. Now, here comes the \nTurn and he checks. Well, I'm going to be t at that pot in the dark ... because I \nknow he doesn't have anything and I also know he's probably going to pass. \nHe checked, didn't he? If he had something, he would've bet.  \nOf course, I might have to make a further adjustment. If he checked (on the \nFlop) and then called me ... I'd give him credit for something. If there's no \nStraight or Flush draw out there ... he's  probably got a small piece of the \nBoard. (If he had a big piece...he would've bet.) If he checks again on Fourth \nand calls me again ... then I'd know I'm going to have to show him a hand on", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 52}),
 Document(page_content='the end unless I thought he was drawing and missed his hand. Only then \nwould I think I had a chance to steal it on the end.  \nAnother way I\'d adjust my style when I was in the pot with a weak player is \nwhen I turned a real big hand say, a Set of Trips. As you\'ll learn, I don\'t slow \nplay that hand. I always lead with it. But, against a weak player...I would \ncheck it because I\'d know that if he ha d anything, he would bet. And I\'d get to \nbreak him anyway. If he didn\'t have an ything, I wouldn\'t mind giving him a \nfree card. I want him to improve his hand. I want him to make something so I \ncould break him there.  \nIt\'s more difficult to outplay a strong player. You can\'t do simple things \nagainst better players you\'ve got to put a play on somebody who knows what\'s obvious. And if he does some thing that\'s obvious like I think he\'s \ntrying to pick up the pot ... well, I\'ll put a play on him and raise him with \nnothing because he might throw his hand away. But if a weak player bets at \nme, I\'m not going to raise him... unless I\'ve got something.  \nSince a good player will understand the ob vious, I must try to deceive him. I\'ll \neven put a play on more than one good player. For example, if someone \nbrought it in (raised it) in an early posi tion and three players just called it ... I \nmight try to pick up that pot. I might move in with nothing.  \nAgainst a good player, you\'ll have a lot more tools to work with ... many \ndifferent strategies to use. You\'re effe ctively restricted to a "pickaxe and \nshovel" basic, fundamental things agai nst a weak player. Never forget that. \nDon\'t try to devise elaborate strategies to use against a bad player. They won\'t \nwork against him. Use sophisticated plays against a good player. They\'ll work \nagainst him.  \nAnother point you should note about weak players is that they come in \nseveral varieties. They\'re not all like  the one I just described. Some are \ncompletely opposite. There are some who check their good hands and bet \ntheir bad hands. They like to bluff ... an d they do it almost all the time. So, \nwith a player like that, you keep on ch ecking it to him ... and let him bluff his \nmoney off to you.  \nNote that I didn\'t say you check raise him. You don\'t want to take the play \naway from that type of player. In fact, check raising is a strategy I rarely use. I \nthink it\'s a weak play. I\'ll do it occasionally ... but not often.  \nHowever, I suppose I encounter more ch eck raising than the average player \nbecause I play so aggressively. If a player makes a hand, he\'ll check it to me \nthinking that I\'m going to bet ... and he\'s usually right. Most of the time, I will \nbet. So he checks it to me ... and after I bet he raises.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 53}),
 Document(page_content='As I said, I don\'t do too much check rai sing myself. I\'ll usually do it when \nsomeone seems to be trying to take th e play away from me. Perhaps, I might \ncheck it ... and move in on him or someth ing like that. But, I don\'t do it often. \nCheck raising is not really a part of my philosophy of Poker. I do it on \noccasion you have to keep people in line but I don\'t look for opportunities to \ncheck raise somebody.  \nSurprisingly, if you employ my style of play at No Limit Hold \'em ... you \nwon\'t be in constant fear of getting check raised. By playing aggressively, you \nmight think that "well, they\'re probably going to get me this time" every time \nyou bet. But, even though you\'ll probab ly encounter more check raising than \nmost players, you\'ll be amazed at ho w many times your opponents keep \nthrowing their hands away  whenever you bet.  \nIt all reverts back to my basic style of  play. My opponents know that if I\'ve \ngot any kind of a hand any kind of a draw and they do check raise me ... then \nall of my money (and theirs) is goin g to the middle. And ... because they \nknow that ... it keeps them off me it stops them from playing back at me.  \nThere are other things that my aggressive  style of play does for me. Not only \ndoes it give me an "umbrella of protec tion" from getting played back at (in \nmost cases) and not only does it make  my opponents constantly fear me and \ntherefore make it easy for me to pick up numerous pots without a contest ... \nbut it has other advantages as well. I\'ve  already told you I also get a lot of \nloose action. This may seem contradictory ... because how can I pick up pots \neasily on the one hand and get a lot of l oose action on the other? But, it\'s easy \nto understand when you realize that the pots I pick up are when nobody\'s got \na hand. And, as I said, that\'s a big percentage of the time. When I get so called \n"loose action"...it\'s when somebody does have a hand. At those times, all the \nmoney is subject to go to the center. And when it does as you now know I\'ve \nusually got the worst hand.  \nBut I can also find a hand when I look  down. And, once in a while, it\'s the \nbest hand. When I\'m up against another hand at those times ... the pot gets to \nbe a mountain. It wouldn\'t be nearly as big if I wasn\'t the aggressive player I \nam. I\'d never get the action I do when I\' ve got a hand if I was known to slow \nplay hands ... or do a lot of check- raisi ng. That\'s why I rarely do those things.  \nAn example of why being known as an  aggressive player and constantly \nplaying that way is the most profitable way to play Poker is clearly illustrated \nby the following situation.  \nLet\'s say I turned a big hand on the Flop a Set of Trips or even Two Pair. I\'m \nfirst to act and I\'m in the pot with so meone who raised before the Flop. He\'s \nsupposed to have a strong hand. He\'s probably got a big Pair in the hole \nbigger than anything that showed on the Flop.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 54}),
 Document(page_content="In this situation, there's a principle I always apply in Hold 'em. I always \nmake it a habit to lead into the raiser whenever I turn a big hand.   \nMost players will slow play their hand in that spot ... or hope to get in a check \nraise. When they do that, they're play ing it wrong ... as you'll now see.  \nBy betting right into the raiser, you ma ke him think you're either trying to \ntake the pot away from him or you've got some kind of draw or a mediocre hand. Consequently, he'll almost invariably raise you. At that point ... you can \nget all your chips in. And it's tough for him to get away from his hand \nbecause he has so much money already in the pot.  \nThe raiser expects you to check to hi m on the Flop. I mean, he knows you \nknow he's supposedly got a strong hand. He raised coming in, didn't he?  \nWhen most players turn a Set with a small Pair (or turn Two Pair with small \nconnecting cards) ... they do the obviou s. They check ... waiting for the raiser \nto bet. And then they put in a raise.  \nThat's the wrong way to play it. That way they give the raiser an opportunity \nto get away from his hand at a minimum loss. But, if you lead into him ... and \nhe raises there's no savings. He's almost committed to get the rest of his \nmoney in the pot.  \nEven if it's a raggedy Flop without a Straight or Flush draw you should still \nmake the same play. Perhaps even more  so ... because with three Rags out \nthere a bet would indicate weakness rathe r than strength to most players. \nSince it does look like you're weak (and like you're trying to take the pot away \nfrom him) ... the average player will respond to your bet by raising.  \nThe only risk you take when you play the hand that way is that the raiser \nmight not raise you on the Flop because he might not have a hand ... but he might bluff at it if you check and you'd win the amount he bluffed.  \nHowever, it's far more probable he does have a hand. He's supposed to have a \nhand! He's represented a hand. He was the raiser. On that very reasonable \nassumption, I go ahead and lead into his hand. When compared to \ncheckraising in that situation, it's the bigger money making play, by far. I \nthink it's one of the strongest plays in Hold 'em.  \nIf you turned a Set in an unraised po t (and it was a raggedy Flop) ... you'd \nhave to play the hand quite differently . Depending on what Set you flopped, \nyou might not even play it at all. You' ll see what I mean in a minute. But, the \nconcept you should understand is this:  \nIn No Limit play, you must be very ca reful you don't lose all your chips in \nan unraised pot.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 55}),
 Document(page_content='Here\'s what I mean: let\'s say you and six other players got in for the absolute \nminimum that is, you all limped in for a $50 force (the Blind bet). Everybody \njust called. Nobody raised ... so the field wasn\'t weeded out at all. Now, a J 4 2 \nflops. You turn 3 Deuces. In the previo us situation with this same Flop you \nshould lead right into the raiser with yo ur Set. He\'s probably got an overpair \nand will raise as expected. But, in the present situation, you must play it \ncarefully. Very carefully. You turned a hand that\'s easy to get broke with. \nThere\'s nothing in the pot ... and you do n\'t want to get broke in a "nothing" \npot.  \nThe six people in the pot with you tried to turn the nuts for free. And one of \nthem might have the nuts. Or close to it. So when one of the players commits \nall his money when there\'s only a few hundred dollars in the pot ... you better \nwatch out. Your 3 Deuces probably aren\'t any good.  \nYou could be up against 3 Jacks, but that \'s not as likely as 3 Fours since there \nwas no raise before the Flop. That\'s the hand you should be afraid of 3 Fours.  \nI\'m not saying you shouldn\'t play the hand. That\'s not the case at all. I\'m just \nsaying that you have to play it carefully because nobody showed any early \nstrength. Therefore, you\'re not likely to be up against a big Pair. However, \nyou could be facing another Set. Nevertheless, if it\'s checked to you, you\'ve \ngot to bet it. But you don\'t want to get broke with the hand because it was a \nnothing pot to begin with. If you get raised, your own judgement in the \nparticular situation will have to preva il. With the Third Set (Deuces), you \nmight want to go on with the hand ... and then you might not. With the \nSecond Set (Fours) ... you just could not get away from it. Someone\'s going to \nhave to show you 3 Jacks. That\'s all there is to it.  \nAn important point for you to remember  is that in a judgement situation \nyou\'re always better off sticking to your first impression. Once you decide what a man\'s most likely to have espe cially in No Limit play you should \nnever change your mind. You\'ll probably be right the first time ... so don\'t \ntry to second guess yourself.   \nWith constant observation of your o pponents\' play... you\'ll learn how to put \nthem on a (probable) hand. Once you do...don\'t change your mind. Stick to \nyour first impression. Have the courage of your convictions!', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 56}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter Three: \nNo Limit Hold\'em: Introduction - Part \nIII  \nHaving courage is one of the most impo rtant qualities you must have to be a \ngood No Limit player. If you don\'t have it ... you\'ll have to restrict your play \nto Limit Poker. You need courage in Limit too ... but not nearly to the degree \nyou must have it at No Limit.  \nA lot of Limit players and now I\'m talking about the very best Limit players \njust can\'t play No Limit. They don\'t have  the "heart" for it. What\'s more ... they \ncan\'t adjust to the complexity of No Limi t play and they find it very hard to \ngo from what\'s essentially a mechanical  game (Limit) to one that takes in \neverything (No Limit). Only very specia l players can make that transition \nsuccessfully.  \nYou also have to have a different "feel" for No Limit play. I mean, you have to \nbe right just about all the time especially when your entire stack\'s at stake.  \nIn Limit play, you\'re not going to get knocked out of a game by one or two \nmistakes. You can make several mistakes in a Limit game and still win the \nmoney ... because your opponents are ma king more mistakes than you are. \nPlaying No Limit, you can make just one crucial mistake at any time and you \ncan lose all your chips.  \nIt not only takes a lot of "heart" to pl ay No Limit ... it also takes a lot of \n"muscle". You need "muscle" in Limit t oo.. but you need much more of it at \nNo Limit.  \nA strong No Limit player can keep "s lapping you around" just "lean on" you \nand keep "leaning on" you until you me lt. Of course, that could happen in \nLimit too ... but, again, not to the same degree.  \nThe very best players I know are extr emely aggressive players ... and that\'s \nwhat makes them the great players they  are. The more aggressive they are ... \nthe better they are. It\'s that simple. And I firmly believe that\'s what accounts \nfor the difference between a very good pl ayer and a truly top player. It\'s the \ndividing line. That\'s for sure.  \nThere\'s not a man alive that can keep beating on me. I refuse to let somebody \nkeep taking my money ... and all the othe r truly top players are the same way. \nAn aggressive player might do it for a while ... keep leaning on me. But, at the \nfirst opportunity I get, I\'m going to ta ke a stand and put all my money in the \npot.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 57}),
 Document(page_content='It\'s like that little boy who keeps stic king his head up and keeps getting \nslapped all the time. Well, sooner or late r he\'s not going to stick his head up \nany more. So if a guy keeps going on and on and keeps pounding on me ... \nthen me and him are fixing to play a pot.  \nLike me, all the top players know you have to be extremely aggressive to be a \nconsistent winner. You have to bet, bet, bet...all the time. If I find somebody I \ncan keep betting at and he keeps saying "take it Doyle", "take it Doyle"...well, \nI\'m going to keep pounding on him. I\' m not going to let up. And that poor \nguy never will win a pot from me. He\'s goin g to have to have the nuts to call \nme.  \nThat\'s what most players do ... they k eep throwing their hand away. They\'re \nweak. They sit down and try to make the nuts on you. That\'s hard to do. So \nyou keep whamming on \'em and wha mming on \'em and you just wear \'em \ndown. And, sooner or later, you\'ll win all their money.  \nPerhaps now, you can see more clearly what I explained to you earlier. When \na big pot comes up ... I\'ve usually got the worst hand. That weak player finally picked up the nuts ... and that\'s what I usually look at in a big pot. But, \nI\'ve already paid for that big pot with  all the other pots I\'ve won. So I\'m \nfreerolling with all that weak player\'s money (and the money of all the other \nweak players in the game).  \nYou can\'t do that against a truly top play er in No Limit ... because he\'s fixing \nto make a stand and play back at you.  And that\'s the big difference between a \nmerely good player and a great one.  \nAnother important difference is that a real top player can win money with a \nmarginal hand. A weaker player can\'t do that. They don\'t know how ... or \nthey\'re afraid to put any money in the po t in a borderline situation. They want \nthe nuts (or close to it) before they\'ll jeopardize any of their chips. They don\'t \nwant to do too much gambling...so they check a lot of hands that I\'d bet for \nvalue.  \nBetting for value is what it\'s all about. For example, if it came down to a tough \nsituation on the end and a tight player  had Two Pair, but there\'s a possible \nStraight out there ... well, that tight play er would probably check it trying to \nshow the hands down.  \nIn that same situation, as long as I fe lt reasonably sure my opponent didn\'t \nhave that Straight I\'d be more aggressive. I want to make some money on the \nend. I want to get value for my Two Pair. So I\'d bet... and try to sell my hand \nfor the most money I thought I could get.  \nI don\'t have to have the nuts to bet my hand on the end. If I feel like I\'ve got \nthe best hand ... I\'m going to bet it and get value for it. A more conservative', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 58}),
 Document(page_content='player would check it on the end and he\' ll get his check "called". So he\'ll lose \nthat last bet.  \nI never was a tight player ... even when I first started to play. Experience has \ntaught me a lot. Early in my career, I didn\'t know how to start at a pot and \nquit ... like I can now.  \nA very big part of winning consistently and winning big at No Limit is to get \nthe other guy in a position where if he  makes a bet he\'s actually jeopardizing \nall his chips as opposed to you jeopardizing all of yours.  \nThat has always been the key to No Limit play as far as I\'m concerned. I \nwant to put my opponent to a decision for all his chips.   \nFor example, if a guy\'s got twenty thou sand dollars in chips and you lead off \nfor six or seven thousand ... you\'re really betting him twenty thousand. This is \nbecause he knows if he calls that six or  seven thousand ... well, then, he\'s got \nto go for the rest of it.  \nYou\'re betting seven thousand ... he\'s betting twenty.  \nHowever, if he bets me seven ... it\'s just  the reverse. So, I always try to make \nthe bet that puts him in jeopardy ... not me. If he\'s right ... and I\'m bluffing ... \nhe\'s going to move in with his twenty thousand and I\'m not going to call him. \nSo he\'ll win seven thousand. But, if he\'s wrong ... and I\'ve got a hand....he\'s \nstill going to move in. But now he\'s going to get called and he\'s going to lose twenty thousand.  \nSo he\'s laying me about 3 to 1 his twenty thousand to my seven. I put the \ncommitment on him. I make him commit himself. I\'m not committed. \nWhether he thinks I am or not ... I\'m not.  That\'s the beauty of it. He\'s thinking \nabout my bet ... and wondering how much more he\'s going to have to put in \nthere.  \nIt\'s an either/or situation. Either I\' m bluffing ... or I\'ve got the nuts. And \nagainst me, he knows it could cost him twenty thousand his whole stack \nunless he throws his hand away.  \nAnd, boy, you\'d be surprised how many times they say "take it Doyle", "take \nit Doyle". They just throw their hand away and throw their hand away ... over \nand over and over again. I mean ... even I\'m surprised. I think to myself "well, \nhe CAN\'T throw this one away".. but I bet anyway. And there goes his hand \n... chunk! It finally gets to be mechan ical with them. And I\'ve won another \npot.  \nI\'ve stolen so many pots I couldn\'t be gin to count them. And most of the time, \nI\'ve actually had to force myself to bet.  I\'d be playing and I hadn\'t held a hand \nall night. Yet ... I won every pot becaus e I hadn\'t bet into the nuts yet.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 59}),
 Document(page_content='It goes on and on like that. I pick up  a hand and I\'ve got nothing. The Flop \ncomes out there and I\'ve still got nothing. So  I kind of have to hit myself to bet \nat it because there\'s a guy I\'ve been pounding on and pounding on. And, all \nthe time, I\'m thinking "how can he thro w his hand away this time"? But I bet \n... and away it goes. Chunk! ... one more time.  \nIf he takes a stand and raises me ... it gets back to my basic philosophy. If I\'ve \ngot a hand ... I\'ll go with it even though  I know it\'s sometimes the worst hand.  \nBy now, you should have a very good id ea of how I play No Limit Hold \'em. I \nhope this somewhat lengthy introduction  gave you a sufficient "feel" for my \nstyle of play...and I also hope it will help you to understand how I play \nspecific hands in various situatio ns. I\'ll discuss those shortly.  \nHowever, when you read those discussi ons you should realize it\'s quite \ndifficult to state exactly what I\'d do with a specific hand in a particular \nsituation. So many things are involved . No Limit Hold \'em is a very complex \ngame.  \nMost of the things I\'ll say will be an a ccurate reflection of what I\'d generally \ndo. But, I might do something else or  even something completely opposite \ndepending on who\'s in the pot with me and whether or not I have position on \nhim.  \nAlways remember ... No Limit Hold \'em is a game of position and people.   \nThere\'ll be a lot of times when only your good judgement will dictate the \nproper play. Situations will come up a ll the time when a hard and fast rule \nwill prove inadequate. Poker especially No Limit Hold \'em is not a game you \ncan learn to play well in "ten easy le ssons". A thousand hard lessons might \nnot be enough. There are simply too ma ny variables involved. Even the most \nsophisticated computer in the worl d would be unequal to the task.  \nNevertheless, the "lessons" you\'ll soon be learning will go a long way in \nhelping you to master No Limit Hold  \'em. The general principles and \nconcepts that I\'ll discuss about the play of specific hands will give you a far \ngreater command of the game than almost  all the players you could expect to \nbe competing with. I wish I knew all the general guidelines you\'ll soon be \nreading when I first started to play. It would\'ve made things a lot easier for \nme. That\'s for sure.  \nBut before I get into how you should (g enerally) play specific hands ... there \nshould be a discussion of the ante, betting structure, bankroll requirements \nand other considerations you\'ll have to make before you sit in on a No Limit \nHold \'em game. So that\'s what I\'ll do now.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 60}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter Three: \nThe Ante and Other Considerations  \nIf I had to choose a particular size game that would be close to "perfect" for \nNo Limit Hold \'em ... it would be nine handed. Of course, I\'m talking about a \nRing (full) game.  \nActually I prefer to play in a short handed game with about four or five \nplayers. The reason is that in a short handed game with a high ante you\'re \nforced to get in there and play. You ca n\'t just sit there and wait for the big \nPairs or Ace King or even small connecting cards. If you do..."you\'ll go like \nBroomcorn\'s uncle". So, a game like that suits my style just fine. It gives me \nplenty of room to muscle the game.  \nA "full" game with nine players is all right, too. That\'s just about the right \namount of players for a Ring game where there\'ll be good action. I mean, \nthere\'ll be people coming in the pots be cause they\'ll know they won\'t have to \nbe looking at the nuts every hand.  \nHowever, when that nine handed game all of a sudden turns into an eleven \nhanded game ... well, the complexion of  the game changes completely. What \nwas once a relatively fast and loose game becomes a thing of the past. The \nplayers no longer get in there and play  as often. The game begins to screw \ndown real tight.  \nThere\'s a lot more combinations out ever y hand with eleven players than with \nnine players. So everyone stops pl aying borderline hands and they start \nwaiting for the really good  ones. In short, they do n\'t do as much gambling ... \nso the action really dries up.  \nMany Poker games are like that and th ey stay like that unless "something" \nhappens to change the character of th e game. More than anything else, the \n"something" that\'ll change that tight game  back to the loose game it once was \nis for one of the players to start giving a lot of action. As I\'ve said ... that\'s \nwhat I do. I\'m known as an action player. It\'s an image I\'ve always had. \nBecause I give action…I get it.  \nI mean, I\'ll get into a Poker game and almo st from the very first hand I\'ll start \ngambling. I\'ll be taking chances... betting  ... raising ... re raising ... moving in. \nThat\'ll stir up a game real fast. One play er can do it. That\'s all it takes. And \nthat player\'s usually me.  \nI don\'t merely talk loose ... I prove I\'m loose by my actions. You know the old \ncliché: "a first impression is a lasting impression" . Well, that first impression I', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 61}),
 Document(page_content='create lasts throughout the session ... even though I might change gears  (go \nfrom loose to tight to loose) several times during the course of a game.  \nBeing able to adjust your playing speed  is a very important part of being a top \nplayer. There are a lot of reasons for this.  \n1. You never  want to get yourself stuck in an identifiable pattern. You \nmust mix up your play. If you do ... you\'ll always keep your opponents \nguessing.  \n2. As I said, you also want to create an image... the image of a loose, \ngambling type of player who gives a lot of action. But, it has to be the \nimage of a good loose player not th e image of a fool who\'s throwing a \nparty (giving his money away).  \n3. Since you\'ll most likely get off loser if you play as I recommend and \nstart plunging around  (playing very loose) almost as soon as you begin \nto play ... you\'ll have to gear down  (start playing tight) after you\'ve laid \nyour (image creating) groundwork. Then you\'ll start playing loose \nagain.. and you\'ll continue to vary your speed throughout the session.  \n4. You\'ll also want to adjust your speed to the varying speeds of \nparticular players. If there\'s a guy in the game who\'s speeding around  ... \nthen you do exactly the opposite by  gearing down - and remember to \nplay only solid hands against him. On  the other hand, if you notice that \na certain player is playing real ti ght... then you can start bluffing at \nhim.  \n5. The game itself might dictate the speed  at which you\'ll have to play. If \neveryone is playing real loose and all the pots are being jammed ... then you start playing real tight. Conversely, when the game\'s so tight you \ncan hear it squeaking ... you should pl ay loose and pick up all the pots \nyou can.  \n6. When players start dropping out of the game (and their seats remain \nvacant) ... you have to move into "high gear". As I said, you can\'t sit \nback and wait in a short handed game. If you do, the ante will get you \nbecause the good hands don\'t come often enough. So you must play ... \nor you might as well quit the game.  \n7. And, of course, there\'s the ante. That \'s the main thing that determines \nhow fast you play. Actually, the absolute size of the ante is not what\'s \nimportant. It\'s the relationship of the ante to the amount of money you \nhave. A $10 ante in a No Limit game would be quite high if all you had \nwas $500. But, if you had $5000 ... that $10 ante would be very low. In \nthe first (high ante) game ... you\'d have to play pretty fast. You could \nslow down considerably in the latter (low ante) game.  \nThe ante is such an important determinin g factor as to how fast you play that \nthe trouble  and trash  hands I later discuss would become big hands if you \nwere anteing high enough. In fact, that\'s  the case in the World Championship \nHold \'em Tournament because of the way it\'s structured. It starts with each', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 62}),
 Document(page_content='player anteing $10 and there\'s a $50 Blind.  According to a predetermined time \nschedule and, as players are eliminated  the ante and Blind get higher and \nhigher as the tournament progresses ... unt il it\'s down to the final two players. \nAt that point, each player antes $1000 an d blinds it for $2000. If you sit around \nand wait putting in that kind of mo ney every pot ... you\'ll go faster than \nBroomcorn\'s uncle.  \nYou\'ve got to play almost every hand when you\'re anteing that high. At the \nvery least, you\'ve got to see the Flop. So , it\'s really not all that surprising I \nwon the 1976 and 1977 World Championsh ips with "trash" hands. The only \nthing that is surprising is  that in both years the ha nds were almost identical.  \nIn 1976, when I won $220,000, the last po t had $176,000 in it. I won that pot \nwith the 1Os 2s. All it had on the Flop  was a Pair of Deuces ... but I caught \ntwo running Tens on Fourth and Fifth.  Jesse Alto (a very experienced non \nprofessional who owns an automobile de alership in Houston, Texas) was the \nman who came in second.  \nAs you know, in 1977, Bones was the young man who came in second to me. \n(He\'s a Pro who\'s now living in Las Vegas,  but is originally from Los Angeles, \nCalifornia.) In the last pot with Bones I had a 10d 2h and flopped a Pair of \nTens. This time, I caught a Deuce on Fo urth St. but I filled up with a Ten on \nthe end. That last pot was worth $130,000 and I won $340,000 in the 1977 \nTournament.  \nOf course, in a normal ante Ring game, it would be a rare case when I\'d play \nthose hands. There\'s little reason to when  the ante doesn\'t "force" you to play. \nA major exception would be when I play a pot for the sole reason of trying to \nsteal it. Then, it doesn\'t make any difference what I have. I mean, I could be \nplaying the hand without even looking at  my hole cards. At such a time, I\'d \nbe playing my money, my position and a particular player. My hand wouldn\'t \nmatter. If I was forced to look at it (b ecause I got played with), I might find \ntwo Aces, Ace King ... or trash.  \nYou\'ll almost surely have to get some No Limit experience under your belt \nbefore you\'ll be able to play a pot comp letely blind. So, in the beginning, I \nsuggest that you restrict the way you\'ll play specific hands to the \nrecommendations I\'ll soon be making. However, it\'s important for you to \nunderstand that those recommendations as to the hands you should play and \nthe way you should play them are what  I would do in a normal or medium \nante Ring (nine handed full) game. In a game different from that ... you\'ll have \nto adjust your play as previously discussed.  \nIn order to help you determine what  constitutes a normal (medium ante) \ngame, you should use the following table as a guide.  \nNine-Handed Game -- No Limit Hold\'em', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 63}),
 Document(page_content='*Twice the \nminimum  buy-ins listed here would be much  better. More than twice would \nbe better still.   \nIn the above table, the very low  ante game where each player antes $1 (with or \nwithout the Blind) would be approximat ely equivalent to the game with the \nmultiple Blinds of $1, $2 and $5. Assuming  there are nine players, it would \ncost you $9 a Round in the first case. (I t would be an additional $2 if each \nplayer had to take the Blind once a Roun d.) In the game with the three Blinds, \nit would only be $8 a Round. As you ca n see, it doesn\'t make much difference \nwhether everyone antes or the mult iple Blind structure is used.  \nSometimes, the game is structured where the "dealer" (Button)  and the first \nBlind have to blind it for an identica l amount. This would be the case when \nthe Blinds in the low ante game wer e $5, $5 and $10 instead of the $2, $5 and \n$10 seen in the table. Also, there are so me games that have four Blinds. The \neffect of that would be to move a game as classified in the table to a higher \nclassification. For example, a game with four Blinds of $5, $10, $25 and $50 \nwould be a high ante game...not a medium ante game.  \nOf course, all the terms in the table from very low  to very high  are applied to \nthe ante on an absolute  basis. That is, because of the antes, they would be \ncalled very small and very big No Limi t games, respectively. But, when you \nconsider the various games listed relative  to the minimum  buy ins in the \ntable ... there\'s actually very little di fference between them. (To get around the \ntable in each of the games shown, it\'ll cost you about 4% of your buy in if you \nsit down with an absolute minimum buy.)  \nYou wouldn\'t want to sit down with less than the minimum buys shown. As \nthe footnote states, you should definitely consider buying in for more.  \nWhen I play in a game with three Blinds of $25, $50 and $100...I never sit \ndown with less than $20,000. What\'s more  ... I like to have as much as (or \nmore money than) any other player at  the table. If my stacks are not \napproximately equal to the guy with th e most money then I couldn\'t break \nhim, could I?  \nAnd ... I practice what I preach. I start playing fast right away. I\'ve always \nplayed like that. Even when I was just starting out. Back then I\'d buy in for a \nthousand (in a small No Limit game) and I\'d usually get stuck (lose) that first', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 64}),
 Document(page_content='thousand. Then, I\'d pull up and start pl aying tighter and I almost always got \neven ... or won.  \nAbout three out of four plays, I\'d lose th at first thousand ... but, on that fourth \nplay, I\'d get on a rush (winning streak ) and I\'d more than make up for those \nfirst three losses. I mean, I\'d be playin g so fast and winning so many hands \nwhen I was rushing that I\'d literally break every player in the game. It\'s because whenever I hold a bunch of hands, I usually get action on them.  \nI\'ve never won a bunch of pots on the ba nk (watching the other guys play). If \nI\'m striking (making a bunch of hands) ... I\'m in there I\'m not on the side. If \nyou\'re going to have a rush…you\'ve got to let yourself have one.  You\'ve got \nto sustain that rush. And to do that, you\'ve got to get in there and play.  \nAfter I\'ve won a pot in No Limit ... I\'m in the next pot regardless of what \ntwo cards I pick up. And if I win that  one ... I\'m always in the next one. I \nkeep playing every pot until I lose on e. And, in all those pots, I gamble \nmore than I normally would.   \nIf you don\'t play that way ... you\'ll neve r have much of a rush. I know that \nscientists don\'t believe in rushes ... but they make about fifteen hundred a \nmonth. I\'ve played Poker for almost 25 years now ... and I\'ve made millions at \nit. A big part of my winnings came from playing my rushes.  \nThere\'s only one world class Poker player that I know of who doesn\'t believe \nin rushes. Well, he\'s wrong ... and so are the "scientists". Besides, how many of \nthem can play Poker anyway?  \nIf you want to take the money off ... I mean, make a big score ... then, you\'ve \ngot to play your rushes. It\'s that simple.  \nAt this point, you should have a very g ood feel for my style of play.
