It should \nhelp you to understand and appreciate the things I\'m going to say about the \nway I play specific hands ... from before  the Flop on through each stage of \nplay until all the cards are out.  \nIn all the situations that I\'ll shortly discuss, an important assumption  has \nbeen made. That is:  \nUnless otherwise noted, the way I\'d play  a specific hand at No Limit Hold \n\'em is how I\'d play it in a pot agains t other top Poker players ... and not the \nway I\'d play it against a weak player.   \nThe reason that assumption has been ma de is because, as you already know, \nagainst a weak player (or a drunk) you have to play quite differently. All you \ntry to do against a weak player is make  the best hand and then extract from \nhim the largest amount of money you can. Just outplay him.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 65}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter Three: \nBig Pairs (AA/KK) - How to Play \nSpecific Hands  \nAn important qualification you must be aware of before reading what follows \nis that the recommendations I make are how you should generally play the \nhands discussed That's the way I genera lly play them. But, you should never \nfall into a pattern playing Poker. I don't. I always vary my play ... I try to mix \nit up as much as I can. I never consis tently repeat my action on any hand. I \ndon't play like a computer that's programmed to do the same routine over \nand over again. The high quality of pl ayers I play against on a regular basis \nwould easily detect a pattern to my play  if there was any. So I never do the \nsame thing with the same hand from the same position against the same \nplayer. I'm always changing speeds during the course of a game.  \nHowever, for your purposes, my playing recommendations for a particular \nhand are a good way for you to play th em ... until your opponents learn your \nstyle. When they do ... you start shif ting gears up and down continuously \nuntil there is no noticeable pattern.  \nI'm going to break the game down in to four major - and very broad - \ncategories as follows:  \nI. PAIRS  \nII. SMALL CONNECTING CARDS  \nIII. BORDERLINE HANDS  \nIV. TRASH HANDS  \nHow to play your hand when you have a Pair in the pocket is going to be \ndiscussed first. That category will be sub divided and discussed as follows:  \na. Big Pairs A A, K K and A K  \nb. Q-Q  \nc. J J down to 2 2  \nI've grouped an Ace King with a Pair of Aces and a Pair of Kings because it's a \nvery strong hand. As you'll learn, I would rather have A K than A A or K K.  \nI'll discuss each of the hands as I'd play them in a nine handed game from an \nearly position (first three seats), middle position (next three seats) and late \nposition (last three seats). A medium ante game is assumed (unless otherwise \nnoted).  \nA A and K K how to play before the Flop", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 66}),
 Document(page_content="With a Pair of Aces or Kings in an e arly position before the Flop. . .I would \nprobably limp in with them (just call th e Blind) hoping that somebody would \nraise it behind me so I could re raise.  \nIn a middle position if nobody in the early seats came in I would play them \nthe same way. But, if somebody in the early seats did come in ... I'd put in a \nraise with them (of about the size of the pot).  \nIn a late position, I'd obviously raise with them and hope that somebody \ntrailed their hand around to me that is, slow-played their hand so they could \nre raise me. If they did I'd play back, of course, and might move in depending \non the circumstances. If I did play ba ck and got about half my money in the \npot before the Flop with two Aces or tw o kings ... there'd be no question that \nI'd get the rest of it in on the Flop  regardless of what came on the turn. \nNothing could stop me. If my opponent didn't set me in on the Flop ... I'd \nmove it all in myself. The reason I'd do that is because there are too many \nways I could outguess myself... and I'm not go ing to try. If I get either of those \nbig Pairs cracked ... well, I'm just go ing to have to lose my money.  \nConversely, a rare situation could exist where you'd consider throwing away \ntwo Kings before the Flop when you got raised. It's a hard hand to get away \nfrom…but if a real tight player moved in  on you a player you know to be so \ntight that he wouldn't make that kind  of play unless he had two Aces then, \nyou might want to throw them away. Of  course, you'd have to be almost \ncertain about your man before you'd do that. One way I make this rare \ndecision is to put myself in my opponent 's position. I ask myse lf if I'd re raise \n(if I were him) with two Queens (or less). If the answer is NO ... I'd throw the \ntwo Kings away.  \nI'm going to discuss how to play a big Pair  on the Flop in a moment. But, this \nis a good point to note that when you have two Kings and there's a single Ace \non the Flop ... it's complete judgement as  to whether or not you should go on \nwith your hand. If you put your opponent  on an Ace* ... that's the end of the \npot right there. If not ... you play your two Kings as if you had the best hand.  \nA A and K K how to play on the Flop   \nRegardless of the hand you have, the Fl op is where you'll make your most \ncrucial decisions. It's THE  key point in the hand. It's where you put people on \nhands ... decide what they've probably got. Usually, everything after the Flop \nis more or less cut and dried.  \n*There's a lot of very interesting facts on Hold 'em probabilities In the \nAppendix. Particularly relevant here are the following two facts:   \n1. In a nine handed game, when you have two Kings, the probability \nthat no other player has an Ace is about 20% ... or, a player will have", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 67}),
 Document(page_content='an Ace about 80% of the time. (See "Hold \'em Absence of Aces before \nthe Flop ... by numbers of players.\')  \n2. Also, an Ace (with two unpaired ca rds less then Kings) will flop \nabout 18% of the time. (See "Hold \'em Flops for selected hands: Selection B.\') \nOf course, you put people on hands befo re the Flop, too ... but, on the Flop, \nyou\'re in a much better position to dete rmine what a man probably has by the \nway he calls - whether he\'s drawing to a Straight or Flush and so forth.  \nI play a Pair of Aces or Kings very ca utiously from an early position when \nthere\'s three cards that\'ll make a Straight or a Flush on the Flop. This is \nespecially true if there are two or more  people in the pot with me. The guys \nthat called behind me are liable to have  anything. In that  position, they\'ve \neither got a hand that could break me ... or  I\'ll win a very small pot if I bet. So, \nin an early position, a bell rings (remindi ng me not to bet) when I see three to \na Straight or Flush on the Flop when I\' ve got Aces or King in the pocket. \nConsequently, I immediately start playing that hand slow ... and usually I just \ncheck in a front position.  \nNow, if I\'m in a late seat ... and somebo dy had trailed in in the early seats ... I \nmight go ahead and bet once. If I got called ... I would immediately become \ndefensive again with that hand. Anytime  there\'s three cards to a Straight or \nFlush, I play the hand with extreme caution.  \nThe quality of the possible Straight that\'s  out there also has a big influence on \nthe way I\'d play that big Pair. If it came 9 8 7, 10 9 8 or J 10 9 and I\'ve got two people in the pot with me...I immediat ely give it up. Almost any two cards \nthat those two people have will fit into those Flops somehow. They\'re either \ngoing to have a hand that\'s already go t me beat or they\'re going to have a \nhand to draw at that would make my hand no better than even money shot.  \nIf it comes 10 9 8 and one of them\'s got a Q J ... then, he\'s got the Straight \nmade. If he\'s got a J 10 ... then, he\'s got a Pair with an open end Straight draw. \nHe could catch a Seven, a Ten, a jack or a Queen. Anyone of those cards will \nbeat me. There are 13 of them* in the deck and he\'s got two shots at them. \nThat makes his hand as good as mine at  that point he\'s almost exactly even \nmoney to beat me so I don\'t want to pu t myself in jeopardy and get myself in \na position where I could get broke.  \n*4 Sevens, 4 Queens, 3 Jacks and 2 Tens.   \nI don\'t always give up the pot in that situation. I just play extremely \ncautiously. That is, I don\'t charge… an d try to win the pot right there.  \nIf just a J 10 falls say the Flop is a J 10 2 well, there I\'d really play my two Aces \nbecause any combination of big cards would give my opponent some kind of', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 68}),
 Document(page_content="hand. A King Queen will give him an open end Straight draw ... an A K will \ngive him two overcards and a belly Strai ght draw ... an A J, K J, Q J, A 10, Q \n10, or K 10 will give him a Pair so I'd go ahead and play my two Aces in that \nsituation. If he's got jacks and Tens (or better) ... well, more power to him \nbecause he's got a hand with which he can win a big pot from me.  \nIf you know your player ... you'll be able to figure out what hand he's likely to \nhave. You have to use common logic in putting your opponent on a hand.  \nI'm not as leery of a three card Flush on the Flop as I am a three card Straight. \nThere's not as many possible hands that could beat you ... although a guy \ncould have a Pair and a Flush draw  if he's in there with you.  \nThe first thing I'd do would be to see if  either one of my two Aces (or Kings) \nmatched the cards out there. If three Hearts fell ... and I had two red Aces ... I \nwould immediately play that hand. It's a big hand. But if I had the two black \nAces or didn't have the Ah ... I might be  a little more hesitant to play it.  \nAs I said, if I had the Ah ... I'd play the hand fast on the Flop. If I get called ... \nI'm in a position to win it anyw ay. I know where the nuts are.  \nThat's one of the most important thin gs about No Limit Hold 'em. If you \ncan avoid it ... you never want to get your money in dead.   \nYou don't want to he drawing for a Flus h when there's a Pair on the Board. A \nman could have a Full house. And, you don't want to be drawing to a Straight \nwhen another man could have a Flush.  If the Board comes three Hearts and \nyou've got an open end Straight draw yo u don't draw at that Straight. You \nthrow your hand away. All the top player s try to keep from ever getting their \nmoney in completely dead.  \nIf there's a Pair and a Rag on the Flop ... and I had a Pair of Aces or Kings in \nthe pocket ... I'd bet at that pot from an early position. If I got called ... then, \nI'd proceed cautiously. I mean, when the next card was turned ... I'd check it \nto him. If he bet ... maybe I'd call it or maybe I wouldn't. It would depend on \nwhat I felt that he had. I mean, I'd kn ow he's got something that he likes.  \nFor example, if the turn is 6 6 2 and I be t and he calls ... he's telling me he's got \nsome kind of hand. He's probably got a Pair in the pocket (anywhere from \nSevens to Tens) or else he's got a Six or 3 Deuces. So, I'd use my judgement at \nthat point ... and I'd be cautious again. If there were a couple of players in the \npot in front of me and one of them turn ed a Set (of Sixes) he'd probably check \nit to me. That's what most players do in  that situation. They check a Set into \nthe raiser. But, as you know, that's the wrong way to play it. A player would \nknow the right thing to do is to lead into you.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 69}),
 Document(page_content='If it was checked to me and there wasn\'t  a Straight draw on the Board (say the \nFlop was 7 7 2) I might check it also ... and give a free card. I\'d do that for two \nreasons:  \n1. If he didn\'t have a hand, I\'d want  him to help his hand enough to \ncontinue playing. For example, if a jack or Queen fell off on Fourth St., \nit might pair him.  \n2. Another reason I\'d check would be to  eliminate the possibility that I\'d \nget broke if he does have a Seven.  \nBut, if the Flop was 6 6 2 ... I would bet ... because I wouldn\'t want a Three, \nfour or Five falling off and making somebody a Straight.  \nIn brief ... you don\'t give free cards where that free card could break you. If \nthere\'s a possible Straight or Flush dr aw on Board ... you don\'t give a free \ncard.   \nA Flop that\'s 6 6 5 is a lot different (b ecause there\'s a Straight draw) than one \nthat\'s 6 6 K. If I had two Aces with th e latter Flop and it was checked to me ... \nI\'d probably check it back. If he\'s got a King ... he\'s going to play it on the \nTurn (Fourth St.) because you\'ve made hi m think he\'s got the best hand when \nyou check plus, if he does have a Six, as before, you might be able to hold \nyour losses to a minimum.  \nWhat it all boils down to  is that with a Pair of Aces or Kings ... you\'re \nwaiting until you get kind of a cinch hand before you really play a big pot. You\'re not looking to play a big po t where you might have only a small \npercentage the best of it or one where you\'re a big underdog.   \nIn general, with those big Pairs on the Flop ... you play them a little more \naggressively from a late position th an from an early position. Also, you \nshouldn\'t be concerned that someone migh t be checking the nuts to you (such \nas 3 Sixes in the examples used). Yo u never worry about that. I\'ve heard \npeople say: "Well, I was afraid to bet because I was afraid he\'d raise me." \nNever worry about getting raised. You ha ve to go ahead and play and if it \nhappens, it happens... and then you worry  about it. Don\'t cross that bridge \nuntil you come to it.  \nYou can\'t play winning Poker by playing safe all the time. You must take \nchances ... gamble. And you have to feel aggressive to play aggressively. \nThat\'s my style of Poker. An d it\'s a winning style.  \nI\'ve re stated my general philosophy of play at this point because I\'m \ndiscussing the play of a Pair of Aces or Kings in the hole. In most cases, I play \nthem slowly (not slow play them). That  is, I play them cautiously. This is \ncontrary (to my general style of play an d) to the way most people play them. \nMost players feel that they\'re so hard to  come by that when they do get them', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 70}),
 Document(page_content='they want to win a big pot with them. So they play them real fast. That\'s \nusually wrong. (But, there are exceptions I\'ll soon discuss.)  \nThe fact is, with a Pair of Aces or Kings ... one of two things will usually \nhappen. Either:  \n1. You\'ll win a small pot  \nor  \n2. You\'ll lose a big pot   \nThe reason the above is so is because a player is not going to get a lot of \nmoney in the pot unless he can beat your big Pair or when he has a Straight or \nFlush draw. In the latter case, as you\'ll soon see, I\'m going to make him pay to \ndraw to his hand.  \nAnother time I play two Aces or Kings sl owly is in the rare instance a Set of \nTrips flops say, 3 Sevens or 3 jacks. But, this time I do it for somewhat different reasons. Now ... I want someone in the pot with me to catch up \n(improve his hand). So I check it ... but,  just one time. I Want to give them a \nfree card so they can catch a Pair ... or  give them a chance to bluff at it.  \nIt\'s tough to win anything in that spot by leading off ... unless you catch \nsomebody with a Pair in the pocket.  \nOf course, there\'s a small chance you could run into a Set of Fours. But, \nanyone who made that hand will "let yo u know" they made it by the way they \nput all their money in the pot. It takes experience to recognize something like \nthat ... but it\'s just like any other situ ation where somebody\'s betting the pure \nnuts at you. You have to use judgement to evaluate it. After a while, you \nrecognize it. As always ... it boils back down to people.  \nThe one situation where I stand to lose a very big pot with a Pair of Aces (or \nKings) is when there\'s two to a Straig ht or Flush on the Flop. For example, \nthere\'s a J 10 2 out there. If somebody bet at me ... I\'d move in a lot of chips. I \ncould win the pot right there. If not ... th ey\'re really going to pay to draw to \ntheir hand. If I was first to act, I\'d check ... hoping I\'d get to raise it. (It\'s one of \nthe few times I check raise.)  \nIf I get called, I\'ll probably put my o pponent on a Straight (or Flush) draw. \nAnd, of course, on Fourth St. I\'ll go ahead and bet again if a Blank \n(meaningless card) fell.  \nAgain, a lot of judgement\'s involved ... because my opponent might have been \nfortunate enough to make some kind of  hand that would beat my two Aces', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 71}),
 Document(page_content='(such as Jacks and Tens). In that case, I\'d go ahead and pay him off... because, \nas I said earlier, I\'m not going to try to out guess myself.  \nIf the Board fell completely ragged, say a 10 6 5, I would bet from any \nposition. As in all the hands I discu ssed, there\'s always the chance that \nsomeone could\'ve turned a Set. But, agai n, I\'m going to cross that bridge if \nand when I come to it.  \nIn this situation, I\'d know if my big Pair was beat... especially if I had raised \nwith my hand from an early position  before the Flop. All good Hold \'em \nplayers would interpret that as a sign of strength. I mean, the first thing you \nusually give a man (credit for) when he raises (especially the weaker players) \nis a big Pair.  \nSo if it comes a 10 6 5 (and I had rais ed from an early position) ... the other \nplayers will think that I have a strong hand possibly a big Pair, which I\'ve \nactually got. Then ... when I bet on th e Flop and get raised by somebody in a \nlate position ... it gets back to people  again. You\'ve just got to know your \nplayers. He\'s representing to you that he can beat a big Pair. If he\'s a good, solid type player ... what else can he have besides a Set of Trips or, possibly, \nTwo Pair? So, you make up your mind ri ght there whether or not to go ahead \nwith your two Aces (or two Kings).  \nOf course, it\'s possible that he could have  a Pair of Queens or jacks in a back \nposition and didn\'t raise you before the Flop ... and, now, on the Flop \n(because he\'s got an overpair) he\'s decided to test you. Then, you might want \nto call his raise one time ... if it\'s not t oo big a bet. The next time, you check it \nto him and see what he does. If he bets again ... he\'s usually there.  \nUp to now, I\'ve discussed how I\'d play a Pair of Aces or Kings on the Flop \nassuming I didn\'t turn anything that helped my hand. Now, I\'ll discuss the \nsituations where I get some help.  \nIf I turn a Set ... I never slow play it (w ith the exception of a situation I\'ll soon \ndiscuss). I almost always come right ou t and bet ... and I don\'t make just a \nnominal bet. I make an extra large be t because the only way you\'ll win a big \npot is when somebody else turns some thing with you ... or puts you on a \nbluff…or tries to run you down. So ... I really come out smokin\' right there.  \nYou might remember the point I made e arlier that "when you have a Pair of \nAces and a single Ace flops (giving you a Set of Trips) ... there\'ll always be the \npossibility that the next card off coul d make someone a Straight". The reason \nwhy that\'s so can be seen in the examples below.  \nFLOP A', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 72}),
 Document(page_content="With a single Ace on the Flop and any card Five or under ... there's always a \ndraw to a Five high Straight. As in FLOP A ... if a Deuce, Trey or Five fell on \nFourth St. it could make someone a small Straight.  \nThe same thing applies whenever there' s a single Ace on the Flop with any \ncard Ten or above.  \nFLOP B   \n \nWith FLOP B ... a King, Queen or Ten on Fourth would mean someone might \nhave made an Ace high Straight.  \nIf there's no draw to a Straight that incl udes an Ace, then there'll be a draw to \na medium Straight because there'd have to be a two card combination of the \nother four cards ... namely, a Six, Seven, Eight or Nine (an example of which is \nbelow).  \nFLOP C   \n \nThe Straight possibility is more obviou s with something like FLOP C because \nthere are seven different Straights that can be made. (If anyone has a J 10, J 8, \n10 8, 10 6, 8 6, 8 5 or a 6 5 ... they could make  a Straight with the next card off.)  \nYou should always keep this interestin g discovery in mind whenever you see \nwhat appears to be a raggedy Flop with an Ace in it. The threat that someone \ncould make a Straight will always be present.  \nSo when you flop a Set of Aces, you i mmediately go to betting and you bet a \nlarge amount to prevent somebody from drawing at an inside Straight", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 73}),
 Document(page_content="cheaply. A good player will know it's worth it to take a cheap draw at a \nbellyStraight ... and, if he makes it, he can break you.  \nHowever, if you flop a Set with two Kings ... you could possibly give a free \ncard when it comes ragged where ther e's no Straight or Flush draw. For \nexample, say a K 8 2 falls. Now, you can give a card with that Flop because \nyou'd have the nuts if any card other than an Ace, Eight or Deuce fell. An Ace might give someone 3 Aces and an Eight or Deuce could possibly make \nsomeone Four of a kind. Since you don' t realistically worry about a Set of \nFours ... you really want an Eight or De uce to hit the Board on Fourth St.  \nIn the rare instance when you turn a Set of Fours (say, four Aces) you're \nhappy to have them ... but you really don't have a very profitable hand. \nYou've got the deck crippled. There's nothing left that your opponents can \nhave. (The situation illustrated is so rare  that you might not see four Aces get \nbeaten like that in a lifetime of playing Hold 'em.)  \nSo, when you turn a hand that big, you just have to check along and maybe \ntry to win a small bet on the end. Or if you're extremely fortunate you might get somebody to try to bluff at it. They just might try to pick up the pot by \nrepresenting your hand. You could get lucky that way. But, most of the time, \nyou just play it very slow and take  what you can get ... meaning that you \nalways bet on the end from any position.  \nAnother time I would almost always ch eck it is when I flopped the big Full \n(the highest possible Full House). And, that's what you would have with two \nAces if the Flop was A 3 3 or with two Kings if it came K 7 7.* You'd have \nsome leverage then so you could give them a free card. (There's an exception \nto giving a free card which I'll discuss sh ortly.) After you check it once ... you \nthen bet on Fourth ... hoping that  somebody hit something there.  \n*With an Ace (or Aces) on the Board you might not have the big Full with a \nPair of Kings.   \nWhenever you've got a hand that's so big you've got the deck crippled or one \nthat's very unlikely to get beaten ... you should play it very slow on the Flop \nfor two reasons:  \n1. First, you want to give your opponents a chance to bluff; and  \n2. You want to give them a chance to catch something if they don't \nbluff.   \nWith a Pair of Aces or Kings, there's a chance you could flop a Straight or \nFlush draw. It would almost always be a gutshot Straight draw (with the \nexception of a Q J 10 when you had Kings). In any case, if I flopped a Straight \ndraw, I'd be cautious with my hand. You're probably beat at that point", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 74}),
 Document(page_content="because any Flop that would give you a Straight draw could easily make your \nopponent Two Pair. I wouldn't fool with that hand.  \nBut, if I've got the two red Aces and three Diamonds flop ... well, as I noted \nearlier, that's a very big hand. I'd play  that hand from the hip ... and I'd be \nwilling to put all my money in with it.  \nYou should always remember that the Flop is practically the whole game in \nHold 'em. That's where your major decisions will be made. The play on \nFourth St. and Fifth St. is pretty basic.   \nFor example, on the Flop, you put your opponent(s) on a particular hand. \nAnd, all your thinking follows from that . If you think he's drawing at a Club \nFlush ... you bet. You must make your o pponents pay to make their draws. If \nthe Club doesn't come on Fourth St. you bet again. Obviously, if the Club \ncomes ... you check it if you think your opponent made his hand.  \nIf you think you're beat, naturally, you check it ... and if you think your \nopponent's drawing ... you bet. That's the whole thing.   \nOn the end (Fifth St.), if it looks li ke your opponent has missed his hand ... \nthere's usually no reason to bet any further. So you just show your hand over. \n. or you check it and give him a chance to bluff.  \nThat's No Limit Hold 'em in a nutshell. ...but, as you know, it's a far more \ncomplex game than that.  \nA-A and K-K: How to play on Fourth and Fifth   \nSo far I've given you general  guidelines on how to play a Pair of Aces or \nKings before and on the Flop. I'll cont inue to discuss the play of those big \nPairs in the latter stages of action (Fourth and Fifth Sts.). Later, I'll also discuss \nhow I'd play various other hands at the different betting points.  \nBut, when you read the discussions you  should always be aware that my \nadvice is of a general nature. I keep re emphasizing this because it's so important that you understand it. There's not a single play I make that's of an absolute nature. I mean ... there's no  play that I'll make with a particular \nhand. Every hand I play is subject to be played differently depending on the circumstances at the time. The standards I have the ones you've read \n(and will read) generally guide me (as they should you). But, sometimes, \neven I don't know exactly what I'm goi ng to do until the situation comes \nup. Whatever my first feeling (impression) is at the time I'd go with that.   \nFor example, I said I'd check my Pair of  Aces (one time) if there was an open \nSet of Trips on the Flop. On Fourth St., if a man made a big bet or if I bet and \nhe moved in on me ... I'd probably go ahead and pay him off. If a man's lucky \nenough to flop a Set of Fours when I've  got two Aces ... he'd have to show me \nthe fourth one unless I've got a lot of mo ney in front of me and there's not too \nmuch money in the pot.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 75}),
 Document(page_content="I'll put some numbers on what I'm talk ing about so it'll be more clearly \ndefined. However, even what I say now I might not do (or do just the \nopposite) at a particular time. It would depend. On a lot of things. Especially \nthe guy in the pot with me. What do I know about him? So it's back to people \nagain. Nevertheless, here's what I might  do.  \nLet's say there's $20,000 in the pot. I've got $70,000 on the table. My \nopponent's got $20,000 ... and he moves in on me. In that case, I'd probably \npay him off ... if I knew him to be a Player (as opposed to a Rock). However, if \nmy opponent also had $70,000 and overbet the pot by moving in his entire \nstack ... well, then I'm not sure what I'd do. As I said, I'd go with my feelings. \nI'd look at him ... and then I'd decide.  \nTo start with ... if he made a move like th at ... I'd turn my hand face up on the \nBoard. And I'd watch him real close. I'd want to see what his reaction was \nwhen I turned the two Aces up. It woul d take a strong man not to show some \nkind of emotion. And from the emotion I saw, I'd judge whether he had a Set \nof Fours or not. Then I'd react according to whichever way I felt.  \nAs I noted, you continue to bet your big Pair on Fourth St. when it rags off \nand it doesn't look like it completed th e Straight or Flush draw that showed \non the Flop. If your opponent(s) want to  draw again ... you make them pay for \nit.  \nIn the situation where you flopped a Set,  you should also continue to bet on \nFourth even if it does look like some one could've completed a Straight. You \ncan't worry about it because you don't know  which Straight it is (and if it was \nmade at all). Just disregard any Straight card ... and go ahead and bet.  \nBut, if a third Flush card fell on Fourth ... then I'd probably check it. If \nsomeone bet ... I'd call it. I'd be thinking that I was probably beat ... but I'd be \ntrying to make a Full. I mean, I wouldn't  know for sure that I was beat ... but \nI'd call knowing there was a strong possibility I was. And I'd call a pretty big \nbet.  \nIf the man moved all in on me in that sp ot, I'd probably give him credit for the \nFlush. Then it would be simple ma thematics whether or not a call was \njustified. There'd be ten cards out of the 45 left that would help my hand.* \nThat means it's 35 to 10 (or 31/2 to 1) that I don't improve my hand. If the \npot's laying me more than 3 1/2 to 1 ... I'd call. If not ... I'd throw my hand \naway.  \nOf course, the above math only applies wh en you feel very strongly that your \nopponent has the Flush made. If you thought you could have the hand wrong \nwhere the man might have the second (h ighest) Set of Trips (or some other \nhand) then, you might call if the pot was laying you only 3 to 1. You could \naccept a smaller price because you have some doubts.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 76}),
 Document(page_content="So much depends on your judgement in si tuations like that. This is especially \ntrue on the end (Fifth St.). If I didn 't make my Full there ... it would be \ncomplete judgement if I was fo rced to call another bet.  \n*The case (last) Ace is assumed to be still In the deck and so are three each \nof the other three cards on the Board that could pair and make my Full.   \nWhen I discussed how I'd play my big Pair when I flopped a Full , I said I'd \nalmost always check it. The exception wo uld be when two of the cards on the \nFlop were suited (or maybe even two to a Straight). In that case, I would not \ncheck on the Flop. I would bet. I'd be trying to get a man in there drawing to a \nFlush and hoping that he'd make it so I could break him. And, if a Flush card \ndid come on Fourth St. I'd make a big bet ... expecting to be raised ... hoping to \nbe raised.  \nI'd play the hand similarly if I had flopped a Set and the Board paired on the \nend making my Full and at the same time making a possible Flush for \nsomebody. Whenever you've got a Full and a three Flush comes, it's exactly \nthe situation you're looking for. You go ahead and bet even an extraordinarily \nbig bet and you can break your opponent. (You should not, by the way, bet as \nmuch with a three card Straight out there because your opponent may not \nhave the nut Straight. He may even be drawing. So, in either case, if you've \ngot him dead ... you'd want him to play his Straight if he made it or you want \nhim to draw at it ... and a very big bet might scare him off.)  \nIn the case where you flopped a Set and the Board pairs on Fourth or Fifth ... \nbut there's no possible Straight or Flush out there (say the Board is As, 6h Jc \nJd) ... you should lead with your Full. Do n't slow play it. In fact, you should \nmake a big bet (bigger than the size of the pot).  \nThere's a good possibility that your opponent was calling you on the Flop \nwith the Second Button (or possibly th e Third Button). So, when the Board \npaired, it might've made him a strong hand… and you'd be in a position to \nbreak him. He'd probably play back if he made Trips when the Board paired. \nAlso, knowing your aggressive style of play, he might think you're trying to \nrepresent his hand ... and you might get a good play because of that.  \nBut, if a Flush draw was out there on the Flop and the Pair on Fourth didn't \ncomplete the Flush ... well, then I'd make a small bet (smaller than the size of \nthe pot). I want him to call so he'd have  an opportunity to make the Flush on \nthe last card.  \nThe situations I've been discussing are  those where you've made a very big \nhand with your two Aces or Kings ... an d the way you should play it in order \nto extract the most you can from your opponent(s). It's more likely that you \nwon't make a big hand and will have to play a Pair of Aces or Kings very \ncarefully in certain instances on Fourth and Fifth Sts.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 77}),
 Document(page_content="For example, if there were three Rags on  the Flop and then the Board paired \non Fourth or Fifth ... I'd definitely slow down. This is not the same situation as \nwhen a Pair came on the Flop. When  the Pair shows after the Flop, the \npossibility is much stronger that it help ed your opponent there. He's already \ncalled you on the Flop ... indicating that his cards fit into the community \ncards. His call clearly meant that he ha d something a Pair or some kind of \ndraw. So, I'd be cautious again in that situation.  \nIt's a somewhat different situation when  there are four Rags out there and the \nBoard pairs on Fifth St. Exactly what I'd do would depend on whether I bet \nthe two previous times (on the Flop an d on Fourth) ... and on which card was \npaired. If the top card (and possibly the second card) paired ... I'd suspect I \nmight be beat. They'd be the two most da ngerous Pairs. If the Third, or Fourth \nButton paired ... I wouldn't be concerned if I had bet on the Flop and on \nFourth St.  \nAnother time you should not be at all concerned is when the Flop is, say, 8 8 5 \nand then the third Eight falls on Fourth  (or on the end). You just don't worry \nabout a Set of Fours ... so actually your hand got stronger on Fourth St. Before \nthe third Eight showed, there was the nagging possibility your opponent had \nTrips. That's far less likely now ... and he 's probably in there with an overpair.  \nA very tough situation could exist on Fi fth when there's four to a Flush (or \nStraight)...and you don't have any of it. With  a big Pair in that spot, it's back to \njudgement again. You have to evaluate  what you think your opponent was \ndrawing at ... and whether or not he's  got one of the cards that would \ncomplete the Straight or Flush.  \nYou should never bet in that situation. If he's first and he checks ... you just \nshow it down. If you were first, you'd ch eck it. If he bet ... well, you're back to \npeople. You'd just have to evaluate your player.  \nThat situation brings to mind a play I often make. I've play ed a lot of pots \nagainst tight players when I've made a very weak call on Fourth St. hoping \nthe last card will make a four card St raight or Flush on the Board so I could \nrepresent the Straight or Flush by making  a big bet. For example, my (tight) \nopponent has raised before the Flop and I feel he has a big Pair in the pocket. \nThe situation might look like this:", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 78}),
 Document(page_content="My opponent bets on the Flop and I call.  The next card is the 2d and if my \nopponent bets again, I'll call not because I think I have the best hand ... but \nbecause of the tremendous bl uffing opportunity I'll have if the last card is a 3, \n4, 8 or 9. Either one of those four cards will mean the Board is one card off of a \nStraight. I'll almost certainly win the pot if I make a substantial bet on the end \n(representing the Straight) if, as in the example, a Four fell on Fifth. I might \nalso catch a Ten or Seven on the end. I'd win a nice pot in that case, too ... so \nI'm justified in calling on Fourth St. I do a lot of gambling like that on Fourth \nand on the end. And they're good ga mbles because I know a tight player \nwouldn't jeopardize all his money when one card would beat him.  \nIt's not only tough for a tight player to make a call for all his money in a \nsituation like that ... it's tough for anyo ne to do it. But, if you know your \nplayer ... it does make it easier. If the Straight or Flush is a back door job \n(made on Fourth and Fifth Sts.), then yo u may want to reconstruct the play of \nthe entire hand and try to determine wh ether it's logical that that particular \nplayer would go as far as he did to make the hand. Of course, a lot of times a \nplayer will literally back into a hand like that. For example, he may have \nstarted with a small pair on the Flop and he might have picked up a Straight \nor Flush draw on Fourth. And he got th ere on the end without really trying.  \nWith two Aces or Kings, you're going to  have to use a lot of judgement when \nall the cards are out and your hand never got better. You'd have to go back to \nwhat you originally felt your opponent  was drawing at on the Flop and on \nFourth St. If you thought he made what he was drawing at on the last card ... \nwell, obviously, you'd check it whether you were first or last to act. If you \nthought he was drawing at a hand an d completely missed it ... and you were \nfirst you'd still check. But, this time , you'd be doing it to give him an \nopportunity to bluff at it. If you were last and it looked like he missed his \nhand and he checked it to you ... you'd just turn your hand over to avoid \nbeing wrong in your judgement. He's not going to call you if he missed his \ndraw. But, if you put him on the wron g hand to begin with ... you could get \nraised.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 79}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter Three: \nA-K How to play before the Flop  \nI\'ve already mentioned that I\'d rather have  Ace King than either a Pair of Aces \nor a Pair of Kings. A lot of players will probably find that surprising. But it\'s \nnot. You\'ll soon see why.  \nOf course, I know that an A K would ne ver outrun A A or K K if you played \nthem against one another hot and cold. An  A K couldn\'t even beat a Pair of \nDeuces. I know. On a proposition bet, I once took the Deuces and two other \nguys took the A K. The proposition was to play the two hands against one \nanother hot and cold. We simply dealt ou t five cards to see which hand would \nwin more times. It was an even money proposition ... and we bet $500 a hand. \nI won several thousand dollars before they quit.  \nThey weren\'t convinced the first time because we did it two or three different \ntimes. They\'d lose some money...and th en they\'d quit. They\'d go away ... \nCome back (after doing some "homework")  and then we\'d do it again. And I\'d \nbeat them again.  \nBut, I\'m not talking about playing hot and cold  here. Now ... I\'m talking about \nplaying Poker.  \nAn A K is a "better" hand than two Ac es or two Kings for two very important \nreasons:  \n1. You\'ll win more money when you make a hand with it; and  \n2. You\'ll lose less money when you miss a hand with it. \nAnd I can\'t think of two better reasons th an those to prefer an A K over the \nvery big Pairs.  \nThe reason why you can make more mone y with an A K than with two Aces \n(or Kings) is because it\'s a drawing type of hand as opposed to a made hand. I \nmean, you don\'t have anything with an  A K unless you flop something. So \nyou can get away from it real easy. You\'r e not tied on to it like you might be \nwith a Pair of Aces (or Kings). And that \'s why you\'ll lose less money with it.  \nAnother reason why you can make more and lose less with A K than with the \nvery big Pairs is because when you have A K and you pair the Ace or King on \nthe Flop ... it\'s much harder for your opponent to make his hand if he\'s \nplaying something like two connecting cards. For example, if someone\'s \nplaying a 7 6 and the Board comes A 9 8, he hasn\'t made anything \nyet...because when you pair one of your hole cards there can be only two \ncards that\'ll help him.* But, if you had two Aces in the pocket ... the Board', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 80}),
 Document(page_content="could come 9 8 5 or any three cards that could help his hand (such as a Pair \nand a draw). That one extra card considerably improves his chances of \ncracking your Aces.  \n*The exception to this would be when the Flop is three to a big Straight \nwith maybe two to a Flush, like: As Jh 10s or Kd Jd 10c ... and the Ace or King helps both you and your opponent.   \nAce King is also a more flexible hand (in the way you can play it) as you'll \nsoon see.   \nThere's also a big difference between A K suited and A K offsuit. (Any time \nthe cards are suited it's a somewhat stro nger hand than when they're offsuit. \nThis is especially true with A K because you can make the nut Flush.) The big \ndifference between the two hands is that it only takes three cards to make a \nFlush with A K suited. True, you can make one of two Flushes with A K offsuit ... but it takes four cards to make either one. That's a lot harder to do. \nAnd, with one of them (the Flush yo u might make with the King), you may \nnot have the nuts.  \nIn the discussion to follow, the difference between the two hands is \nsometimes ignored. That is, I'm going  to suggest playing them the same \nway. But, you should always remember that A K suited has more value than \nA K offsuit...and it can always be played a little stronger.   \nThe reason why A K is more flexible than A A or K K is because you can play \nan A K in the lead or you can play it sl ow to raise with it. Also, I'd play A K \nfrom any position for a reasonable size bet. And, on occasion, I'd get all my \nmoney in before the Flop (as I'll very shortly discuss).  \nSpecifically, in an early position, I'd brin g it in (raise the Blind) for whatever \nthe normal bring in was for that partic ular game. If I was raised, I'd probably \ncall ... although I don't like to call a raise  with A K (as most players do). I like \nto raise with it.  \nIf I was in a middle position and someon e else had brought it in...I'd just call \nwith it. I wouldn't raise because I'd probably be raising just one man. I'd want \nat least another player to come in.  \nIn a late position, I'd probably raise with  it especially if I was on the Button.  \nThere are times I might even move all in with an A K. Let's say I brought it in \nin an early position and a couple of peop le behind me just called. When it gets \nto the guy on the Button...he raises. We ll ... if he did that, I'd think he was \ntrying to pick up the pot since he'd pr obably think the only person he had to \ncome through (worry about) was me si nce the two people behind me showed \nweakness. So I might move in in that situation.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 81}),
 Document(page_content='Or, if I was on the Button, and three or four people were already in the pot ... I \nmight move all in. At that point, I\'d be trying to pick the pot up ... even \nthough I\'d know if I got called I\'d probably be an underdog.  \nA K how to play on the Flop  \nAs long as I don\'t help my A K on th e Flop, I\'m going to play the hand the \nsame way ... regardless of whether or not the Flop might\'ve helped someone \nelse. For example, if three Rags flopped ... or a Pair ... or three to a Straight or \nFlush ... or anything that did not help my hand the way I play A K is quite \nsimple. Barring the exception I\'ll s oon note, here\'s what I\'d do.  \nIf I was the bettor to start with ... or if I was the raiser I\'d bet from any \nposition. If I called with A K I\'d check ... or if there was a bet in front of me \nI\'d pass.   \nAs I\'ve already said, I play (almost) a ll my hands that way because if I was the \nbettor or raiser before the Flop then I\'ve  represented a hand. So, I\'ll bet on the \nFlop regardless of what comes. I\'ll do it nine times out of ten.  \nYou might have noticed that this is qu ite different from the way I\'d play two \nAces or two Kings. With either of those Pairs in an early position, I\'d cheek it \nif there were three to a Straight or Flus h on the Turn. Remember ... I "hear" a \nbell ringing in that situation that reminds me not to bet. So, if I\'ve got a hand \n(a Pair in the pocket) ... I play it slow. But, if I\'m bluffing ... I go ahead and \nplay it fast. I mean ... I\'ll take one shot at it.  \nThe reason I do that is because I know for sure I\'m not going to go any further \nwith an A K if somebody plays back at  me. With two Aces or two Kings if \nsomebody plays back it puts me to a de cision. But, when I have nothing, I can \nbet A K with confidence because I\'m gone if I get raised. I just throw my hand \naway because there\'s nothing for me to think about. Now you can see why \nyou\'re less likely to lose a big pot with A K than with two Aces or two Kings.  \nWhen I do go ahead and play the hand  (when there\'s nothing on the Flop \nthat\'ll help me), I\'ll make a reasonable  bet somewhere in the neighborhood of \nthe size of the pot. But, as always, there are exceptions. In an unusual \nsituation, I\'d revert back to the same philosophy I use with Aces and Kings. \nFor example, if the Fall was a Jh 10h 9h ... I\'d never bluff. I wouldn\'t even fool \nwith the pot if only two of those c ards were suited. You know somebody\'s \ngoing to have something. Here again, yo u have to use your judgement. It\'s an \nextreme situation.  \nThat also explains why I\'ll bet on the Flop 90% of the time (and not all the \ntime) if I played my hand strong befo re the Flop. There are times when you \nknow somebody must have flopped some thing. And bluffing at a pot in that \nsituation will rarely succeed. So you just give it up.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 82}),
 Document(page_content="If I get some help on the Flop (by catching an Ace or a King), I'd make a \nreasonable bet at the pot from any posi tion. The only time I might check raise \nin this situation is when I had called in a middle position before the Flop and \nthe original raiser (before the Flop) was behind me.  \nWhen someone plays back at me in the above situation  \nI'll either move in or release my hand. It would depend on what flopped. In \norder for me to move in ... I'd have to  put my opponent on a hand where I \nthought he was drawing, For example, if the Turn came Ac 10h 9h. I'd put \nhim on a Flush draw (or maybe a Straight draw) and I'd move in. On the \nother hand, if it came off ragged like a Kh 8s 2d ... I might release my A K. My \nthinking would be that he possibly turned a Set and I might give up.  \nBy the way, in the first situation (when the Flop was Ac 10h 9h) a man \ncould've turned 3 Nines and he'd be in an  ideal position to win a lot of money. \nIt would look to me like he was drawin g at a Straight or a Flush (or both) and \nif he was lucky enough to have turned a Set ... well, there's nothing magical I \ncould do. I'd just have to go ahead and pay him off.  \nIf a Pair of Aces or a Pair of Kings flopped (giving me Trips) and the other \ncard is not one that'll give someone a Straight or Flush draw I might check \nraise with my hand, but I probably wouldn 't because I like to lead with it. It's \na very strong hand and as long as a Pat hand (a Straight or Flush) can't be \ndealt off on the next card ... you migh t want to give a free card in that \nsituation so your opponent(s) would ha ve a chance to make something on \nFourth St. But, you'd only give a free c ard if you were last to act. If you were \nfirst to act ... you wouldn't. You should lead with that hand. If you turned \nTwo Pair (Aces and Kings) ... you'd play th em almost identically to Trips. It's \nalmost the same hand.  \nThe important thing to remember is th at anytime there's a possible draw on \nthe Flop ... you should almost never check you should almost always bet.   \nIn the extremely rare case when you turn a Set of Fours ... you don't have any \nalternative. There's nothing else left ... so you have to check it. If you bet you \ncould catch a man with a Pair of Queens or jacks and he might accidentally \npay you off. But, realistically, you check it and hope that a Ten, Jack or Queen \nwill fall on Fourth St. and pair some one...and then you bet hoping someone \nwill call you with a full.  \nIf a Q J 10  flopped (giving me the nut Straight) ... I'd lead again if I was the \nraiser. Only this time it would not be  a reasonable bet. It would be an \nabnormal size bet.  \nI'd overbet the pot when that Turn came because somebody figures to have \nmade something. They could've made a smaller Straight ... possibly Trips ... or \nTwo Pair ... or a Pair and a Straight draw. That's the type of hand most", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 83}),
 Document(page_content="players move in with. So, you'd probab ly get him to bet all his money.. and \nhe'd be almost dead.  \nIf I was a caller (before the Flop) ... I'd al so raise it with A K. I wouldn't slow \nplay it. I'd raise because the original raiser figures to have a hand that would \nfit that Flop ( Q J 10 ). He could have two Aces or two Kings ... or he might \nhave 3 Queens or 3 Jacks ... or a Pair of Queens with an Ace or King kicker. He'd be subject to go all the way (to Fift h St.) if he had any one of those hands \n... and he'd get all his chips in the middle.  \nWhen the Flop came like a J 10 2  where I'd have a belly Straight draw and two \novercards with an A K ... I'd call a reasonab le bet. I'd really be trying to catch a \nQueen ... because if I caught an Ace or Ki ng, I'd have to be careful with it. It \nmight've made someone else a stronger  hand than my own say a Straight or \nTwo Pair.  \nBut, if you flop two of your Flush cards when you have A K suited ... you'll \nhave a very powerful hand. At that poin t, you'll be a favorite over any other \noverpair with the exception of a Pair of Aces or Kings.  \nI'll lead with that hand, of course, and I'd also lead off and bet if I actually \nturned a Flush with A K suited. You sh ould not check raise with your Flush \nbecause your opponent doesn't figure to have made much on the Flop. But, he \nmight call you with one Pair ... or he mi ght accidentally have a small Flush. \nIt's also possible he'd think you were d rawing to a Flush especially if you're \nan aggressive player and he might call you all the way through with just one \nPair.  \nA-K how to play on Fourth and Fifth  \nThe way you'd play A K on Fourth and Fi fth Sts. (if you made a Pair on the \nFlop) is almost the same way you'd play a Pair of Aces or Kings in the pocket. \nIf you think your opponent made the ha nd he was drawing at ... you check. If \nyou don't think he made it ... you bet.  \nThe only exception would be when you thought you had a man out kicked. \nThat is, you might keep betting with A K if you put your opponent on a hand \nthat's a little bit worse than yours. For example, you think he might've paired \nAces (or Kings) with you ... but, he's go t a smaller kicker. In this case, you'd \ntry to sell your hand (bet the maxi mum amount you think he'll call). You \nwouldn't try as hard to sell a Pair of Ac es (or Kings) in the pocket because he \nmight've been drawing to beat them. With A K, however, there's a good \nchance he's got the top card (an Ace or King) paired with you ... but your \nsidecard (kicker) is higher.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 84}),
 Document(page_content="The important point to remember when you have A K is that it's a drawing \ntype hand where A A (or K K) isn't. It's  therefore a much easier hand to get \naway from than the very big Pairs.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 85}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter Three: \nHow to Play a Pair of Queens  \nI've put a Pair of Queens in a separate ca tegory for the simple reason that it's a \nparticular hand that deserves special treatment. You'll soon see why.  \nWhen I get two Queens in the pocket ... I play them very carefully. I try not to \nplay them too strongly from any posi tion. Unless a good situation arises ... I \ndon't want to move in befo re the Turn with two Queens. By a good situation, I \nmean that I'm in a very late position (possibly on the Button) and four people \nhave called a raise in front of me. Here, I might try to shut them out by \nmoving in. I'd be using the combined st rength of my pair of Queens and my \nposition.  \nIf you're up against two Aces or two Kings with a Pair of Queens ... you're \nabout a 41/2 to 1 underdog. And, if you're up against A K ... you're only a \nlittle better than a 6 to 5 favorite. When people go all in before the Flop...they \nusually have one of those three or four hands.  \nSo, your money's in a lot of jeopardy wh en you get it all in before the Turn \nwith two Queens. If you get called, you'll usually be up against A A, K K or A \nK ... in which case you'll be a big dog or just a small favorite. You can pick a \nbetter spot than that to get all your money in.  \nThat's not to say two Queens don't have a certain amount of value. They do. \nThey're a considerably better than ave rage hand. But, for the reason I just \nmentioned, I seldom raise back with a Pair of Queens from any position ... \nunless it's an unusual situation.  \nBut, I will raise (the Blind) a reason able amount with two Queens from any \nposition if nobody else raised in front of me.  \nIn a middle position, if somebody raised in front of me ... I'd just call as I \nwould with any Pair. I'd just call with th em in a late position, too. I wouldn't \nre raise (except as I mentioned).  \nI also play two Queens very slow on the Flop. Whenever I play them ... I'm \nreally trying to catch a third Queen.  \nIf either an Ace or a King came on the Flop ... I'd play the hand as slowly as \npossible. If anybody bet with any degr ee of authority ... I'd probably give \nthem the pot.  \nAs long as an Ace or King didn't fall ... I'd play two Queens almost exactly the \nway I'd play two Aces or two Kings and that includes the pl ay on Fourth and", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 86}),
 Document(page_content="Fifth Sts., too. So, you might want to re  read the way I'd play those two hands. \nExcluding the times when there's an Ace or  King on the Flop, the only time I'd \nplay Queens differently from two Aces or Kings is when there's a Flush draw \non the Flop. In that case, I wouldn't be eager to get all my money in. A man \nwith a Flush draw could also have an overcard (an Ace or King). If he did ... it \nwould make his hand practically as st rong as mine. Whereas, if I had two \nAces or two Kings against only a Flush draw I'd be about a 9 to 5 favorite.  \nKeeping these differences in mind, yo u can play two Queens on the Flop, \nFourth and Fifth as if they were Aces or Kings. In fact, I play all Pairs in the \npocket in very much the same way ... as you'll now see.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 87}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter Three: \nHow to Play Any Pair other than Aces, \nKings or Queens  \nI'm going to call all the Pairs from Jack s down to Deuces a small Pair (except \nwhen I name a particular Pair). However, it's obvious that the bigger the Pair \nis ... the more valuable it is. And that  principle extends all the way down to \nthe very small Pairs. That is, a Pair of Fours is better than a Pair of Treys for \nthe simple reason that when the Flop is  4-3-2, if someone turned 3-Fours he'd \nbe a huge favorite (about 22 to 1) over someone who turned 3-Treys.  \nI also have a breaking-point that I use in  my play with a Pair of Jacks, Tens \nand Nines. I mentally segregate them from the other small Pairs and I play \nthem a little stronger than the others. I do it simply because they're bigger \nPairs and it's pretty easy for three Rags to fall. When that happens ... you'll \nhave an overpair. But, if you've got two Fives or two Sixes, it's hard for a Turn \nto come without there being at least one overcard. And, with an overcard out \nthere, your hand is kind of dead so you don't want to get too much money \ninvolved.  \nProgressively, then, each Pair is a little  bit better than the others ... but I \nplay them all as if they were a small Pair.   \nBefore the Flop, with any of the small Pairs (except Jacks, Tens and Nines) ... \nI'd limp-in (call the Blind). If somebo dy raised it from an early or middle \nposition ... I'd call it. I wouldn't re-raise.  \nI'd almost always take a Turn with any sm all Pair. I'd be trying to turn a Set \nso I could break somebody.   \nWith a Pair of Jacks, Tens or Nines ... if somebody raised from an early \nposition, I'd probably just call. But, if it was raised from a middle or late \nposition ... I might re-raise with two Jacks,  Tens or Nines if I felt the raiser was \nweak.  \nThe reason I might do that is because (as I noted) the probability is good I'll \nhave an overpair on the Flop. In that ca se, I'd play the jacks just like I'd play \ntwo Queens. The same strategy would apply.  \nHowever, I want to note a very unusual exception I make in a special \nsituation.  \nOne of the reasons I like to play the sm all Pairs from any position is because \nthey give me an opportunity to  slow-down and not appear to be", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 88}),
 Document(page_content='overbearingly aggressive when it might work against me. They also give me a \nchance to show a little respect for a particular opponent.  \nAs you know, if I raise a pot before th e Turn ... I\'m going to bet on the Flop \n(whatever it is) about 90% of the ti me. So, if I raised the pot with two \nNines...I\'d bet on the Flop nine times out of ten.  \nBut, let\'s say I\'m in the pot with a gu y I\'ve been pounding on and pounding \non all night long. And that guy\'s a real  good player who I know is getting \nvery tired of me pounding on him. I also know I\'ve probably got him beat, \nBut, rather than bet him out of the po t, I\'m going to purposely slow-down \nagainst him. An example will best show  you what I mean and I\'ll explain why \nI do it.  \nLet\'s say I raised him with two Nines before the Flop. He calls. The Turn \ncomes 10-2-3 and he checks it. I check al ong. Another Rag falls off on Fourth \nSt. He checks again. Now, I\'m reasonably sure my two Nines are the best \nhand. But, I\'m not going to bet it. I\'ll check along with him to show him some \nrespect. The Board\'s awful looking and I\' m pretty sure he doesn\'t have any of \nit. I\'m also quite sure that if I bet I\'m not going to get called. So I don\'t bet.  \nIt has nothing to do with feeling so rry for the man ... because if I thought \nthere was a good chance he\'d call me, I\'d surely bet. But, instead of pushing him out of the pot once more and getting  him hotter (angrier) than he is ... I \ncheck along with him to cool him off a little.  \nRemember ... he\'s a real good player. An d, although I\'m quite sure he won\'t \ncall me ... I\'m not so sure he won\'t pl ay-back and put pressure on me when \nI\'ve got a hand that can\'t stand much pressure.  \nWhat\'s more, if he doesn\'t put some kind of play on me in this pot ... he could \ndo it at any time. If I keep pushing him out of every pot, sooner or later he\'s \ngoing to stop "sticking his head up".  And, I won\'t be able to "slap" him \nanymore. Then, he\'s going to make me guess. I don\'t want that. I don\'t want \nhim to start getting aggressive. That\'s th e hardest player in the world to beat - \na guy who you bet at and who\'s always pl aying - back at you. That\'s exactly \nthe kind of opponent(s) I don\'t want to play against. I want all my opponents \nto be docile.  \nSo it kind of cools him out when I ju st show down a hand. He knows that I \nknow my two Nines are the best hand. But, by not betting them, I show him \nsome respect. And because I showed the hand down ... I\'ve got him back to \nthinking that when I bet I\' m either bluffing or I\'ve got a hand I\'m going to go \nwith. He\'s back to guessing again. And that\'s exactly where I want him. I \ndon\'t want to antagonize him to the po int where he starts making me do the \nguessing.. It serves a lot of purposes to  slow down in a situation like that.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 89}),
 Document(page_content="A short time later, I might pick-up another Pair of Nines (or Tens or jacks) in a \nvery late position (or on the Button) an d I might raise with it again. Now ... he \nmight play-back at me. If he did ... he'd get the pot. I'd give the pot to anyone \nwho re-raised me before the Flop.  \nI'd never stand a re-raise when I have a small Pair before the flop. I won't \ntake any pressure with them. If someon e puts a play on me ... I throw them \naway.   \nBut, if I don't get re-raise d ... I'm back to my basic style of play. If I was the \nraiser ... I'd go ahead and bet on the Flop . Just about any Flop. If I raised with \ntwo Tens and a 7-3-2 turned ... I'd bet for sure since I've got an overpair. \nHowever, the only time my Pair is of any real value is when I flop a Set.  \nNevertheless, I'd still bet (if I was the raiser) even if three overcards flopped. \nEven if I was sure a guy had a piece of that Flop (a bigger Pair) - and even if I \nwas almost sure I'd get called ... I'd still bet. I'd be giving him the courtesy of a \nbet ... because there's an outside chance  I Could pick that pot up. And it \nwouldn't be a small bet. It would be a reasonable bet.  \nHe'd be looking for me to bet ... and I don't want to disappoint him. It would \nhurt my table-image.  \nI'll do that 90% of the time. In this case , I'll take one stab at the pot and if I \ndon't get it there...I'll try to check it out from there on. An exception would be \nwhen I put a guy on a draw. In that case , he's going to have to pay to make \nhis hand.  \nIf I got raised ... I surely wouldn't go any further with the hand.  \nI play small Pairs cautiously and try to  win a small Pot with them. I won't put \na lot of chips in the pot unless I turn Tr ips. And when I don't make trips with \na small Pair, whenever I bet ... I'm bluffing from there on.  \nIf I had called a raise before the Turn  ... and the raiser bet on the Turn...unless \nI turned a Set, I'd probably surrender th e pot. That's especially true if an \novercard flopped. So, right there, you can see the strength of being the raiser. \nHe made me lay down my hand. That's why I like to be the raiser.  \nWhen you don't help your small Pair on  the Flop ... the important points to \nremember are these:  \n1. You're through with them, if you just called before the Flop ... and \nyou don't put any more money in the pot from there on; and  \n2. If you raised with them, you should generally bet on the Flop trying \nto win a small pot, but, if you get called ... you don't want to bet \nagain (on Fourth and Fifth) and you try to play showdown from that", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 90}),
 Document(page_content="point on - unless you think your opponent is on a draw, in which \ncase you continue betting; and  \n3. If you get re-raised ... you throw away your hand.  \nIt's a different situation entirely when you turn a Set. That's what you played \nfor. And you should play them fast. That's  what I do ... in almost all cases. I \ndon't always raise with them ... but I never check them.  \nNeedless to say, if I was the raiser and I turned a Set ... I immediately bet right \nout.* As you know, I wouldn't need a Set to do that.  \nIf I had called before the Flop ... and someone checks it to me ... and there's \npeople behind me ... I'll always bet with a Set of Trips.  \nAs you know , one of my favorite plays in Hold 'em is to lead right into the \nraiser with Trips (or even Two Pair) - es pecially when I think he's got a big \nPair in the hole. I overbet the pot right there ... and, if the raiser has what he \nrepresented (a big Pair) - he'll almost invariably go ahead and move-in on me.  \n*The only exception to this would be  when I was in the pot with a very \nweek player - and he was the only oppone nt I had. I'd check in this case - at \ndiscussed earlier.  \nYou'd make that play when you've got a small Pair (say Threes) and the Flop \nis 10-7-3. You lead into the raiser because you think he's got an overpair in the \npocket. But, a better Flop would be on e with a Face-Card - say a Q-10-3. Now \n... the raiser's got to have some kind of combination with a Turn like that. If \nhe's got two Aces or two Kings ... he's got to raise you (if he's any kind of a \nplayer). If he's got A-Q ... he'll probably raise you with that, too. If he's got K-\nQ ... he'll probably call you. If he's got a Straight draw ... he'll call - and it's \npossible that he'll raise you. So, you lead  right off into him. If he's fortunate \nenough to have your hand beat ... well,  again, there's nothing magical you can \ndo about it - you have to pay him off.  \nIf someone had called in front of me an d bets on the Flop when it comes like \nA-8-3 and I put him on a Pair of Aces ... I'd probably play my 3-Threes slowly. \nI wouldn't want to take him out of the lead.  \nAnother time you start overbetting the po t on the Turn is when you turn the \nunder Full. This would be when it came  9-9-4 ... and you've got 2-Fours in the \npocket. Well, you start making big (not  reasonable) bets right there because \n'the only way you're going to win any money with your hand is when you \ncatch somebody with a Nine ... or when  you catch somebody with a big Pair \nand they call you or even raise you. You want to be sure there's enough \nmoney involved so you can win a big pot. And, to be sure of that, you've got \nto lead with your hand.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 91}),
 Document(page_content="Note that you play the under Full diffe rent from the way you'd play the big \nFull. If you remember, the way you play the latter hand is to check on the \nFlop because you'd have the deck crippl ed. You want to give a free card then \nso your opponent(s) can catch-up.  \nAre there times when you might release a Set on the Flop- There are. But, \nthey're rare. It's a very hard hand to turn loose.* However, here's a situation where you might possibly save some money:  \nYou bet on the Flop. There's a man in a la te position who didn't raise it before \nthe Turn (so he's unlikely to have a bi g Pair in the pocket). Now...he makes a \nvery strong play after the Turn. I mean, he moves all-in and puts your entire \nstack in jeopardy. At that point, you might be able to determine he's got a \nSet...and if you have the small Set you might be able to get away from your \nhand. But, it's very difficult. In a high-stakes game ... I almost never do it.  \nIf you turn a Set in a raised pot ... it's practically impossible to get away \nfrom it. I defy anybody, anybody, to turn a Set and get away from it if the pot was raised originally.   \nI'll repeat that: if the pot wasn't raised ... conceivably... you could put a man \non a bigger Set than you've got. But, if the pot was raised originally, (before \nthe Flop), it's just impossible to release a Set.  \nIf I raised it before the Flop and I turn a Set ... and a guy beats them ... well, \nhe's going to win a real big pot from m e. If we don't get it all-in on the Flop \n... we'll surely be down to the Green (no chips or money left) when all the \ncards are out.  \n*in addition to what I say here, you might also went to re-read the \ndiscussion on this subject .", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 92}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter Three: \nHow to Play Small Connecting Cards \nBefore the Flop  \nThis is the hand I\'m looking for when  I play No-Limit Hold \'em. Small \nconnecting cards (suited) - the 7c-6c, 8h-7 h, 5d-4d. That\'s the kind of hand I \nwant. It\'s my favorite. And when I get it ... I want my opponent to have two \nAces or two Kings and to believe (as I don\' t) that he should play them slow. If \nhe holds that opinion he\'ll give me the opportunity to get a Turn. And if I do \n... I can break him.  \nExactly such a situation occurred in th e 1977 World Series of Poker. It was \ndefinitely THE pot of the Tournament ... bigger and more important than the \npot I played with "Bones". Not only di d I win it ... but I eliminated two very \ntough opponents. Here\'s what happened:  \n"Junior" Whited had the big Blind for $600.* Player \'X` limped-in for the six \nhundred. "Sailor" Roberts passed. Bones was next and he made it $3500 to go. \nI called ... and so did Milo Jacobson. When  it got back to Junior ... he went all-\nin for $11,300. "X" was now looking at two raises Bones\' $2900 and junior\'s \n$8400. He called. So did Bones. And so did I. Milo passed. It was a big pot \nalready ... and destined to get bigger. The dealer got ready to turn some cards. \nHere\'s what they were:  \n \n*At this stage of the Tournament, the ante was $200 and there were Blinds \nof $300 and $600.  \n**I\'m going to keep "X" anonymous to avoid any personal embarrassment \nthat might stem from this description be cause he\'s one of the world\'s very \nbest No-Limit Hold \'em players.   \nJunior was already all?in so "X" was first to act on the Flop. He moved all-in \nwith a huge bet. Bones passed. It was up to me. \'X\' could\'ve made his move \nand shut me out before the Turn. He would\'ve picked?up $26,500 had he \ndone so. Now ... it was too late. I had him. There was no doubt in my mind \nabout that. So I asked the dealer to count-down his bet. It was $45,400. I \nshoved in four and a half (20 chip) st acks of grays ($500 each) and four black \n($100) chips. I was the only one who had any chips left so we all turned our \nhands over.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 93}),
 Document(page_content='As you can see ... when all the cards were out, the pot was mine. It was the \nonly time in the Tournament where tw o players were eliminated in the same \npot - two very tough ones.  \nIn order to win that $142,500 pot ... I had to gamble almost $12,000 with those \nsmall connecting cards before the Flop. I\' d do it again. I always do it when \nthere\'s an opportunity for me to win a real big pot.  \n"X"...and Junior, too ... had almost exactl y the hands I thought they had. And \nwhen "X" made his move on the Turn, I was certain he had one of two hands \n... the one he did have - or two Aces. He couldn\'t have had anything else.  \nIf "X" had played his hand the way I recommend ... he would\'ve won a "small" \npot. As it was, he lost a big one. That\'s  about true to form for two Aces or two \nKings.  \nIf you recall, I stated on that "with a Pair of Aces or Kings in an early position \nbefore the Flop ... I would probably limp-in (just call the Blind) hoping that somebody \nwould raise it behind me so I could re-raise."  \'X\' got the first part of that advice \nright. If he got the second part righ t and raised Junior,...I never would\'ve got \nto play my hand.  \nThat\'s the whole thing about the small connecting cards. I\'ll come in with \nthem in an early or middle position. I might come in for the first bet (or, as \nyou now know, even the second if I think I can win a real big pot). I probably \nwon\'t raise with this kind of hand beca use I don\'t want to get shut out of the \npot. If I raise ... and somebody else re-rai ses -- I probably won\'t be able to play \nit. Or, if I have to call a double-raise cold...I probably won\'t be able to play it \nthere either. There are exceptions, as al ways....but, in general, I play the hand \nso I can get a Turn with it.  \nSmall connecting cards are a hand that\'s not designed to put a whole lot of \nmoney in with before the Flop. It is a hand that\'s designed to take a lot of \nFlops with. You want to get a Turn with th em to try to make a little Straight, \na little Set of Threes, a little  Two-Pair ... or something.   \nWith any two cards to a Straight-Flush (c onnected or not - except for the top \nand bottom cards of a Straight Flush such as the 8c-4c, Jh-7h, etc.) ... I\'d come \nin in any position. In a late po sition ... I\'d raise with them.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 94}),
 Document(page_content='I\'m really looking to get raised when I co me in with this hand in an early or \nmiddle position. In fact, I hope someone has a big Pair in the hole and raises \nbehind me. Then, I can put a relatively small amount of additional money in \nthe pot ... and, if I get a Turn - I can break him.  \nThe beautiful part about having the sm all connecting cards is that if you \ndon\'t get any help.. you throw them away. If the Turn comes 9-9-2, for \nexample, you don\'t get involved with a 7-6. You\'re through.   \nNormally, I wouldn\'t want to get more  than 5% (maybe, 10%) of my money \ninvolved (before the Flop) with this type of hand. If I get as much as 20% of \nmy money in with that hand ... I\'d have to  be rushing. I wouldn\'t do it unless I \nwas on a streak.  \nAlso, there are times when I might raise with something like a 7-6, if I was in \nan early or middle position. I noted that I generally just call. And, as a rule ... \nthat\'s true. But, if the tempo of the game  was just right ... I\'d raise in an early \nor middle position.  \nFor example, if I was winning a lot of pots ... I\'d do it. I said that I always play \nthe next pot after I win a pot... regardle ss of what position I\'m in. And when I \nplay that pot, I usually raise it. Also , if the game had tightened down where \neverybody was dealing (playing) the nuts ... I\'d shoot it up with a couple of \nsmall connecting cards.  \nOf course, you always try to keep from  getting re-raised with that hand. So, \nthe ideal situation is when you think your "muscle" will keep anyone from \nplaying-back... and will make your opponents think you\'ve probably got big \ncards or a big Pair.  \nThe reasons I raise with the hand in a late position are because I don\'t think \nI\'ll get re-raised and since nobody\'s raised in front of me, I\'ll be able to give \nmy hand some deception. And, the reasons I usually don\'t raise in an early \nposition are because I\'d have to go through six or seven players without \ngetting re-raised. With a lot of top pl ayers in the game ... that\'s not likely. \nAlso, I like to be in the lead - and, if I make something with it, I can take \ncharge. So, with players behind me ... I usually call with it.  \nAnother thing is that I don\'t have to maintain my table-image (of betting on \nthe Flop when I\'m the raiser). If I just  called (before the Flop) and somebody \nelse raised ... I very seldom try to pick the pot up or bluff into the raiser. The \nraiser commands respect. So, when I miss that hand completely when \nsomebody else raised it...well, it\'s their pot. That\'s why I like to be the raiser.  \nThe only reason I don\'t like to raise with small connecting cards is because \nwhen somebody has the hand I want them  to have (a big Pair)...they\'re going \nto raise me back. That\'s one more reason I usually limp-in with them.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 95}),
 Document(page_content='When you limp-in with this hand in  an early position... you\'re actually \nplaying it like you would two Aces or two Kings. So, there\'s also a bit of \ndeception there. And, if somebody raises in a middle or late position ... you \ncan pretty well put them on a hand - that  is, big cards like A-K, K-Q or a big \nPair. That\'s what you\'re also looking to  do - you want to be able to put \nsomebody on a hand so you know  what you\'re trying to beat.  \nIf you play in the style I recommend - th at is, very aggressively - you\'ll have \nto adjust your play in a small game. You\'ll probably discover you\'ll get re-\nraised more when you raise in a sma ll game than you will in a big game. \nThat\'s been my experience. Here\'s why:  \nIf I\'m in a game where there\'s not much money on the table - say, everybody\'s \ngot only $500 or $600 - and I raise it $100 ... well, a guy with big cards is going \nto move-in on me. They do it all the ti me in a small game. And when I\'ve got \na 7-6 or a 9-8 and someone bets the rest of his money at me ... I can\'t call it.  \nI\'m not going to take two small connecting cards and try to beat two Kings, \nA-K and so forth when I can\'t win anything if I get a Turn. So, in a case like \nthat, I throw my hand away.   \nAnd, because of that ... I have trouble winning in a game where there\'s not \nmuch money on the table.  \nBut, it\'s a totally different story in a big game. If I raise it $300 or $400 ... and \nme and the other guy have a lot of chips on the table - well, he\'s a little more \nhesitant about raising me now because he knows there\'s a very good chance \nI\'ll play-back. The guys I play with kn ow when I put my "children" out there \n... I don\'t like to let them drown.  \nBut, even if I do get re-raised in this situ ation...it\'s all right. In fact, it\'s what I \nwant. If he raises me $700 or $800 ... and I\'ve got small connecting cards - I\'ll \ncall, now. If we\'ve both got $25,000 in front of us ... then all I\'ll be putting in is \nabout 5% of my money. And it\'s worth it. Because now I\'ve got a chance to \nwin something if I get a Turn. I might be able to break him.  \nI\'ll now discuss how I\'d play this hand depending on what I flop.  \nHow to Play Small Connecting Cards on the Flop… when you miss your \nhand completely   \nIf I called in an early position with small connecting cards and I miss my hand \ncompletely ... I give the pot up.  \nI don\'t go ahead with that type of hand in that situation. I just surrender. The \nfirst loss is the best loss in a situation like that.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 96}),
 Document(page_content='But, once again, if I was the raiser ... I would, of course, go ahead and bet at \nthe pot. As long as there wasn\'t something "frightening" out there like the Qs-\nJs-10s... I\'m going to bet. And, somethin g "frightening" won\'t be out there 90% \nof the time.  \nIf I had a 7d-6d in an early position and had decided to raise it before the \nTurn (when I was rushing, for example)  ... and the Ah-Ac-Ks flopped ... I\'d bet \nright out. A Flop like that wouldn\'t "frighten" me. Why? It\'s simple. My \nopponents don\'t know I don\'t have A-K or A-Q or K-K ... or any hand where \nthat would be a good Flop for me. They do n\'t know what I\'ve got. In fact, if I \nraised in an early position they might th ink I did have a hand with big cards.  \nIf I had raised it from a middle position before the Flop ...
