I\'d also bet - unless \nsomeone bet in front of me. In that case  ... the pot\'s theirs. I\'d know they had \nsomething... and when I\'ve got nothing wi th this kind of hand, I\'m usually not \ngoing to try to make any great play (alt hough occasionally I will bluff at it).  \nIf I was a caller before the Flop in a mi ddle or late position and it was checked \nto me on the Flop ... I\'d check along. As long as I didn\'t make anything...it \nwould probably have to be checked to me twice (on the Flop and Fourth St.) \nbefore I\'d bet (which would be a bluff).  \nOf course, if I had raised it before the Turn from a late position ... I\'d almost \nalways bet - particularly if it was checked around to me. I\'d bet even if the \nFlop was as noted before (Ah-Ac-Ks) and it was probable that someone had \nan Ace. The reason I\'d do it is just like I discussed earlier. I don\'t want my \nopponents to get out of the habit of checking to me. Since they expect me to \nbet (because I was the raiser) ... I want to fulfil their expectations. So I go \nahead and make a courtesy bet for them. When I make that bet, I\'m trying to \ndo two things:  \n(1) I\'m trying to win the pot right ther e. And I will many a time because they \nget into the habit of throwing their hands away.  \n(2) I\'m also able to maintain my aggre ssive image. As long as I do, they\'ll \ncontinue to check it to me.  \nThat\'s the way I pick-up all the pots I do. Of course, if I get check-raised ... I\'m \nout immediately. That\'s the risk I take. But, a guy really has to have a hand \nbefore he\'ll put a play on me like that. So, when he does ... I let him have the \npot. But, they miss their hands more often than they make them. Because of that, I pick-up more pots than I give-up.  \nHow to Play Small Connecting Cards on Fourth and Fifth...when you miss \nyour hand completely', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 97}),
 Document(page_content="I wouldn't be in there on Fourth St. with this hand if I had nothing ... unless I \nwas the bettor - or, if it was checked to me and I checked it with them. If \nsomeone had called my bet after having checked it to me on the Flop ... I \nwould immediately put him on some kind  of hand. If I thought he was on a \ndrawing hand ... and it looked like he misse d it on Fourth - I'd bet again. If I \nthought he had a made hand regardless of how weak it was (even the Third \nButton) I wouldn't try to make him thro w away his hand on Fourth when he \ncalled me on the Flop and had, therefore, already committed himself to the \npot. For example, if the Flop was a K-8-2 and I tried to pick it up, but I got \ncalled...well, then I'd try to check it out all the way through. At that point, I'd \nbe giving up the pot at a minimum loss.  \nAnd, once again, if I thought my oppo nent was on a drawing hand (like two \ncards to a Straight-Flush) and I make another stab at the pot on Fourth ... and \nI get check-raised - I'm almost always going to  give it up in that situation, too.  \nI'm never going to call a bet when I miss my hand completely. But, I might \nplay?back at a guy who I think's putting a play on me.   \nAs a general rule, I wouldn't make a play in that situation. However, in an \nextreme situation I would. If I was completely convinced a guy was trying to \ntake the pot away from me ... I'd re-play at him. But, I'd have to feel strongly \nabout it before I'd jeopardize a bunch of chips in that spot.  \nMy play on Fifth St. would be just like my play on Fourth. If I'm still betting at \nthe pot...I'd have to continue because th ere'd be almost no way I could win in \na showdown. I mean ... all I'd have woul d be Seven-high (assuming I didn't \npair on the end). Since I put my oppone nt on a draw on Fourth (and that's \nwhy I bet there) ... I'd have to feel he didn't make it when all the cards were \nout. I'd also have to feel very strongly he wouldn't call my last bet. Naturally, \nif I felt like he completed his hand ... I'd check.  \nYou'd be in a tough spot on the end ... but you just couldn't leave all your \nmoney out there without one last stab at the pot. The key to what you'd do on \nFifth is very much based on your op inion of why your opponent called you \non Fourth. You'd have to feel pretty su re he was drawing ... or you could get \nyourself in a lot of trouble.  \nYou might find it difficult to continue  betting your hand when you know you \ndon't have anything. You may think it take s a lot of courage to do that. And it \ndoes. But, all it really is, is good Poker.  \nYou'll discover, if you use my system of  play, that your opponents will be \nscared to give you (free) cards whenever they've got a hand. The reason \nthey'll be afraid to do that is because they know you could be drawing at an \ninside Straight and betting with it. They know an aggressive player is liable to \nshow them anything. Consequently... when  they get a hand ... they want to \nshut you out right then. They bet beca use they don't want you in the pot", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 98}),
 Document(page_content="drawing at them. So there are really two good points about playing in the \naggressive way I recommend:  \n(1) If your opponents do have a hand ... they'll show you right away. They \ndon't want to keep giving you free cards; and  \n(2) Your continuous betting makes them throw away borderline hands so \nyou can pick-up the pot when they don't have anything.  \nQuite simply ... an aggressive player has way the best of it.   \nHow to Play Small Connecting Cards when you make something   \nI'm now going to discuss how I'd play small connecting cards when I turn \nsomething with them. The hand I'm goin g to use as an example throughout \nthe discussion that follows is a 7d-6d. You'll learn how I'd play this hand in \nthree different situations - when I get:  \n(1) a poor flop (slight help)  \n(2) a fair flop (medium help)  \n(3) a good flop (a lot of help)   \nWhen I've got a 7d-6d and a Qs-6h-2c falls ... I'd consider that a poor Flop to \nmy hand. And, the way I'd play it would be very similar to what I'd do when \nI got no help.  \nHowever, there's a big difference in the way I'd play in this situation. It would \ndepend on who I was involved with ... and, more importantly, how much \nmoney he had on the table. I'll gamble wi th the Second Button (a Pair of Sixes, \nin this case) - or even the Third Button - if the guy I was up against was sitting \non a lot of checks. I'd do it even if I knew he had a Pair of Queens. I'd call a \nreasonable bet and might even put as much  as 10% of my mone y in the pot if I \nthought I could break him if I got lucky and caught another Six or a Seven. I'd \nsurely do it if I thought I could win a gigantic pot.  \nI might even raise. There's always a time I might raise - whether I've got a \nsmall piece of the Flop (in this case) or when I've completely missed my hand. \nBut, those times have nothing to do wi th the value of my hand. I'd do it \nbecause I detected a weakness in somebo dy ... or because of my position. \nRight now, I'm discussing what I'd do based on how much value I thought \nmy little Pair of Sixes had.  \nAnother difference in the way I'd play this  hand when I got a little help on the \nFlop (and no help on Fourth or Fifth) is  that I'd continue to bet on Fourth if I \nwas the original raiser. You'll recall that even if I missed this hand completely,", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 99}),
 Document(page_content="I'd bet it on the Flop as long as I was the raiser. But, if my bet on the Flop was \ncalled ... I'd try to check it out from then on (unless I thought my opponent \nwas drawing).  \nNow, however, I'd bet again on Fourth despite the fact that my bet on the \nFlop was called. I don't like to keep betting when I'm on a complete bluff ... \nbut I do like to keep betting when I've go t an Out. And, I'd feel like I've got an \nOut because if I catch that other Six (o r a Seven) ... I'd feel like I'd have a \nstronger hand than my opponent.  \nSo I wouldn't show any weakness with my hand on Fourth St. I'd go ahead \nand make a reasonable bet.  \nIf I still didn't get any help on Fifth St., I'd more than likely stop betting. If my \nopponent was drawing and he didn't make  his hand ... my Pair of Sixes are \nprobably good - so I'd check. And, if they aren't good, there's no sense in \nlosing any more money with them.  \nIn the case where I got some additional help on Fourth - say I caught a Seven - \nwell, then I'd make an oversized bet (mor e than what's in the pot). I'm always \nout to win a big pot ... and now I'd have a hand to do it with. I wouldn't try to \nsell my hand for a small amount of money. I'd make a very big bet on Fourth \n... and a very big bet on Fifth.  \nIf I didn't catch that Seven until the end ... then I might try to sell it on Fifth St. \nfor whatever I thought I could get.  \nThe above way I'd play this hand when I caught a Seven on Fourth (or Fifth) \nassumed that I was the original raiser co ming in and I stayed in the lead. That \nis, I continued to bet on every turn of the cards.  \nIf I was a caller coming in and had chec ked and called on the Flop ... I'd play \nthe hand differently if I caught a Seven on  Fourth St. In this case, it would be \nanother one of the few times I'd check-rai se if there was a lot of money in the \npot. I wouldn't want to take my opponent  (the original raiser) out of the lead \nwhen I know he'd bet again on Fourth because the pot's so big ... especially \nsince he'd have almost no idea the Seven helped me. He'd surely try to shut \nme out...and when he bet - I'd raise him.  I'd want to win the pot right there \nbecause the Board might pair on the end (with a Queen or Deuce) and kill my \nTwo-Pair.  \nThe situation where I caught a Six on Fo urth St. would be different still. My \nhand wouldn't be nearly as concealed (a s it would be when I caught a Seven). \nThe two Sixes on the Board would look very threatening. So, even if I had \nbeen a caller up to this point ... there's a good chance I'd take the lead and bet \nwhen the Six hit. And, even though th e raiser could readily see that I might \nhave 3 Sixes ... he might also think I was representing them. That, by the way,", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 100}),
 Document(page_content="would be a very good situation to bluff at  the pot if you didn't have a Six in \nthe hole.  \nNow, I'll discuss how I'd play that 7d-6d when I got what I'd call a fair Flop. \nAny three cards that gave me the top Pa ir, an open-end Straight (or a Flush) \ndraw would be a fair Flop. But, I'd pl ay fast only with the Straight draw.  \nI play Flush draws extremely slowly be cause they're so obvious. When there \nare two of the same suit on the Flop, I see so many players move-in on a guy \nafter he bets when they're drawing to a Flush. Occasionally, I do it too... \nbecause my philosophy of play is to protect my money and bet whenever I \ncan. But, it's usually a very obvious play. Most players will put you on a Flush \ndraw in that situation. And for that reason I like a Straight draw better.  \nIf I get that Straight draw ... well, I'm ready now. I mean really ready. The \nbattle's on. If I was the original raiser ... of course, I'd bet on the Turn. If I get \nraised ... I'd play-back and move all my ch ips in. If somebody bets in front of \nme ... I'd raise 'em.  \nIf I wasn't the original raiser ... this would be another time when I'd check-\nraise. If the guy who raised it before the Flop bet after I checked ... I'd raise \nwith most or all of my chips. I'd be the aggressor at that point ... and nobody \ncould take me out of the lead from then on.  \nAs I said earlier, most decisions are made on the Flop. I mean, that's where \nyou steal pots. So I'd play this hand that way because I'd be in a very typical situation where I steal a lot of pots. I'd be bluffing with an Out. I \ncould win the pot right there. If I got called, I'd have a good draw (an open-end Straight which I'd make about 33% of the time) and a small chance to back-door Two-Pair or Trips.   \nIn the case where I just turned the top Pair (when the Board was a 6-4-2 or a 7-\n4-2) ... I'd play it cautiously. I'm not go ing to fall in love with that hand...but, \nI'll gamble a little with it.  \nIn other words, I'd check to the raiser ... and then I'd probably call. If I was in \na late position (and hadn't raised origin ally) ... I'd also call if somebody bet. \nBut, it would be a weak call - meaning th at I probably wouldn't go any further \nwith the hand if I don't get any help on Fourth and somebody bets at me \nagain.  \nOne of the reasons I'd call on the Flop is because my Pair might be the best \nhand. just because the other guy raised it  originally doesn't mean he has to \nhave a big Pair in the pocket. So, ther e's a possibility I've got the best hand \nright now. I'd know more depending on what he did on Fourth St. If he bet \nagain (and I didn't help my hand) ... I' d get rid of it pretty fast. I wouldn't \ninvest a lot of money with that hand without any help.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 101}),
 Document(page_content="But, the main reason I'd call on the Flop is because of the possibility I could \nwin a big pot if I improve my hand and beat a hand (two Aces or two Kings). \nAnd the reason I check rather than bet is because I might have the best hand \nand I could get myself shut-out if I bet and get raised. Then, I'd have to throw \nmy hand away. By checking, I could ca ll a reasonable bet and try to catch a \ncard.  \nIf I did improve on Fourth, I'd play it from then on just like I would in the \nsituation where I got a poor Flop, but got some help on Fourth.  \nA good (or even a great Flop) to a 7d-6d would be a Pair with a Straight (or \nFlush) draw, Two-Pair, Trips, a Straight or a Flush (even though it's a small \none).  \nWith any good Flop to small connecting cards ... I'd play the hand as if it \nwas complete - whether it was or not.  I'd lead with the hand in an early \nposition ... and I'd raise in a late position.  \nI'd play the hand to get all my money in the center to start with - even if I \nturned a Pair with a draw. In the latte r case, I'd play it that way because I'd \nhave two chances to win it ... when I be t or raise (and my opponent throws \nhis hand away) - or when I improve (if my bet or raise is called). Naturally, you'll be in some jeopardy - even when you get a very good Flop. But, you're almost always in some jeopardy . So you can't worry about somebody \nhaving the nuts all the time. If you did ... you never would get to play a pot.   \nFor example, if you turned a Flush with somebody else ... yours will probably \nbe the little one - and you'd be dead.* If  it happened ... you'd just have to lose \nyour money because you'd (almost always) have to go ahead and pay your \nopponent off. It's one of the hazards of the game.  \nYou could also flop the ignorant (low) end of the Straight. That would be \nanother hazard if somebody turns a bi gger Straight. And again, if your \nopponent bet anything within reason, yo u'd have to go ahead and pay him. \nFor example, if the Flop was a 10-9-8 and somebody moved all-in on you, \nyou'd be down to judgement. You'd have to know your player ... and a lot \nwould depend on how much is in the pot and the amount he sets you in for. If \nyou've got $1000 in the pot and he bets you $50,000 more ... well, perhaps, you \nwouldn't go for it and you'd throw yo ur hand away. But, if you've got $1000 \nin the pot and he bets you $2000 more - all your money, or all his money - \nthen you'd surely pay it off.  If you're beat...you're beat.  \nThat happens a lot, by the way. And, it's why (as you'll later learn) a K-9, J-7 \nand hands like that are trash and shouldn' t be played (in a normal ante, Ring \ngame).", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 102}),
 Document(page_content="With all the good Flops, I'd already be committed to the pot ... so, on Fourth \nSt., I'd bet - if I was first or if it was checked to me. But, as always, there are \nexceptions.  \n*There's no way you can draw out when It's a Flush against a Flush In Hold \n'em ... except for a Straight-Flush.   \nFor example, if you flopped a Diamon d Flush and another Diamond came on \nFourth St. - your hand would be almost ruined. All you'd have is a Seven-high Flush. At that point, you must check your hand and hope to show it \ndown. If you can't show it down ... you've got to throw it away. Or, if you \nflopped a Straight and the Board pairs on  Fourth St. - you could also be in \ntrouble. Usually, that shouldn't stop you because if a man turned a Set or \nTwo-Pair, he would've raised you on the Flop. So, if he made a Full (when the \nBoard paired) ... you'd have to pay him off. Another hazard.  \nAs you continue to use my system of play, you'll discover the many \nadvantages it has. The situation above is a good case in point. If the Flop was, say a 5-4-3 (giving me a Straig ht) ... my opponent would've let me \nknow on the Flop whether or not he had a hand (Two-Pair or Trips). That is, \nif he's a good player he would.  \nThe reason why is because he wouldn't want another card to fall that would \nbe one card off of a Straight. He knows if an Ace, Deuce, Six, or Seven comes on Fourth ... he's going to have to give the pot up. He knows I'll bet in that case whether or not I have th e one card that'll make the Straight.  \nFor that reason, all good Hold 'em players do most of their gambling on the \nFlop... not on Fourth and Fifth Sts. Occa sionally, you'll see a big pot played \nafter the Flop ... but, in the majority of cases, all the money usually goes in on the Flop. That's the reason the Flop is the most crucial point in the game.   \nYou'll recall that earlier I stated it's quite inconceivable to me that anybody \ncould get away from their hand if they flopped a Set of Trips in a raised pot. \nAt that point, I was talking about a hi dden Set (a Pair in the pocket and one \non the Board). It's a different case entire ly when the Pair is on the Board and I \nhave one of the matching cards in the hole . I've turned down a lot of Sets in a \nsituation like that when, for example, I have a 7-6 and the Flop is 7-7-2 ... and I \nbet and get called. There's really not very many hands someone can call me \nwith.  \nSo it's easy to release a Set in this case because when you get a lot of money \ninvolved you know the guy who's in th ere with you has probably got a Seven \nalso. (It's especially true if he's the aggressor.) So you have to evaluate your \nkicker. I mean ... what's it worth? The conc lusion I reach is that it's usually not \nworth very much. If I really think he's  got a Seven then I know the best I", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 103}),
 Document(page_content='could hope for is that I\'ve got him ti ed. Of course, I\'m talking about a good \nplayer ... and it\'s much more likely he\'s got me beat.  \nHe\'s probably in there with a Seven and a higher card that he could\'ve \nflopped a Straight with (such as an 8-7, 9-7 or 10-7). Another possibility is that \nhe\'s got a high card (such as an Ace or King) that\'s suited. He might have a 7-\n6 (like I do) or a 7-5 (the only likely hand I could beat). But it\'s almost inconceivable he\'s in there with a 7-4, 7-3 or a 7-2 (although the latter hand \nwould give him a Full).  \nSo when I got down into the hand and I gave him credit for the other Seven \nbecause he was showing a whole lot of speed ... I couldn\'t continue playing \nmy Seven with a small connecting card. And I release that Set quite readily. \nI\'d do it real quick.  \nWhen I have a Set like that with a diffe rent kicker, I make another evaluation. \nIf my kicker was slightly bigger... say a Ni ne or Ten - I\'d probably play it. If I \nhad a suited Ace or King then I\'d definitely go ahead and play it.  \nOf course, the situation could be quite di fferent when I turn a Set with that 7-6 \n... where I might not release it. This woul d be the case where I raised with the \nhand before the Flop. Now, on the Flop, everybody checks it to me ... and I \nbet. Somebody plays-back (check-raises me). In this situation, I might go \nahead with my hand figuring that the guy was trying to shut me out. He \nmight be playing-back with an overpair or a lot of different hands he might \nnot have played too strong (raised me with) before the Flop.  \nIt would also be a different situation if I had called a small raise before the \nFlop in a late position with a 7-6. Now,  I would not give the raiser credit for a \nSeven if a 7-7-2 fell. And I\'d probably pl ay my hand real fast trying to win a \nbig pot.  \nWhenever there\'s a raise before the Turn  ... there\'s a chance you can win a big \npot. But, in an unraised pot ... it\'s hard  to win a big one. Earlier I noted that \nyou don\'t want to get broke in a "nothi ng" pot. I\'m reminding you of that now \nbecause you might try to win a big pot when you turn a Set with small \nconnecting cards in an unraised pot. Yo u. shouldn\'t. I never jeopardize very \nmuch money without a real good hand when I don\'t have anything in the pot \nto protect. I don\'t go out of my way to win "nothing" pots.  \nAnother important part of my playing philosophy I want to remind you about \nis this:  \nYou should constantly be trying to get as much value for your hand as you \ncan. And the way you do that is to bet.   \nThat should be clear by now. You beco me a big winner at Poker by betting ... \nraising ... and re-raising - by playing ag gressively. Of course, there are times', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 104}),
 Document(page_content="you have to play defensively - when an aggressive strategy would be wrong \nbecause it could defeat your purpose by getting you shut-out of a pot. But, in \ngeneral, you want to be aggressive.  \nThat means you can't let every card that  hits the Board constantly threaten \nyou. As I said, if you're always worrying about somebody having the nuts ... \nyou never will get to play a hand. This applies to all the hands I've discussed, \nbut it's especially meaningful here be cause I'm discussing how to play small \nconnecting cards when you get a good Fl op. That's what you're playing them \nfor in the first place ... so, when you ma ke something with them - you want to \nget value for them. So you should always apply this principle:  \nIf you're going to call... you might as well bet.   \nYou should do that at all the stages of play ... but it's particularly important on \nthe end.  \nIf you do ... you'll get paid off with hands that aren't what you thought they \nwere. I mean, there'll be many times you'll put your opponent on a hand \ncompletely different from what he's got. I'm not Houdini ... and neither are \nyou. You might think a man is drawing to  a Flush ... but maybe he's got a Pair \n- just one Pair. He might have been running you down with a lot less than \nyou thought he had. So, when a Flush card  hits the Board on Fifth St. - it may \nnot have helped him at all. I mean, you'll know he's got something when that \nFlush card comes.. either the Flush you thought he was drawing at - or some \nother piece of the Flop. Or maybe he's got Two-Pair when you've got a \nStraight. You really don't know what he 's got ... but since you're going to pay \nit off anyway since you've got a good ha nd with your small connecting cards - \nyou might as well bet.  \nThe only exception I make is when the Board pairs on the end. Then, I'll check \nit ... and may or may not call depending on  how I feel about the situation. But \nbarring that, if I've made a real good  hand with my small connecting cards ... \nI'd go ahead and bet.  \nThe opposite of the case where I might be a little concerned when I don't have \nthe nuts is, of course, when I do have the nuts. Naturally, in that case, I'll do \nwhatever I think will get the most money in the pot.  \nIf I thought my opponent had a strong ha nd ... I'd make a big bet. If I thought \nhe had a weak hand ... I'd try to sell my hand by making a smaller bet. \nThere'd be a lot of judgement there ... ju dgement about what I think he's got.  \nMy decision on how much to bet depe nds on whether I made my hand early \n(on the Flop) or late (on the end).  \nIf I made my hand early. ..I'm not going to try to sell him anything - I'm \ngoing to try to break him.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 105}),
 Document(page_content="If I made my hand late and I haven't been charged a lot of money to make it \n(like it was checked on the Flop and there was a small bet on Fourth and I make the nuts (in the end) ... well, then I'm not going to try to break him - because he probably won't call a big be t. Then, I'd try to sell my hand for \nwhatever I thought I could get for it.   \nThose of you who are new to No-Limit Hold 'em may not have been able to \nappreciate how strongly I feel about th e small connecting cards. And of those \nof you who are experienced players were pr obably quite surprised. But, that's \nwhere it's all at in my opinion. You ha ve to use a lot of judgement when you \nplay the small connecting cards ... and wh en you play them right - they're big \nmoney-makers. And that's what No-Limit Hold 'em is' all about.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 106}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter Three: \nBorderline or Trouble Hands  \nYou should commit to memory the following list of trouble hands. I call them \nthat because that's exactly what they are  ... and I only play them in borderline \nsituations.* They're hands you can lose a lot of money with ... so you should \nplay them very cautiously. You don't want to jeopardize much money with \nthem.  \nTROUBLE HANDS (only when offsuit)   \nAce-Queen King-Queen Queen Jac Jack-Ten \nAce-Jack King-Jack Queen-Ten Nine-Eight \nAce-Ten King-Ten   \n*Two Important qualifications are that I don't consider the trouble hands \nborderline when:  \n(1) they're suited; and  \n(2) I get them In a short-handed game. As you'll learn, I define a \nshorthanded game as one with four players or lost and In such a game the \ntrouble  hands are actually big hands.  \nThe reason I consider those hands bord erline is because I'd question calling a \nraise with them. If they're suited, I'll call a raise with them and go ahead and \ntake a turn. When they're not suited, I wo n't call a raise if I'm out of position.  \nBy out of position I mean that I'm in a middle position and a man in an early \nposition came in raising. I'll pass these hands in that spot.  \nIf I'm in a late position and the pot's been raised and another man calls ... well, \nthen I'll usually call with them but, I'll hear another bell ringing when I do. \nThis time, that bell will be remindin g me to play my hand with extreme \ncaution...unless I get an excellent turn to it.  \nThe reason why you have to be so careful with those hands is because with \nevery one of them you might be up ag ainst a hand where you'd be almost \ndead. Most players consider A-A, K-K or A-K to be the best raising hands ... \nso there's a good possibility the raiser has one of those three hands. True, you \ncan't always assume that ... but it's always in the back of your mind. So, if \nyou've got A-Q, A-J or A-10 ... and you're up against A-A, K-K or A-K ... \nyou've got a terrible hand.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 107}),
 Document(page_content="It's extremely hard to win a big po t with those hands (offsuited) when \nyou've called a raise. They're definitely  trouble hands. You're much more \nlikely to lose a big pot with them th an you are to win a big pot with them. \nEven when I make a Pair with them on the Flop ... I play them extremely cautiously - or about the same way I'd play when I had a Pair of Aces or \nKings in the pocket.  \nFor example, if I played a K-Q (offsuit) and the Board came K-4-2 ... I'd be in a \nlot of trouble if the raiser's got one of  the three hands I've assumed he might \nhave. He'd have two Aces, three Kings or  a Pair of Kings (like I've got) but \nhe'd have an Ace kicker.  \nOr, if I played a 9-8 and the Flop was Q-J-10 ... I still wouldn't be too excited \nabout my hand - even though I turned a Straight. It would not only be the \nignorant end of the Straight ... but it  would have an additional weakness \nbecause the high-end of the Straight woul d be made up by a very strong hand \nthat everybody plays - namely, A-K.  \nSomething else you have to think about wi th the trouble hands is that it's not \nas easy to pick-up pots with them when you turn a Straight draw. You'll \nremember that when I turn a Straight draw with small connecting cards, I \nplay my hand real fast because I have two shots to win the pot. I can win the \npot right on the Flop because, with sma ll cards out there it's less likely anyone \nelse turned a hand. And, if I do get called, I've still got a second shot to win it \nif I make my Straight.  \nBut, if I turn a Straight draw with a K-Q (say, the Flop is J-10-5) ... it's highly \nlikely somebody's got a piece of that Flop - and I'm less likely to pick the pot \nup when I bet. So, I don't have two shots to win it anymore.  \nThe same kind of reasoning applies to the times when you might turn the top \nPair and a Straight draw with a K-Q when  the Flop is Q-J-10. It's not even a \ngood hand then because you might be dead (as you would be with a 9-8) \nwhen somebody has an A-K. The best you could be drawing for would be a \nsplit.  \nEven when you turn a very good hand like Two-Pair or Trips ... you could be \nin jeopardy. If the Flop was K-K-2... yo u could once again be in big trouble \nwith K-Q when someone's got A-K. The di fference here is that you probably \nwon't be able to get away from your hand and you'll have to go ahead and \nlose a lot of money.  \nThe important point to remember about the trouble hands is when you do \nget a Flop to them you don't want to get heavily involved. You should just try to play the pot as cheaply as possible.   \nA minor exception to the above consid eration is when you turn a Straight \n(meaning that you must use both your hole cards as when you have, say a Q-", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 108}),
 Document(page_content="10 and the Flop is K-J-9 or J-9-8). However, even in this case (when you have \nthe nuts) ... there's a chance you could lo se the pot. If a Queen fell on Fourth, \nwith the K-J-9 Flop, you could lose to an A-10 ... and with the J-9-8 Flop, you \ncould lose to a K-10. So, you're not completely safe with some of these hands \neven when you turn the nuts.  \nWhen you have one of the trouble hands suited ... it's a much stronger hand.* \nFor example, if you had the Kd-Qd and the Flop was 1Os-7d-2d ... you'd have \na real big hand. Not only would you have a Flush draw, but you'd also have \ntwo overcards. Or, if you had the 9d-8d with that Flop, you'd have a Straight \nand a Flush draw. That situation (with either the Kd-Qd or the 9d-8d) would \nbe a good opportunity to check-raise  somebody if you were in an early \nposition. If you were in a late positi on and somebody leads into you...you \ncould raise them. Now, you'd be back to the principle where you'd have two \nshots to pick-up the pot. You might win it right there ... or, if you get called, \nyou'd have a good hand to fall back on.  \nChapter Three: \nTrash Hands  \nWith the exception of an Ace or a King with any suited card ... I consider any \nhand I haven't already discussed to be a trash hand. An Ac-8c or a Kh-4h are \nhands that I put in the same category as the small connecting cards and I play \nthem approximately the same way. For example, if the Flop was 9h-6c-2c, and \nI had the Ac-8c ... I'd have a Flush draw and an overcard. If I was in the pot \nagainst two Queens ... I'd be about even-mon ey to win it. So I'd play my hand \nin that situation like I would with tw o small connecting cards that were suited \n(say the 9c-8c). That is, I'd play it fa st ... and try to win the pot on the Flop \nbecause, once again, I'd have two shots to win it.  \n*However, the trouble hands suited or offsuit should be played the came \nway - slowly - unless you Flop a Flush or a Flush draw. Then, you can show \nsome Speed.   \nBut that's where I draw the line - with an Ace or a King and another suited \ncard. After it passed the Ace and King ... if the two cards don't connect - even \nif they're suited - I consider them trash hands. Hands like a Qh-4h or Js-6s are \ntrash.  \nNaturally, hands with non-connecting and offsuit cards such as Jh-5c, 1Os-3d, \n9c-4h are obviously garbage. But, so are  the offsuit hands such as K-9, Q-8, J-7, \n10-6, 9-5, 8-4, 7-3 and 6-2 that a lot of people play because you can turn a \nStraight with them. I don't play those ha nds because if I got the best Flop I \ncould to them (outside of a Full House) ... I could get broke with them by \nrunning into a bigger Straight. Consequently, I never play a hand when I have \nthe top and bottom cards of a Straight - except when I'm in position.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 109}),
 Document(page_content="I always make exceptions when I'm in position - even with the trash hands. \nFor example, I might call a raise before the Flop if I was on the Button with a \nhand like A-8 (offsuit) - or any of the garbage hands - if enough (say, five) \npeople were in the pot in front of me ... and I didn't think there'd be any more \nraises. I might call a small raise and take a turn with a trash hand because it's \na good percentage play. I'd be trying to turn a Full, Trips or Two Pair. But, if I \ndon't get a real good Flop to the ha nd ... I'll throw it away. I won't get \ninvolved and burn up a bunch of money with one of those trash hands. I'm \nnot going to call any bets on the Flop. I'll be raising ... or I'll be gone.  \nI'd even raise with a trash hand if I was in position. More than that ... I'd play \nit fast after the Flop, too. If the guys  in the early positions threw their hands \naway and someone in a middle position  limped-in ... well, if I'm on the \nButton, I'd be in position and I'd raise it regardless of what two cards I have. \nAnd, if it was checked to me on the Flop  ... I'd bet regardless of what flopped.  \nObviously, I wouldn't be playing my ha nd because of its value. Trash hands \nhave no value. I might as well be pl aying with two blank cards in this \nsituation because all I'd be doing is pl aying my position and my opponent. I'd \nfeel like he's got a weak hand to begin with (because he limped-in) and if he \nmisses it ... I'll be able to pick the pot up. Other than the exceptional \nsituations I discussed, trash hands are just not playable.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 110}),
 Document(page_content="Chapter Three: \nShort-Handed Play  \nA lot of times you'll be in a full (Ring) game and before the night's over you'll \nbe playing short-handed. As I already mentioned, you have to be able to \nchange gears  in such a situation. You should  play in the same basic style \naggressively - but you should realize that  all the hands increase in value. This \nis particularly true of the big cards.  \nAnd, in a short-handed game, the trouble  hands all become playable from \nalmost any position. Also, position is probably the most important thing in \na short-handed game.   \nThe reason that's so is because you get to  look at more cards and have to play \nmore hands than you would in a Ring game. You also play your position \nmore than your cards in a short-handed game.  \nWhen your game's down to four-handed,  you need a better hand in the first \ntwo positions than you need in the last  two. When you raise on the Button, \nthe other man has to act first (on the Flop) and that puts him at a big \ndisadvantage. It's a great equalizer when the other man has to act on his hand \nfirst.  \nSo, in a short-handed game, you'd play your position along the same theories \nI discussed in a full game - except the values of the hands go up a few \nnotches. The trouble  hands become better hands because you don't figure to be \nup against A-A, K-K or A-K nearly as often as you might in a Ring game.  \nYou simply play more in line with a big- card theory in a short-handed game. I \nmean, the bigger your cards are ... the better hand you'll have. For instance, \ntwo Aces or two Kings is just a mounta in in a short-handed game ... and you \ncould play them real fast. But, in a Ri ng game, you might play either hand a \nlot slower because there could be a lot of people taking a Turn to beat those \nbig Pairs. That wouldn't  be the case in a short-handed game. Consequently, \nthey're much more valuable hands than they are in a Ring game. What you're \ntrying to catch in a short-handed game is big cards in position.", metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 111}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter Three: \nInsurance  \nMany times when you\'re playing No-Limit  Hold \'em a player will have all his \nmoney in the pot before or on the Flop (or even on Fourth St.). Since there are \ncards to come and since no more betting can take place (if it\'s a head?up \nsituation), both players will generally turn their hands over so that Insurance  \ncan be considered.*  \nInsurance  is a side-bet that\'s usually made between the two players involved \nin the pot or between one of the players involved and an Insurance Man  who \nmay or may not be an active player. The player with the hand having the best \npotential to win the pot is offered (o r asks for) some Insurance. Taking \nInsurance is a way to protect your investment in the pot. But, it\'s always a bad \nbet (unless a mistake is made). As it is in life away from the Poker table, the \nInsurance Man  won\'t be giving away anything.  When he lays you a price on \nyour hand ... he\'ll be getting the best of it. The price you\'ll be getting will \nalways be considerably less than the true price your hand is worth. (See the \nAppendix  and below.) The difference betwee n the true price and the actual \nprice the Insurance Man  is willing to lay is his Vigorish  (edge or Commission).  \n*There\'s no rule that says you must turn your hand over, but such a request \nis rarely (if over) refused.   \nI used the phrase "best potential to win the pot" because it\'s not always the \nbest hand on the Flop that has the best  winning potential. For example, if the \nFlop was 7c-5d-4d and you had the 7d-6d ... you\'d be the favorite (about 2 1/3 \nto 1) over an opponent with a Pair of Kings (say, the Ks-Kh). You\'d have 20 \ncards in the deck that could win for yo u with two shots to catch any one of \nthem.*  \nI try not to take Insurance  myself. I try to lay it because the best (potential) \nhand always has to take the worst of it. For example, if you\'re a 3 to 2 favorite \n... well, the best you can usually get is 13 to 10 (or maybe 7 to 5). So why take \nit? That\'s the edge you\'re looking for to start with. If you take Insurance  ... \nyou\'re giving up your edge.  \nThrough the years, I\'ve heard a lot of discussion about whether you should or \nshouldn\'t take Insurance .  \nMy advice is to lay the  Insurance  ... but don\'t  take it.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 112}),
 Document(page_content='You can\'t argue with mathematical facts when you have the best of \nsomething. If you can lay 7 to 5 on a 3 to 2 shot ... you should do it. But you \nshouldn\'t take 7 to 5 when you\'re a 3 to 2 favorite. It\'s that simple.  \nHowever, I can understand that if a man was on a short bankroll...well, \nperhaps then he should take Insurance. I guess it would be O.K. to take the \nworst of it so you could stay in action. But, if your bankroll warrants it ... don\'t take Insurance - lay it.  \nI used to talk about a related subject with a very big (and very successful) \ngambler I\'ve known for many years. He said "if a man came in and offered to \nlay me 10 to 1 on the flip of a coin for all the money I had in the world ... I \nWOULDN\'T take it." He said he just couldn\'t liquidate everything he\'s got - \nall of his property and his cash. He wouldn\'t  risk losing it all. It would be over \na million dollars. He wouldn\'t do it even  if he thought he could get hold of \nanother million.  \n*Your Straight-Flush draw gives you 15 wins and you have five more wins \nwith the 3-Sixes and 2-Sevens that are still In the dock. Of course, the assumption here Is that your op ponent\'s hand doesn\'t improve.  \nBut, I\'d do it. I surely would. I\'d just have to. I couldn\'t pass up the \nopportunity to take 10 to 1 on an even ?money shot. I\'d do it because I have \nenough confidence in myself that I\'d be  able to come up with another million \nif I lost.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 113}),
 Document(page_content='Chapter Three: \nA Final Word  \nOf course, I\'m sure you understand that all the numerous possibilities have by \nno means been exhausted. No-Limit Hold \'em is a highly complex game. It\'s \nhardly possible (and certainly not practical) to attempt to discuss the \nenormous variety of situations that co uld occur. And, as you now know, there \nare certain questions I couldn\'t answer definitively because even I don\'t know \nexactly what I\'d do until I was faced with the problem. As I\'ve said, at such \ntimes, I go with my "feeling" which is really a rapid analysis of conscious and \nsub-conscious facts.  \nNevertheless, I\'ve given you a lot of white meat  (sophisticated techniques and \nstrategies) that have only been know n by a few world-class Poker players - \nand, in some cases, not even then.  \nThe average player has never had access to the kind of information you\'ve \njust read. First of all, nothing as comprehensive as this has ever been written \nabout No-Limit Hold \'em. Even if it was, unless it was written by someone \nwho has played at a world-class le vel for many years - and who was a \nconsistent winner - it would not be of mu ch value. In fact, it could even be \nharmful. Having no information at all is  better than having bad information.  \nSo ... you should do quite well at No-Limit Hold \'em now that you know \nalmost as much about the game as I do. The rest is up to you.', metadata={'source': 'players/doyle_brunson/brunson_pdfs/super_system.pdf', 'page': 114})]

 Document(page_content='INTRODUCTION\nby D oyle Brunson\nI’d been t oying w ith the idea of  revising m y Super /System for year s, but \nevery time I discussed it with friends or fellow professional poker  players, I \nalways hear d the same respons e: “Why? Y\nou can’\nt\n count\n hi\nm\n out\n unt\ni\nl\n t\nhe f\nal\nl\n of\n t\nhe l\nas\nt\n car\nd. I\n’\nve been t\nes\nt\ned\n \nt\ni\nm\ne and agai\nn on m\nany bat\nt\nl\nef\ni\nel\nds\n. I\n’\nve l\nos\nt\n a l\not\n of\n l\ni\nt\nt\nl\ne s\nki\nr\nm\ni\ns\nhes\n, but\n \nI\n’\nve w\non t\nhe bi\ng ones\n. T\nhat\n’\ns\n w\nhat\n r\neal\nl\ny count\ns\n.\nT\nhe adver\ns\ni\nt\ny I\n’\nve f\naced has\n been a bl\nes\ns\ni\nng i\nn di\ns\ngui\ns\ne. I\nt\n’\ns\n s\nt\nr\nengt\nhened m\ny\n \nchar\nact\ner\n. I\n’\nve had t\no dr\naw\n on t\nhat\n s\nt\nr\nengt\nh m\nany a t\ni\nm\ne at\n t\nhe poker\n t\nabl\ne,\n \nand I\n’\nl\nl\n cont\ni\nnue t\no dr\naw\n on i\nt\n f\nor\n t\nhe r\nes\nt\n of\n m\ny year\ns\n.\nI\n need t\nhat\n s\nt\nr\nengt\nh, t\noo. Y\nou s\nee, I\n’\nm\n a gam\nbl\ner\n. I\n’\nl\nl\n al\nw\nays\n be one. I\n \ncoul\ndn’\nt\n be anyt\nhi\nng el\ns\ne. So m\ny l\ni\nf\ne w\ni\nl\nl\n al\nw\nays\n be f\ni\nl\nl\ned w\ni\nt\nh w\ni\nns\n—and\n \nl\nos\ns\nes\n. I\n w\noul\ndn’\nt\n have i\nt\n any ot\nher\n w\nay. I\nt\n’\ns\n exci\nt\ni\nng. T\nher\ne’\ns\n al\nm\nos\nt\n never\n a\n \ndul\nl\n m\nom\nent\n i\nn m\ny l\ni\nf\ne, and I\n can’\nt\n i\nm\nagi\nne anyone havi\nng a bet\nt\ner\n l\ni\nf\ne t\nhan\n \nt\nhe one I\n have r\ni\nght\n now\n. I\n’\nve got\n j\nus\nt\n about\n ever\nyt\nhi\nng I\n w\nant\n.\nT\nhat\n E\nl\nus\ni\nve Som\net\nhi\nng\nY\nes\n, t\nhe deck’\ns\n been s\nt\nacked agai\nns\nt\n m\ne at\n var\ni\nous\n t\ni\nm\nes\n i\nn m\ny l\ni\nf\ne, but\n I\n’\nve\n \nover\ncom\ne ever\ny col\nd deck I\n’\nve f\naced. I\n’\nm\n enough of\n a dr\neam\ner\n t\no r\neal\ni\nze\n \nw\nhat\n got\n m\ne t\nhr\nough m\ni\nght\n have been t\nhat\n el\nus\ni\nve s\nom\net\nhi\nng a gam\nbl\ner\n cal\nl\ns\n \nl\nuck. B\nut\n I\n’\nm\n al\ns\no enough of\n a r\neal\ni\ns\nt\n t\no know\n t\nhat\n, i\nn gener\nal\n, w\ne m\nake our\n \now\nn l\nuck—t\nhr\nough know\nl\nedge, s\nki\nl\nl\n, and exper\ni\nence. A\nnd t\nhat\n goes\n f\nor\n t\nhe\n \ngam\ne of\n poker\n as\n w\nel\nl\n as\n t\nhe gam\ne of\n l\ni\nf\ne.\nI\nn t\nhe s\num\nm\ner\n of\n 1933, I\n w\nas\n bor\nn i\nn t\nhe Wes\nt\n T\nexas\n t\now\nn of\n L\nongw\nor\nt\nh, a\n \ns\npot\n on t\nhe r\noad cons\ni\ns\nt\ni\nng of\n a f\new\n hous\nes\n and a gener\nal\n s\nt\nor\ne. I\n don’\nt\n \ns\nuppos\ne t\nhe popul\nat\ni\non ever\n exceeded one hundr\ned. We had onl\ny t\nw\no\n \ni\nndus\nt\nr\ni\nes\n i\nn t\nhe ar\nea, f\nar\nm\ni\nng and a U\n.S. G\nyps\num\n pl\nant\n. M\ny dad w\nor\nked f\nor\n \nPl\nant\ner\ns\n G\ni\nn C\nom\npany, and w\nhi\nl\ne he di\ndn’\nt\n m\nake m\nuch m\noney, t\nher\ne w\nas\n \nal\nw\nays\n f\nood on t\nhe t\nabl\ne and a l\ni\nt\nt\nl\ne ext\nr\na f\nor\n t\nhe ki\nds\n once i\nn a w\nhi\nl\ne. We\n \nl\ni\nved i\nn a f\nour\n-\nr\noom\n f\nr\nam\ne hous\ne at\n t\nhe t\ni\nm\ne, w\ni\nt\nh an out\nhous\ne at\n t\nhe back. I\n \nr\nem\nem\nber\n t\nhi\nnki\nng w\nhen I\n w\nas\n l\ni\nt\nt\nl\ne t\nhat\n, i\nf\n I\n ever\n got\n any m\noney, I\n’\nd br\ni\nng\n \nt\nhe pl\num\nbi\nng i\nndoor\ns\n. I\n qui\nt\n t\nhe com\npany and began m\ny car\neer\n as\n a f\nul\nl\n-\nt\ni\nm\ne pr\nof\nes\ns\ni\nonal\n \npoker\n pl\nayer\n. I\n’\nve never\n r\negr\net\nt\ned t\nhat\n deci\ns\ni\non.\nT\nur\nni\nng Pr\no\nT\nhe f\ni\nr\ns\nt\n gam\nes\n I\n pl\nayed t\nhat\n am\nount\ned t\no anyt\nhi\nng w\ner\ne dow\nn on E\nxchange\n \nSt\nr\neet\n i\nn For\nt\n Wor\nt\nh, T\nexas\n. I\n’\nd be s\nur\npr\ni\ns\ned i\nf\n you coul\nd f\ni\nnd a t\nougher\n s\nt\nr\neet\n \ni\nn t\nhe w\nhol\ne w\nor\nl\nd. T\nhey w\ner\ne t\nw\no di\nf\nf\ner\nent\n w\nor\nl\nds\n. A\nf\nt\ner\n w\ne accum\nul\nat\ned a good-\ns\ni\nzed s\nt\nake w\ne m\noved upt\now\nn t\no t\nhe\n \nt\nhr\nee hundr\ned and f\ni\nve hundr\ned buy-\ni\nn gam\nes\n w\nher\ne w\ne pl\nayed w\ni\nt\nh doct\nor\ns\n,\n \nl\naw\nyer\ns\n, and ot\nher\n pr\nof\nes\ns\ni\nonal\n peopl\ne.\nFor\n t\nhe next\n f\ni\nve or\n s\ni\nx year\ns\n w\ne m\nade t\nhe T\nexas\n ci\nr\ncui\nt\n, pl\nayi\nng bi\ngger\n and\n \nbi\ngger\n gam\nes\n t\nhr\noughout\n t\nhe s\nt\nat\ne. For\n t\nhe m\nos\nt\n par\nt\n, t\nhes\ne gam\nes\n w\ner\ne f\nor\n r\ni\nch oi\nl\n m\nen and\n \ncat\nt\nl\nem\nen w\nho had a hanker\ni\nng t\no t\nake on young pr\nof\nes\ns\ni\nonal\ns\n l\ni\nke us\n. We l\nos\nt\n our\n ent\ni\nr\ne bankr\nol\nl\n—cl\nos\ne t\no s\ni\nx f\ni\ngur\nes\n—and bel\ni\neve\n \nm\ne, t\nher\ne’\ns\n not\nhi\nng m\nor\ne cant\nanker\nous\n t\nhan t\nhr\nee br\noke gam\nbl\ner\ns\n. She w\nas\n a phar\nm\naci\ns\nt\n i\nn San A\nngel\no, T\nexas\n,\n \nand I\n cour\nt\ned her\n f\nor\n about\n t\nw\no year\ns\n. She w\nas\n s\nom\net\nhi\nng w\nor\nt\nh w\ni\nnni\nng, you\n \ns\nee, and I\n can t\nel\nl\n you I\n had an uphi\nl\nl\n f\ni\nght\n per\ns\nuadi\nng m\ny s\nw\neet\nhear\nt\n t\nhat\n I\n \nw\nas\n her\n one and onl\ny. She w\nas\n convi\nnced I\n w\nas\n m\nar\nr\ni\ned, and i\nt\n t\nook a heap of\n \nt\nes\nt\ni\nm\noni\nal\ns\n t\no convi\nnce her\n t\nhat\n I\n w\nas\n s\ni\nngl\ne and avai\nl\nabl\ne. She had a l\not\n of\n doubt\ns\n. I\nt\n w\nas\nn’\nt\n w\nhat\n m\nos\nt\n gi\nr\nl\ns\n w\ner\ne\n \ndoi\nng at\n t\nhe t\ni\nm\ne. When I\n w\noke up i\nn t\nhe r\necover\ny\n \nr\noom\n, i\nt\n w\nas\n dar\nk. E\nven t\nhough I\n w\nas\n ver\ny gr\noggy, I\n coul\nd t\nel\nl\n t\nhi\nngs\n w\ner\nen’\nt\n \ngoi\nng t\noo w\nel\nl\n f\nor\n m\ne. N\not\n onl\ny w\ner\ne m\ny head and back i\nn bandages\n, but\n m\ny\n \nent\ni\nr\ne ches\nt\n w\nas\n w\nr\napped i\nn gauze and com\npl\net\nel\ny cover\ned w\ni\nt\nh t\nape. I\n \nr\nem\nem\nber\n t\nhi\nnki\nng, “D\noyl\ne, t\nher\ne’\ns\n s\nom\net\nhi\nng aw\nf\nul\nl\ny w\nr\nong.” L\noui\ns\ne w\nas\n \nt\nher\ne at\n m\ny s\ni\nde t\nel\nl\ni\nng m\ne ever\nyt\nhi\nng w\nas\n goi\nng t\no be al\nl\n r\ni\nght\n, but\n I\n knew\n \ns\nhe w\nas\n t\nr\nyi\nng t\no hi\nde s\nom\net\nhi\nng. I\n w\nas\n i\nn a l\not\n of\n pai\nn, and t\nhe dr\nugs\n t\nhey\n \nkept\n f\needi\nng m\ne kept\n m\ne f\nai\nr\nl\ny s\nt\nupi\nf\ni\ned f\nor\n t\nhe next\n f\new\n days\n.\nI\n r\nem\nai\nned i\nn t\nhe hos\npi\nt\nal\n f\nor\n qui\nt\ne a w\nhi\nl\ne. M\ny r\nel\nat\ni\nves\n and f\nr\ni\nends\n w\ner\ne\n \nal\nw\nays\n com\ni\nng by t\no s\nee how\n I\n w\nas\n doi\nng. T\nhat\n w\nas\n a com\nf\nor\nt\n. \nSt\ni\nl\nl\n, nobody had t\nhe cour\nage t\no t\nel\nl\n m\ne w\nhat\n t\nhe r\neal\n s\ni\nt\nuat\ni\non w\nas\n. A\nnder\ns\non H\nos\npi\nt\nal\n i\nn H\nous\nt\non. What\n I\n had not\n been t\nol\nd w\nas\n \nt\nhat\n w\nhen t\nhe doct\nor\ns\n opened m\ne up, t\nhey f\nound m\nas\ns\ni\nve cancer\n s\npr\nead\n \nt\nhr\noughout\n m\ny body. I\nt\n had r\neached cl\nos\ne t\no t\nhe bas\ne of\n m\ny br\nai\nn, and m\ny\n \nches\nt\n and s\nt\nom\nach ar\nea w\ner\ne r\ni\nddl\ned w\ni\nt\nh i\nt\n. Four\n s\nur\ngeons\n had been cal\nl\ned i\nn\n \nand t\nhey al\nl\n agr\need t\nhat\n i\nt\n w\nas\n us\nel\nes\ns\n t\no pr\noceed. Wi\nt\nh t\nhat\n oper\nat\ni\non,\n \nt\nher\ne w\nas\n a pos\ns\ni\nbi\nl\ni\nt\ny t\nhat\n I\n’\nd be abl\ne t\no l\ni\nve l\nong enough t\no s\nee m\ny baby\n \nbef\nor\ne t\nhe cancer\n r\neached m\ny br\nai\nn.\nWe f\nl\new\n t\no H\nous\nt\non t\nhe next\n day. I\n w\nent\n i\nnt\no t\nhe\n \noper\nat\ni\nng r\noom\n at\n 10:\n30 a.m\n. I\n s\npent\n ei\nght\n hour\ns\n under\n t\nhe kni\nf\ne and at\n 6:\n30\n \np.m\n., t\nhey gave L\noui\ns\ne t\nhe new\ns\n. I\n w\nas\n goi\nng t\no m\nake i\nt\n. I\nt\n had been t\nouch\n \nand go.\nT\nhe I\nm\npos\ns\ni\nbl\ne H\nad H\nappened\nA\nt\n one poi\nnt\n dur\ni\nng t\nhe oper\nat\ni\non, m\ny bl\nood pr\nes\ns\nur\ne dr\nopped t\no zer\no, but\n \nt\nhey pul\nl\ned m\ne t\nhr\nough. What\n w\nas\n t\nr\nul\ny i\nncr\nedi\nbl\ne w\nas\n t\nhat\n t\nher\ne w\nas\n no\n \nl\nonger\n any t\nr\nace of\n cancer\n i\nn m\ny s\nys\nt\nem\n. T\nhe\n \ni\nm\npos\ns\ni\nbl\ne had happened.\nT\nhe odds\n agai\nns\nt\n m\ner\nel\ny s\nur\nvi\nvi\nng t\nhe oper\nat\ni\non i\nt\ns\nel\nf\n w\ner\ne ver\ny hi\ngh. A\n \nm\nont\nh ear\nl\ni\ner\n t\nhe bl\nack cor\nr\nupt\ni\non of\n m\nel\nanom\na had been vi\ns\ni\nbl\ne t\no t\nhe naked\n \neye. T\nhat\n t\nhe cancer\n had di\ns\nappear\ned w\nas\n i\nncom\npr\nehens\ni\nbl\ne t\no t\nhe s\nt\naf\nf\n at\n t\nhe\n \nhos\npi\nt\nal\n. Fi\nve doct\nor\ns\n had unani\nm\nous\nl\ny agr\need t\nhat\n i\nt\n w\nas\n a m\nedi\ncal\n \ni\nm\npos\ns\ni\nbi\nl\ni\nt\ny f\nor\n m\ne t\no l\ni\nve l\nonger\n t\nhan a f\new\n m\nor\ne m\nont\nhs\n, w\ni\nt\nh or\n w\ni\nt\nhout\n \nt\nhe oper\nat\ni\non.\nFor\n t\nhe next\n t\nw\no w\neeks\n, L\noui\ns\ne and Sai\nl\nor\n t\nook t\nur\nns\n w\nat\nchi\nng m\ne t\nw\nent\ny-\nf\nour\n hour\ns\n a day, s\ni\nnce w\ne coul\ndn’\nt\n af\nf\nor\nd a pr\ni\nvat\ne nur\ns\ne. I\n had t\no be\n \nobs\ner\nved cl\nos\nel\ny. T\nhe t\nubes\n t\nhat\n l\ned t\no m\ny body had t\no be checked\n \ncons\nt\nant\nl\ny, and m\ny vi\nt\nal\n s\ni\ngns\n had t\no be m\noni\nt\nor\ned cont\ni\nnuous\nl\ny. I\n don’\nt\n \nknow\n w\nhen L\noui\ns\ne and Sai\nl\nor\n got\n any s\nl\neep.\nA\nf\nt\ner\n l\neavi\nng t\nhe hos\npi\nt\nal\n, I\n r\necuper\nat\ned at\n m\ny s\ni\ns\nt\ner\n’\ns\n. When m\ny s\nt\nr\nengt\nh\n \nr\net\nur\nned, I\n r\nepor\nt\ned back t\no t\nhe hos\npi\nt\nal\n i\nn For\nt\n Wor\nt\nh f\nor\n a checkup. T\nher\ne’\ns\n a m\neani\nngl\nes\ns\n s\npot\n of\n s\nun-\ndr\ni\ned gr\nas\ns\n i\nn f\nr\nont\n of\n Puggy’\ns\n \nbal\nl\n, a bl\nem\ni\ns\nh on t\nhe gr\neen pat\nh t\no t\nhe hol\ne, but\n not\n a hi\nndr\nance t\no hi\ns\n put\nt\n i\nn\n \nany w\nay. For\n s\nom\ne r\neas\non I\n’\nl\nl\n never\n l\ni\nve l\nong enough t\no under\ns\nt\nand, Puggy\n \nm\noved hi\ns\n bal\nl\n a f\new\n i\nnches\n aw\nay f\nr\nom\n t\nhe s\nuns\npot\n, t\no no advant\nage. M\naybe\n \ni\nt\n’\ns\n j\nus\nt\n Pug’\ns\n nat\nur\ne. \nC\nhagr\na had hi\ns\n bodyguar\nd r\ni\ndi\nng i\nn t\nhe car\nt\n w\ni\nt\nh hi\nm\n.\n“J\ni\nm\nm\ny, Puggy m\noved hi\ns\n bal\nl\n,” t\nhe bodyguar\nd announced.\nWel\nl\n, C\nhagr\na w\nent\n bal\nl\ni\ns\nt\ni\nc, s\ncr\neam\ni\nng, bel\nl\now\ni\nng, t\nhr\neat\neni\nng, “I\n’\nm\n gonna\n \nbl\now\n al\nl\n you bl\nanket\ny-\nbl\nanks\n aw\nay!\n”\nI\n f\ni\ngur\ne Puggy cos\nt\n m\ne $2 m\ni\nl\nl\ni\non i\nn f\nut\nur\ne ear\nni\nngs\n t\nhat\n day, m\naybe m\nor\ne,\n \nand I\n’\nve never\n l\net\n hi\nm\n f\nor\nget\n i\nt\n. H\ne w\nas\n bani\ns\nhed f\nor\never\n \nf\nr\nom\n our\n gr\noup.\nM\ny Saddes\nt\n H\nour\nL\ni\nf\ne i\ns\n l\ni\nke poker\n s\nom\net\ni\nm\nes\n. J\nus\nt\n w\nhen t\nhi\nngs\n ar\ne goi\nng s\no good t\nhat\n you\n \nt\nhi\nnk you’\nr\ne s\nuppos\ned t\no w\ni\nn ever\ny pot\n, you get\n a m\nons\nt\ner\n hand cr\nacked, and\n \ni\nt\n s\npel\nl\ns\n t\nhe begi\nnni\nng of\n a di\nzzyi\nng dow\nnw\nar\nd s\npi\nr\nal\n. T\nhat\n’\ns\n how\n i\nt\n w\nas\n \nw\nhen D\noyl\na di\ned at\n ei\nght\neen.\nShe’\nd been at\nt\nendi\nng U\nN\nL\nV\n. We knew\n s\nhe had a val\nve pr\nobl\nem\n w\ni\nt\nh her\n \nhear\nt\n, but\n i\nt\n w\nas\nn’\nt\n s\nuppos\ned t\no be s\ner\ni\nous\n. T\nhey s\nay i\nt\n w\nas\n t\noo m\nuch\n \npot\nas\ns\ni\num\n t\nhat\n t\nook her\n f\nr\nom\n us\n. I\nt\n w\nas\n s\no unexpect\ned, l\ni\nke bei\nng ki\ncked i\nn\n \nt\nhe gut\n s\no har\nd you don’\nt\n t\nhi\nnk you can ever\n s\nt\nand up agai\nn, br\neat\nhe agai\nn.\nY\nou know\n how\n each of\n us\n s\nom\net\ni\nm\nes\n s\near\nches\n f\nor\n t\nhe m\neani\nng of\n l\ni\nf\ne?\n \nL\nos\ni\nng D\noyl\na s\nt\nar\nt\ned m\ny s\near\nch i\nn ear\nnes\nt\n. D\noyl\na w\nas\n a devout\n C\nhr\ni\ns\nt\ni\nan, as\n \ni\ns\n her\n m\not\nher\n, L\noui\ns\ne. T\no be s\nur\ne, I\n had C\nhr\ni\ns\nt\ni\nan bel\ni\nef\ns\n, t\noo. B\nut\n I\n w\nas\nn’\nt\n \nr\neal\nl\ny pr\nact\ni\nci\nng t\nhem\n. I\n gues\ns\n I\n had s\nt\nr\nayed about\n as\n f\nar\n aw\nay f\nr\nom\n G\nod as\n \nyou can and s\nt\ni\nl\nl\n be a bel\ni\never\n. I\n kept\n f\nei\ngni\nng s\nem\ni\n-\ncons\nci\nous\nnes\ns\n and gi\nvi\nng t\nhem\n t\nhe w\nr\nong com\nbi\nnat\ni\nons\n, as\nki\nng t\nhem\n t\no cal\nl\n \nt\nhe par\nam\nedi\ncs\n. Sym\npat\nhy f\nr\nom\n t\nhem\n w\nas\n not\n f\nor\nt\nhcom\ni\nng, how\never\n. I\n w\nas\n \npi\ns\nt\nol\n-\nw\nhi\npped and t\nhey br\noke m\ny nos\ne i\nn t\nhe pr\noces\ns\n. M\ny f\nace w\nas\n badl\ny cut\n \nup w\nhen L\noui\ns\ne cam\ne dow\nns\nt\nai\nr\ns\n t\no i\nnves\nt\ni\ngat\ne t\nhe com\nm\not\ni\non.\nT\nhe phone r\nang. \n“T\nhat\n’\ns\n t\nhe al\nar\nm\n com\npany,” one of\n t\nhe m\nen gr\now\nl\ned. “T\nel\nl\n t\nhem\n \never\nyt\nhi\nng’\ns\n al\nl\n r\ni\nght\n, or\n w\ne’\nl\nl\n ki\nl\nl\n you r\ni\nght\n now\n!\n”\nI\nt\n w\nas\n, i\nndeed, t\nhe s\necur\ni\nt\ny com\npany, r\nes\npondi\nng t\no a s\nt\nandar\nd al\ner\nt\n. I\nn or\nder\n \nt\no det\ner\nm\ni\nne w\nhet\nher\n t\nhi\ns\n w\nas\n a f\nal\ns\ne al\nar\nm\n, t\nhey as\nked f\nor\n a pas\ns\nw\nor\nd t\nhat\n \nw\noul\nd l\net\n t\nhem\n know\n ever\nyt\nhi\nng w\nas\n okay. L\noui\ns\ne t\nook t\nhe cal\nl\n and had t\nhe\n \npr\nes\nence of\n m\ni\nnd t\no gi\nve t\nhe w\nr\nong pas\ns\nw\nor\nd, j\nus\nt\n as\n I\n had gi\nven t\nhe w\nr\nong\n \ncodes\n. B\nut\n i\nns\nt\nead of\n pi\ncki\nng up on t\nhe cl\nue t\nhat\n s\nom\net\nhi\nng w\nas\n t\ner\nr\ni\nbl\ny\n \nam\ni\ns\ns\n at\n t\nhe B\nr\nuns\nons\n’\n r\nes\ni\ndence, t\nhe w\nom\nan on t\nhe ot\nher\n end adm\noni\ns\nhed\n \nL\noui\ns\ne, s\nayi\nng s\nhe had been gi\nven t\nhe w\nr\nong pas\ns\nw\nor\nd. \n“Y\nes\n, I\n know\n,” L\noui\ns\ne conf\ni\nr\nm\ned pol\ni\nt\nel\ny, hopi\nng t\nhe i\nnt\nr\nuder\ns\n w\noul\ndn’\nt\n \ndi\nvi\nne t\nhe di\nr\nect\ni\non of\n t\nhe phone conver\ns\nat\ni\non. She agai\nn r\nepeat\ned t\nhe i\nnval\ni\nd\n \ncode and hung up. N\now\n, you’\nd t\nhi\nnk t\nhat\n w\nas\n enough t\no s\nend hel\np on i\nt\ns\n w\nay.\n \nB\nut\n no. T\nhe phone r\nang agai\nn. A\nnd agai\nn i\nt\n w\nas\n t\nhe s\necur\ni\nt\ny com\npany. I\n can’\nt\n t\nel\nl\n you t\nhat\n t\nhe car\nds\n you’\nr\ne deal\nt\n w\ni\nl\nl\n \nbe t\nhe ones\n you w\nant\n, but\n w\nhat\never\n t\nhey t\nur\nn out\n t\no be, pl\nay t\nhem\n w\ni\ns\nel\ny.\n \nT\nhat\n’\ns\n t\nhe s\necr\net\n.\nI\nt\n al\nl\n goes\n by s\no qui\nckl\ny, l\ni\nf\ne. H\ne’\ns\n \ni\nm\npr\nes\ns\ned m\ne gr\neat\nl\ny, ever\n s\ni\nnce he t\nr\ni\num\nphed i\nn one of\n hi\ns\n f\ni\nr\ns\nt\n t\nour\nnam\nent\ns\n \nat\n t\nhe B\ni\ncycl\ne C\nl\nub. M\nany w\nor\nl\nd-\ncl\nas\ns\n pl\nayer\ns\n have t\nol\nd m\ne t\nhat\n T\nodd i\ns\n one\n \nof\n t\nhe bes\nt\n young pl\nayer\ns\n t\noday. So, don’\nt\n j\nus\nt\n go by w\nhat\n I\n s\nay. I\n coul\nd be\n \nbi\nas\ned. D\noyl\ne l\ned w\ni\nt\nh aces\n f\nul\nl\n, but\n w\nhen t\nhe doubl\ne r\nai\ns\ne\n \ncam\ne back t\no hi\nm\n, he l\nai\nd dow\nn t\nhe hand. So t\nhe cont\nr\nact\nor\n w\non t\nhe hand agai\nns\nt\n odds\n \nt\nhat\n onl\ny s\nom\ne t\nop poker\n m\nat\nhem\nat\ni\nci\nan and t\nheor\ni\ns\nt\n, s\nuch as\n M\ni\nke C\nar\no,\n \nm\ni\nght\n be i\nnt\ner\nes\nt\ned i\nn cal\ncul\nat\ni\nng. \nA\nnyw\nay, f\nour\n year\ns\n l\nat\ner\n, T\nom\n i\nnvi\nt\ned m\ne t\no par\nt\ni\nci\npat\ne i\nn t\nhe acqui\ns\ni\nt\ni\non of\n \nt\nhe H\nol\ni\nday H\not\nel\n i\nn R\neno, and t\nhanks\n t\no m\ny s\nucces\ns\n at\n hi\ns\n t\nabl\ne, I\n w\nas\n abl\ne\n \nt\no accept\n. I\nn 1967, I\n m\noved t\no N\nevada w\ni\nt\nh hi\nm\n and hi\ns\n f\nam\ni\nl\ny.\n \nU\nnf\nor\nt\nunat\nel\ny, w\ne r\nan i\nnt\no t\nr\noubl\ne s\necur\ni\nng a gam\ni\nng l\ni\ncens\ne, s\no t\nhe H\nol\ni\nday\n \nH\not\nel\n never\n qui\nt\ne panned out\n, f\nor\n m\ne at\n l\neas\nt\n. \nT\nhe or\ni\ngi\nnal\n l\ni\ncens\nees\n of\n t\nhe H\nol\ni\nday H\not\nel\n i\nn R\neno becam\ne T\nom\n, J\nohn\n \nM\nonf\nr\ney, and A\nus\nt\ni\nn H\nem\nphi\nl\nl\n, w\nho w\noul\nd l\nat\ner\n par\nt\nner\n w\ni\nt\nh R\ned M\ncC\nom\nbs\n,\n \now\nner\n of\n t\nhe M\ni\nnnes\not\na V\ni\nki\nngs\n and f\nor\nm\ner\n ow\nner\n of\n t\nhe San A\nnt\noni\no Spur\ns\n \nand D\nenver\n N\nugget\ns\n.\nB\nut\n, hot\nel\n or\n not\n, I\n w\nas\n pl\nayi\nng enough poker\n t\no keep m\ne occupi\ned. I\nt\n \nw\nas\n t\nr\nul\ny a “s\naw\ndus\nt\n j\noi\nnt\n,” w\ni\nt\nh r\ned-\nf\nl\nocked w\nal\nl\npaper\n on t\nhe w\nal\nl\ns\n and\n \noi\nl\ned s\naw\ndus\nt\n cover\ni\nng t\nhe f\nl\noor\ns\n. N\nevada and C\nal\ni\nf\nor\nni\na pl\nayer\ns\n cam\ne t\nher\ne\n \nt\no pl\nay f\ni\nve-\ncar\nd s\nt\nud, r\nazz, and C\nal\ni\nf\nor\nni\na l\now\nbal\nl\n dr\naw\n. T\nhi\ns\n w\noul\nd change\n \nw\nhen a s\nm\nal\nl\n gr\noup of\n T\nexans\n, l\ned by Fel\nt\non M\ncC\nor\nki\nndal\ne and i\nncl\nudi\nng\n \nD\noyl\ne B\nr\nuns\non, B\nr\nyan “Sai\nl\nor\n” R\nober\nt\ns\n, J\nohnny M\nos\ns\n, A\nm\nar\ni\nl\nl\no Sl\ni\nm\n, J\nack\n \nSt\nr\naus\n and m\ne, i\nnt\nr\noduced hi\ngh-\ns\nt\nakes\n no-\nl\ni\nm\ni\nt\n T\nexas\n hol\nd’\nem\n t\no N\nevada.\nT\nexas\n hol\nd’\nem\n pr\noved popul\nar\n am\nong t\nhe pl\nayer\ns\n, but\n f\nor\n year\ns\n t\nher\ne w\nas\n no\n \ncas\ni\nno ot\nher\n t\nhan t\nhe G\nol\nden N\nugget\n i\nn w\nhi\nch t\no s\npr\nead a gam\ne. T\nhe G\nol\nden\n \nN\nugget\n di\ndn’\nt\n exact\nl\ny at\nt\nr\nact\n t\nhe s\nam\ne num\nber\n of\n hi\ngh r\nol\nl\ner\n cas\ni\nno pat\nr\nons\n \nt\nhat\n t\nhe St\nr\ni\np cas\ni\nnos\n r\neel\ned i\nn by t\nhe t\nhous\nands\n. T\nhi\ns\n m\neant\n t\nher\ne w\nas\n ver\ny\n \nl\ni\nt\nt\nl\ne oppor\nt\nuni\nt\ny t\no cat\nch a dr\nop-\ni\nn pl\nayer\n or\n pr\noducer\n at\n t\nhe poker\n r\noom\n. B\nut\n \ni\nn 1969, Si\nd Wym\nan, t\nhe bos\ns\n of\n t\nhe D\nunes\n H\not\nel\n and C\nas\ni\nno, t\noday t\nhe s\ni\nt\ne\n \nof\n t\nhe B\nel\nl\nagi\no, i\nnvi\nt\ned us\n t\no s\npr\nead a hi\ngh-\ns\nt\nakes\n no-\nl\ni\nm\ni\nt\n gam\ne j\nus\nt\n out\ns\ni\nde\n \nt\nhe ent\nr\nance t\no hi\ns\n m\nai\nn s\nhow\nr\noom\n, w\nher\ne w\ne w\ner\ne abl\ne t\no cat\nch l\not\ns\n of\n dr\nop-\ni\nns\n, i\nncl\nudi\nng t\nhe l\nat\ne M\naj\nor\n R\ni\nddl\ne, t\nhe m\naj\nor\ni\nt\ny ow\nner\n of\n t\nhe D\nunes\n. \nR\nem\nem\nber\n, N\nevadans\n and C\nal\ni\nf\nor\nni\nans\n w\ner\ne pr\ni\nm\nar\ni\nl\ny f\ni\nve-\ncar\nd s\nt\nud pl\nayer\ns\n.\n \nA\nnd al\nt\nhough he w\nas\n or\ni\ngi\nnal\nl\ny f\nr\nom\n L\nockhar\nt\n, T\nexas\n, R\ni\nddl\ne w\nas\n by now\n a\n \nt\nr\nans\npl\nant\ned N\nevadan. A\ns\n s\nuch, he had no exper\ni\nence pl\nayi\nng a gam\ne t\nhat\n \nr\nequi\nr\ned s\nuch s\nubl\ni\nm\ne s\nt\nr\nat\negy, and i\nt\n i\ns\n f\nai\nr\n t\no s\nay t\nhat\n he and ot\nher\ns\n new\n t\no\n \nt\nhe gam\ne w\ner\ne f\naced w\ni\nt\nh a s\nt\neep l\near\nni\nng cur\nve. When al\nl\n t\nhe car\nds\n w\ner\ne out\n, t\nhe boar\nd w\nas\n K\n-\nK\n-\n9-\n9-\nJ\n. M\nos\ns\n m\noved i\nn\n \non R\ni\nddl\ne, and R\ni\nddl\ne cal\nl\ned hi\nm\n. R\ni\nddl\ne\n \nhad a w\ni\nr\ned pai\nr\n, and he w\nas\n not\n about\n t\no l\nay t\nhem\n dow\nn, not\n r\neal\ni\nzi\nng t\nhat\n he\n \nhad t\nhe w\nor\ns\nt\n hand pos\ns\ni\nbl\ne i\nn t\nhi\ns\n s\ni\nt\nuat\ni\non and coul\nd not\n even beat\n t\nhe f\ni\nve\n \ncar\nds\n on t\nhe boar\nd. \nO\nne pl\nayer\n, J\noe R\nubi\nno, w\nho w\nas\n f\nr\nom\n A\nl\nabam\na and a good K\nans\nas\n C\ni\nt\ny\n \nl\now\nbal\nl\n pl\nayer\n (\nbut\n not\n m\nuch of\n a T\nexas\n hol\nd’\nem\n pl\nayer\n)\n, w\nent\n s\no f\nar\n as\n t\no\n \nr\negi\ns\nt\ner\n an obj\nect\ni\non t\no J\nohnny w\ni\nnni\nng t\nhe pot\n. R\nubi\nno cl\nai\nm\ned t\nhat\n s\ni\nnce\n \nR\ni\nddl\ne coul\nd not\n beat\n t\nhe boar\nd w\ni\nt\nh hi\ns\n t\nw\no deuces\n, he s\nhoul\nd be abl\ne t\no t\nake\n \nhi\ns\n l\nas\nt\n cal\nl\n back. I\nt\n di\ndn’\nt\n t\nake J\nohnny but\n a s\necond t\no t\nel\nl\n hi\nm\n t\nhat\n \ns\nom\net\ni\nm\nes\n t\nhe boar\nd i\ns\n t\nhe bes\nt\n pos\ns\ni\nbl\ne hand i\nn T\nexas\n hol\nd’\nem\n and t\nhat\n hi\ns\n \ncom\nm\nent\n s\nhow\ned how\n l\ni\nt\nt\nl\ne he knew\n about\n t\nhe gam\ne. H\ne al\ns\no t\nol\nd hi\nm\n a\n \ncoupl\ne of\n ot\nher\n t\nhi\nngs\n about\n m\ni\nndi\nng hi\ns\n ow\nn bus\ni\nnes\ns\n w\nhen he w\nas\n not\n \ni\nnvol\nved i\nn a pot\n.\nA\ns\n t\nhe gam\ne began t\no cat\nch on i\nn L\nas\n V\negas\n dur\ni\nng t\nhe l\nat\ne s\ni\nxt\ni\nes\n and ear\nl\ny\n \ns\nevent\ni\nes\n, hi\ngh s\nt\nakes\n no-\nl\ni\nm\ni\nt\n T\nexas\n hol\nd’\nem\n gam\nes\n r\nanged f\nr\nom\n $10,000 t\no\n \n$100,000 change-\ni\nn (\nt\nhat\n’\ns\n about\n $60,000 -\n $600,000 i\nn t\ner\nm\ns\n of\n t\noday’\ns\n \ndol\nl\nar\n)\n. \nI\nn 1968, T\nom\n and L\naf\nayne M\noor\ne deci\nded t\no hol\nd a t\nabl\ne gam\nes\n t\nour\nnam\nent\n \ni\nn or\nder\n t\no pr\nom\not\ne t\nhe H\nol\ni\nday H\not\nel\n i\nn R\neno. T\nhey des\ni\ngned el\nabor\nat\ne\n \ni\nnvi\nt\nat\ni\nons\n t\no T\nhe Fi\nr\ns\nt\n A\nnnual\n G\nam\ni\nng Fr\nat\ner\nni\nt\ny C\nonvent\ni\non and s\nent\n t\nhem\n \nt\no a s\nel\nect\n gr\noup of\n appr\noxi\nm\nat\nel\ny f\ni\nf\nt\ny hi\ngh r\nol\nl\ner\ns\n. T\nhi\ns\n w\nas\n \nt\nhe f\ni\nr\ns\nt\n ever\n m\naj\nor\n poker\n t\nour\nnam\nent\n, and i\nt\n dr\new\n t\nw\nent\ny or\n t\nhi\nr\nt\ny poker\n \npl\nayer\ns\n, bookm\naker\ns\n, and pool\n hus\nt\nl\ner\ns\n, i\nncl\nudi\nng m\nys\nel\nf\n, J\nohnny M\nos\ns\n,\n \nD\noyl\ne B\nr\nuns\non, J\nam\nes\n “L\nonggoodi\ne” R\noy, A\nubr\ney D\nay, B\nenny B\ni\nni\non,\n \nA\nm\nar\ni\nl\nl\no Sl\ni\nm\n, Puggy Pear\ns\non, J\ni\nm\nm\ny C\nas\nel\nl\na, M\ni\nnnes\not\na Fat\ns\n, B\ni\nl\nl\n B\noyd,\n \nJ\nack St\nr\naus\n, Fel\nt\non “C\nor\nky” M\ncC\nor\nki\nndal\ne, G\neor\nge B\nar\nnes\n, “Sai\nl\nor\n” R\nober\nt\ns\n,\n \nJ\nohnny J\nos\neph, and t\nhe not\nor\ni\nous\n f\nat\nher\n of\n act\nor\n Woody H\nar\nr\nel\ns\non, C\nhar\nl\nes\n,\n \nnow\n s\ner\nvi\nng l\ni\nf\ne f\nor\n t\nhe 1979 as\ns\nas\ns\ni\nnat\ni\non of\n J\nohn H\n. A\nl\nl\n t\nhe gam\nes\n w\ner\ne\n \n“l\ni\nve” gam\nes\n, t\nhat\n i\ns\n, pl\nayer\ns\n coul\nd r\nebuy chi\nps\n i\nf\n t\nhey w\nent\n br\noke. T\nhi\ns\n \nm\neant\n t\nhat\n t\nhe w\ni\nnner\n had t\no be t\nhe bes\nt\n pl\nayer\n, not\n j\nus\nt\n t\nhe l\nucki\nes\nt\n. \nA\nt\n t\nhi\ns\n t\nour\nnam\nent\n, I\n w\non t\nhe “M\nr\n. O\nut\ns\ni\nde” t\nr\nophy, des\ni\ngnat\ni\nng m\ne as\n t\nhe\n \nbes\nt\n out\ns\ni\nde or\n r\noad gam\nbl\ner\n at\n t\nhe t\nour\nnam\nent\n. O\nddl\ny enough, bot\nh T\nom\n \nM\noor\ne and B\ni\nl\nl\n B\noyd, w\nho r\nan t\nhei\nr\n ow\nn gam\nes\n and t\nher\nef\nor\ne w\ner\ne t\nhought\n \nof\n as\n i\nns\ni\nde gam\nbl\ner\ns\n, w\ner\ne under\n cons\ni\nder\nat\ni\non f\nor\n t\nhe aw\nar\nd as\n w\nel\nl\n.\nB\nenny and J\nack B\ni\nni\non w\ner\ne i\nm\npr\nes\ns\ned w\ni\nt\nh t\nhe s\nucces\ns\n of\n t\nhe t\nour\nnam\nent\n \nand acqui\nr\ned t\nhe r\ni\nght\ns\n t\no i\nt\n w\nhen T\nom\n M\noor\ne s\nol\nd t\nhe H\nol\ni\nday i\nn 1970. T\nhey\n \nr\nenam\ned i\nt\n t\nhe Wor\nl\nd Ser\ni\nes\n of\n Poker\n. For\n t\nhe i\nnaugur\nal\n t\nour\nnam\nent\n, w\nhi\nch\n \nw\nas\n hel\nd at\n B\ni\nni\non’\ns\n H\nor\ns\nes\nhoe C\nas\ni\nno, he r\net\nai\nned t\nhe m\nul\nt\ni\n-\ngam\ne f\nor\nm\nat\n of\n \nM\noor\ne’\ns\n G\nam\ni\nng Fr\nat\ner\nni\nt\ny C\nonvent\ni\non, but\n w\ni\nt\nh t\nhe except\ni\non of\n a f\new\n \nbookm\naker\ns\n, t\nher\ne w\ner\ne no pr\noducer\ns\n. E\nven t\nhough t\nhe pr\noducer\ns\n had not\n yet\n \nf\nound t\nhei\nr\n w\nay t\no t\nhe Wor\nl\nd Ser\ni\nes\n of\n Poker\n, t\nhi\ns\n t\nour\nnam\nent\n w\nas\n as\n \ns\nucces\ns\nf\nul\n as\n i\nt\ns\n pr\nedeces\ns\nor\n. B\nut\n unl\ni\nke T\nom\n M\noor\ne’\ns\n t\nour\nnam\nent\n, t\nhe f\ni\nr\ns\nt\n \nWor\nl\nd Ser\ni\nes\n of\n Poker\n w\nas\n at\nt\nended by var\ni\nous\n r\nepr\nes\nent\nat\ni\nves\n of\n t\nhe pr\ni\nnt\n \nm\nedi\na.\nT\nhe f\nol\nl\now\ni\nng year\n, L\nos\n A\nngel\nes\n T\ni\nm\nes\n j\nour\nnal\ni\ns\nt\n T\ned T\nhackr\ney s\nugges\nt\ned t\no\n \nB\ni\nni\non a new\n f\nor\nm\nat\n:\n a s\ni\nngl\ne no-\nl\ni\nm\ni\nt\n T\nexas\n hol\nd’\nem\n t\nour\nnam\nent\n.  Document(page_content='(\nbookm\naker\ns\n, oi\nl\nm\nen, bus\ni\nnes\ns\nm\nen, and s\no on)\n t\nhat\n m\nake a no-\nl\ni\nm\ni\nt\n gam\ne\n \nt\nhr\ni\nve. T\nhanks\n t\no t\nhe exci\nt\nem\nent\n gener\nat\ned by B\ni\nni\non’\ns\n PR\n cam\npai\ngn, t\nher\ne\n \nw\nas\n no s\nhor\nt\nage of\n pr\noducer\ns\n at\n t\nhe 1971 Wor\nl\nd Ser\ni\nes\n of\n Poker\n. I\nn L\nas\n \nV\negas\n, t\nhi\ns\n w\nas\n t\nhe begi\nnni\nng of\n t\nhe hal\ncyon days\n of\n no-\nl\ni\nm\ni\nt\n poker\n.\nA\nt\n one s\nuch l\ni\nve gam\ne i\nn t\nhe s\nevent\ni\nes\n, D\noyl\ne B\nr\nuns\non and I\n t\nook on a\n \npr\noducer\n nam\ned R\nex C\naubl\ne, a T\nexan w\nho ow\nned t\nw\no excl\nus\ni\nve w\nes\nt\ner\nn\n \nw\near\n and t\nack s\nhops\n i\nn D\nal\nl\nas\n and H\nous\nt\non, w\nhi\nch he nam\ned “C\nut\nt\ner\n B\ni\nl\nl\n’\ns\n”\n \naf\nt\ner\n a f\nam\nous\n cut\nt\ni\nng hor\ns\ne. A\ns\n i\nt\n l\nat\ner\n t\nur\nned out\n, R\nex w\nas\n al\ns\no i\nm\npor\nt\ni\nng\n \ncer\nt\nai\nn agr\ni\ncul\nt\nur\nal\n pr\noduct\ns\n f\nr\nom\n M\nexi\nco t\nhat\n t\nhe D\nE\nA\n obj\nect\ned t\no. A\nnyw\nay,\n \nR\nex l\ni\nked t\no pl\nay hi\ngh change i\nn no-\nl\ni\nm\ni\nt\n T\nexas\n hol\nd’\nem\n, and he w\noul\nd s\nhow\n \nup at\n t\nhe H\nor\ns\nes\nhoe dur\ni\nng t\nhe Wor\nl\nd Ser\ni\nes\n of\n Poker\n w\ni\nt\nh a s\ni\nzeabl\ne\n \nbankr\nol\nl\n. \nN\now\n, D\noyl\ne and I\n have been f\nr\ni\nends\n f\nor\n over\n f\nor\nt\ny year\ns\n, and w\ne’\nve pl\nayed i\nn\n \ncount\nl\nes\ns\n gam\nes\n t\noget\nher\n—but\n none have ever\n been as\n s\nt\nr\nange as\n t\nhi\ns\n one.\n \nO\nn t\nhi\ns\n par\nt\ni\ncul\nar\n eveni\nng, R\nex w\nant\ned t\no pl\nay a $50,000 change-\ni\nn gam\ne.\n \nFour\n or\n f\ni\nve of\n us\n t\nook hi\nm\n up on t\nhe chal\nl\nenge. B\nut\n f\ni\nr\ns\nt\n, D\noyl\ne w\nas\n gr\naci\nous\n \nenough t\no gi\nve R\nex a t\nhi\nr\nt\ny-\nm\ni\nnut\ne cr\nas\nh cour\ns\ne on t\nhe f\ni\nner\n poi\nnt\ns\n of\n \nhol\nd’\nem\n. O\nnl\ny af\nt\ner\n R\nex w\nas\n cer\nt\nai\nn he had enough of\n t\nhe bas\ni\ncs\n t\no pl\nay\n \ncr\nedi\nbl\ny, di\nd w\ne al\nl\n s\ni\nt\n dow\nn. \nL\nes\ns\n t\nhan t\nhi\nr\nt\ny m\ni\nnut\nes\n i\nnt\no t\nhe gam\ne, an unr\nai\ns\ned pot\n cam\ne up bet\nw\neen R\nex\n \nand poker\n w\nor\nl\nd cham\npi\non B\nobby B\nal\ndw\ni\nn, w\nho beat\n m\ne i\nn 1978 f\nor\n t\nhe t\ni\nt\nl\ne\n \nand w\nho i\ns\n now\n Pr\nes\ni\ndent\n of\n t\nhe B\nel\nl\nagi\no and C\nE\nO\n of\n t\nhe M\ni\nr\nage pr\noper\nt\ni\nes\n.\n \nT\nher\ne cam\ne a f\nl\nop of\n K\n-\nJ\n-\n2, t\nhr\nee s\nui\nt\ns\n. B\nobby checked i\nn f\nr\nont\n, and R\nex\n \nchecked. T\nhe t\nur\nn car\nd w\nas\n a 6, and bot\nh pl\nayer\ns\n agai\nn checked. T\nhe r\ni\nver\n \ns\nhow\ned a 4, w\ni\nt\nh no f\nl\nus\nh pos\ns\ni\nbl\ne. B\nobby checked, R\nex bet\n $1,500, and\n \nB\nobby r\nai\ns\ned $30,000. \nR\nex, w\ni\nt\nh $60,000 i\nn f\nr\nont\n of\n hi\nm\n, ponder\ned and ponder\ned, s\neem\ni\nng t\no\n \ncons\ni\nder\n f\nol\ndi\nng i\nn or\nder\n t\no pr\nes\ner\nve hal\nf\n hi\ns\n s\nt\nack. Fi\nnal\nl\ny, cl\near\nl\ny\n \ni\nnt\ni\nm\ni\ndat\ned, he r\nel\nuct\nant\nl\ny cal\nl\ned. \nB\nobby t\nr\ni\num\nphant\nl\ny r\nol\nl\ned 3-\n5 out\n of\n t\nhe hol\ne f\nor\n t\nhe nut\ns\n. R\nex had j\nus\nt\n s\nm\noot\nh cal\nl\ned w\ni\nt\nh t\nhe nut\ns\n. \nA\nt\n t\nhi\ns\n poi\nnt\n, D\noyl\ne ut\nt\ner\ned hi\ns\n f\navor\ni\nt\ne phr\nas\ne of\n as\nt\noni\ns\nhm\nent\n:\n “I\n’\nl\nl\n be a\n \ns\nunbur\nned s\non of\n a bi\nt\nch.” I\n had t\no s\nuppr\nes\ns\n a l\naugh. B\nut\n back i\nn t\nhe ear\nl\ny\n \ndays\n of\n t\nhe Wor\nl\nd Ser\ni\nes\n of\n Poker\n, t\nhi\ns\n ki\nnd of\n t\nhi\nng happened. T\nhe\n \nt\nour\nnam\nent\n at\nt\nr\nact\ned m\nany pr\noducer\ns\n l\ni\nke R\nex, and s\nom\ne pl\nayed w\ni\nt\nh us\n f\nor\n \neven hi\ngher\n s\nt\nakes\n.\nT\nhe popul\nar\ni\nt\ny of\n t\nhe Wor\nl\nd Ser\ni\nes\n w\nas\n not\n l\nos\nt\n on Si\nd Wym\nan, an af\nf\nabl\ne\n \nm\nan and t\nhe publ\ni\nc r\nel\nat\ni\nons\n di\nr\nect\nor\n f\nor\n t\nhe D\nunes\n and t\nhe A\nl\naddi\nn. Whi\nl\ne at\n f\ni\nr\ns\nt\n, t\nhi\ns\n w\nas\n s\neen as\n a pos\ni\nt\ni\nve change f\nor\n t\nhe\n \nt\nour\nnam\nent\n, i\nt\n had t\nhe i\nr\noni\nc ef\nf\nect\n of\n cr\now\ndi\nng out\n t\nhe l\ni\nve gam\nes\n—t\nhe ver\ny\n \nr\neas\non w\ne had s\nt\nar\nt\ned t\nhe WSO\nP i\nn t\nhe f\ni\nr\ns\nt\n pl\nace!\n \nT\noday, t\nhe gam\ne of\n no-\nl\ni\nm\ni\nt\n T\nexas\n hol\nd’\nem\n t\nhat\n w\ne i\nnt\nr\noduced t\no N\nevada s\no\n \nm\nany year\ns\n ago has\n been t\nr\nans\nf\nor\nm\ned, t\nhanks\n t\no i\nt\ns\n ent\ner\nt\nai\nnm\nent\n val\nue, t\no\n \nt\nel\nevi\ns\ni\non audi\nences\n. E\nver\n i\nncr\neas\ni\nng par\nt\ni\nci\npat\ni\non i\nn m\naj\nor\n f\nr\neeze-\nout\n \nt\nour\nnam\nent\ns\n (\nm\nor\ne t\nhan 2,500 pl\nayer\ns\n i\nn t\nhe 2004 Wor\nl\nd Ser\ni\nes\n of\n Poker\n)\n \nhave f\nor\nced t\nour\nnam\nent\n hos\nt\ns\n t\no i\nm\npos\ne r\napi\ndl\ny i\nncr\neas\ni\nng ant\ne and bl\ni\nnd\n \ns\nt\nr\nuct\nur\nes\n i\nn or\nder\n t\no keep t\nhe t\nour\nnam\nent\n t\ni\nm\nes\n m\nanageabl\ne. A\nnd t\nhi\ns\n has\n \npr\noduced an aber\nr\nat\ni\non of\n t\nhe pur\ne f\nor\nm\n of\n t\nhe gam\ne. Wi\nt\nh cer\nt\nai\nn not\nabl\ne\n \nexcept\ni\nons\n, t\nhe gam\ne of\n no-\nl\ni\nm\ni\nt\n T\nexas\n hol\nd’\nem\n i\ns\n a gam\ne des\ni\ngned t\no be\n \npl\nayed af\nt\ner\n t\nhe f\nl\nop. T\nhat\n’\ns\n w\nhen t\nhe r\neal\n pl\nay i\ns\n s\nuppos\ned t\no begi\nn.\n \nH\now\never\n, m\nany hands\n s\neen at\n t\nel\nevi\ns\ned event\ns\n t\noday ar\ne pl\nayed bef\nor\ne t\nhe\n \nf\nl\nop, w\nhen t\nhe pl\nayer\ns\n have r\necei\nved onl\ny t\nhei\nr\n hol\necar\nds\n. T\nhi\ns\n s\nt\nyl\ne of\n pl\nay,\n \ns\nom\net\ni\nm\nes\n r\nef\ner\nr\ned t\no as\n “cat\nch an ace and t\nake a r\nace,” r\ne-\ni\nnt\nr\noduces\n a\n \ns\nubs\nt\nant\ni\nal\n am\nount\n of\n l\nuck i\nnt\no a gam\ne t\nhat\n had al\nw\nays\n f\navor\ned t\nhe bes\nt\n \npl\nayer\n over\n t\nhe bes\nt\n car\nd cat\ncher\n.\nB\nut\n i\nt\n appear\ns\n t\nhat\n not\nhi\nng can s\nt\nop an i\ndea w\nhos\ne t\ni\nm\ne has\n com\ne. A\nnd f\nor\n \nt\nhe hundr\neds\n of\n t\nhous\nands\n, i\nf\n not\n m\ni\nl\nl\ni\nons\n, of\n pl\nayer\ns\n now\n act\ni\nve on t\nhe\n \nonl\ni\nne poker\n s\ni\nt\nes\n ar\nound t\nhe w\nor\nl\nd, s\nur\nel\ny t\nhe t\ni\nm\ne has\n com\ne. I\nn t\nhe f\nut\nur\ne,\n \nyou can expect\n t\no s\nee t\ni\nm\ne m\nanagem\nent\n pr\nobl\nem\ns\n devel\nop f\nor\n t\nhe t\nour\nnam\nent\n \nhos\nt\ns\n as\n m\nor\ne and m\nor\ne of\n t\nhe I\nnt\ner\nnet\n pl\nayer\ns\n gai\nn ent\nr\ni\nes\n i\nnt\no t\nhe m\naj\nor\n \nt\nour\nnam\nent\ns\n.\nL\nooki\nng i\nnt\no t\nhe f\nut\nur\ne, i\nt\n’\ns\n not\n har\nd t\no i\nm\nagi\nne t\nhe cr\neat\ni\non of\n a pr\nof\nes\ns\ni\nonal\n \npoker\n l\neague, w\ni\nt\nh s\never\nal\n t\neam\ns\n s\nel\nect\ned by s\nom\ne s\nor\nt\n of\n dr\naf\nt\n.  Document(page_content='O\nN\nL\nI\nN\nE\n PO\nK\nE\nR\nby D\noyl\ne B\nr\nuns\non\nT\nechnol\nogy s\nur\nr\nounds\n us\n. T\nhi\nngs\n change. A\nnd t\nhe s\nw\ni\nf\nt\nnes\ns\n of\n change t\noday\n \ni\ns\n unpar\nal\nl\nel\ned i\nn hi\ns\nt\nor\ny. N\not\nhi\nng m\nakes\n poker\n pl\nayer\ns\n m\nor\ne aw\nar\ne of\n t\nhi\ns\n \nchange t\nhan t\nhe advent\n of\n onl\ni\nne poker\n. \nC\nom\nput\ner\ns\n changed ever\nyt\nhi\nng—f\nr\nom\n pr\noduct\ni\nvi\nt\ny, t\no r\nes\near\nch, t\no gam\nes\n.\n \nPoker\n, t\noo. Y\nou s\nee, al\nong cam\ne t\nhe I\nnt\ner\nnet\n and s\nuddenl\ny you coul\nd f\ni\nnd\n \nal\nm\nos\nt\n any ans\nw\ner\n i\nn s\neconds\n, be anyw\nher\ne i\nn t\nhe w\nor\nl\nd, i\nns\nt\nant\nl\ny—not\n \nphys\ni\ncal\nl\ny, of\n cour\ns\ne, but\n w\ne l\near\nned w\ne di\ndn’\nt\n need t\no be phys\ni\ncal\nl\ny pr\nes\nent\n \nt\no be t\nher\ne. A\nnd s\no w\ne coul\nd pl\nay poker\n w\ni\nt\nhout\n bei\nng phys\ni\ncal\nl\ny pr\nes\nent\n. We\n \ncoul\nd be at\n t\nhe t\nabl\ne. I\nns\nt\nant\nl\ny.\nI\n r\nem\nem\nber\n t\nhe f\ni\nr\ns\nt\n t\ni\nm\ne I\n pl\nayed poker\n onl\ni\nne w\nas\n i\nn 1999. I\n t\nhi\nnk i\nt\n w\nas\n a\n \nt\ni\nny $3 l\ni\nm\ni\nt\n gam\ne, and I\n w\nas\n us\ned t\no pl\nayi\nng $2,000 l\ni\nm\ni\nt\n and hi\ngher\n gam\nes\n \nw\nher\ne you coul\nd w\ni\nn or\n l\nos\ne upw\nar\nds\n of\n $1 m\ni\nl\nl\ni\non w\ni\nt\nhout\n l\neavi\nng your\n s\neat\n.\n \nI\n’\nd got\nt\nen cur\ni\nous\n, becaus\ne M\ni\nke C\nar\no had endor\ns\ned an onl\ni\nne poker\n s\ni\nt\ne, and\n \nI\n t\nhought\n t\nhi\ns\n w\nas\n s\nt\nr\nange, cons\ni\nder\ni\nng he had pr\nevi\nous\nl\ny w\nr\ni\nt\nt\nen a col\num\nn\n \nw\nar\nni\nng of\n t\nhe pi\nt\nf\nal\nl\ns\n of\n onl\ni\nne pl\nay. I\nf\n he’\nd changed hi\ns\n m\ni\nnd, t\nhen t\nhe l\neas\nt\n \nI\n coul\nd do w\nas\n i\nnves\nt\ni\ngat\ne f\nor\n m\nys\nel\nf\n. R\nem\nar\nkabl\ny, i\nt\n w\nas\n as\n exci\nt\ni\nng as\n any\n \npoker\n I\n’\nd ever\n pl\nayed. T\nher\ne I\n w\nas\n, par\nt\ni\nci\npat\ni\nng i\nn poker\n on t\nhe s\ncr\neen w\ni\nt\nh\n \nopponent\ns\n s\neat\ned i\nnches\n aw\nay, but\n know\ni\nng t\nhey w\ner\nen’\nt\n act\nual\nl\ny i\nnches\n \naw\nay. T\nhey w\ner\ne i\nn E\nngl\nand and G\ner\nm\nany and H\nong K\nong. E\nver\nyw\nher\ne. I\n \nw\nas\n pl\nayi\nng poker\n i\nn a gam\ne t\nhat\n coul\nd never\n have been pos\ns\ni\nbl\ne bef\nor\ne.\nA\n T\nO\nR\nN\nA\nD\nO\nA\nnd s\no, unexpect\ned and out\n of\n now\nher\ne, onl\ni\nne poker\n bl\new\n ont\no t\nhe s\ncene. I\nt\n \nw\nas\n l\ni\nke a t\nor\nnado s\nw\neepi\nng dow\nn t\nhe T\nexas\n Panhandl\ne. A\nnd I\n r\neal\ni\nzed—\ngr\nudgi\nngl\ny at\n f\ni\nr\ns\nt\n—t\nhat\n i\nt\n w\nas\n her\ne t\no s\nt\nay. Y\nou coul\nd now\n put\n poker\n i\nnt\no\n \nt\nw\no m\nai\nn cat\negor\ni\nes\n:\n onl\ni\nne poker\n and r\neal\n-\nw\nor\nl\nd poker\n. N\not\ni\nce t\nhat\n I\n’\nm\n \ns\nayi\nng “r\neal\n-\nw\nor\nl\nd” poker\n, not\n “r\neal\n” poker\n. T\nhat\n’\ns\n becaus\ne onl\ni\nne poker\n i\ns\n \nr\neal\n poker\n. Sadl\ny, t\nhat\n \nt\nhr\ni\nl\nl\n i\ns\n gone f\nr\nom\n onl\ni\nne poker\n. C\ner\nt\nai\nnl\ny,\n \nt\nher\ne’\ns\n no equi\nval\nent\n i\nn r\neal\n-\nw\nor\nl\nd poker\n.\nR\neas\non #9:\n Pr\ne-\nSel\nect\n B\nut\nt\nons\nO\nne of\n t\nhe gr\neat\n i\nnvent\ni\nons\n of\n onl\ni\nne poker\n ar\ne t\nhe ear\nl\ny act\ni\non or\n pr\ne-\ns\nel\nect\n \nbut\nt\nons\n. I\nn r\neal\n-\nw\nor\nl\nd poker\n, pr\ne-\ns\nel\nect\ni\nng w\noul\ndn’\nt\n be appr\nopr\ni\nat\ne, becaus\ne t\nhat\n w\noul\nd l\net\n opponent\ns\n w\nho act\n \nbef\nor\ne you know\n how\n you pl\nanned t\no r\nes\npond.\nT\nhe ear\nl\ny act\ni\non choi\nces\n hel\np s\npeed up t\nhe pl\nay, and t\nhey’\nr\ne es\npeci\nal\nl\ny us\nef\nul\n \ni\nf\n you’\nr\ne pl\nayi\nng ot\nher\n gam\nes\n s\ni\nm\nul\nt\naneous\nl\ny. I\nt\n’\ns\n \na s\nt\nr\nai\nght\n l\ni\nm\ni\nt\n gam\ne, and I\n’\nm\n w\nai\nt\ni\nng f\nor\n D\nr\n. B\nl\nueber\nr\ny, at\n t\nhe bot\nt\nom\n of\n t\nhe\n \ns\ncr\neen, t\no act\n.
